Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Federal Heights Municipal Code" and may be also cited as the "Federal Heights Code." 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-1) 
Charter reference- Codification, §§ 4.8, 4.9. 
State Law reference- Codes adopted by reference, C.R.S. § 31-16-201 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section or ordinance, or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of this Code: 
    Generally. All terms and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical terms and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    Charter. Whenever the term "Charter" is used in this Code, it shall mean and refer to the Charter of the City of Federal Heights, Colorado as printed in Part I of this volume. 
    City . The term "city" shall mean the City of Federal Heights, Colorado. 
    City council or council . The term "city council" or "council" shall mean the city council of the City of Federal Heights, Colorado. 
    Code . The term "Code" shall be deemed to mean the Federal Heights Municipal Code, as published and subsequently amended, unless the context requires otherwise. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, but if the time for an act to be done shall fall on Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, the act shall be done upon the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, C.R.S. § 2-4-108. 
    County. The term "county" means the County of Adams, Colorado. 
    C.R.S. The abbreviation "C.R.S." shall mean the latest edition or supplement of the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer or employee to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Gender. Every term in any ordinance importing the masculine shall extend to and be applied to females as well as males, and associations and bodies corporate as well as individuals shall be included. 
State Law reference- Gender, C.R.S. § 2-4-103. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and co-partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Number. A term importing the singular may extend and be applied to the plural, and vice versa. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.R.S. § 2-4-106. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officer, department, employee, board, committee, or commission. Whenever reference is made to an officer, department, employee, board, committee, or commission, it shall be deemed to refer to an officer, department, employee, board, committee, or commission of the city. 
    Owner . The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person . The term "person" means an individual, corporation, government, governmental subdivision or agency, business, trust, estate, trust, partnership, association or any other legal entity. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real, personal and mixed property. 
    Public place means any place commonly or usually open to the general public or to which members of the general public may resort, or accessible to members of the general public. By way of illustration, such public places include, but are not limited to, public ways, streets, buildings, sidewalks, alleys, parking lots, shopping centers, shopping malls, mobile home parks, common areas of private buildings and facilities, and places of business usually open to the general public, but shall not include the interior or yard area of private homes, residences, condominiums, apartments, or mobile homes. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Reasonable time. In all cases where any ordinance or provision of this Code shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such duty, or compliance with such notice. 
    Shall, may. The term "shall" is mandatory and the term "may;" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The term "state" shall mean the State of Colorado. 
    Street. The term "street" shall embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the county. 
    Tenant . The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written or in writing. The terms "written" or "in writing" shall include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-2) 
Charter reference- Definitions, art. 20. 
State Law reference- Definitions, C.R.S. § 2-4-101 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section; nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - References to chapters or sections. 
    All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code and all amendments or as may be amended unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Code does not affect prior offenses, penalties, contracts, rights. 
    Nothing in this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances or resolutions. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not revive any ordinance or resolution in force before or at the time the ordinance or resolution repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance or resolution repealed. 
Sec. 1-9. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  Any additions or amendments to this Code shall be adopted as Ordinances as required by the Charter, and when passed in such forms as to indicate the intention to make the same a part thereof, shall be incorporated into this Code so that reference to it as the Federal Heights Municipal Code, shall be understood as including such additions or amendments. 
(b)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(c)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in language substantially as follows: "That section _____ of the Federal Heights Municipal Code is hereby amended to read as follows: ... (words and numbers to be deleted are stricken through; words and numbers to be added are underlined)." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  If a new section not then existing in the Code is to be added, then language substantially as follows may be used: "That the Federal Heights Municipal Code is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered _____, which section reads as follows: ... (words and numbers to be deleted are stricken through; words and numbers to be added are underlined)." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(e)  All sections, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-3) 
Charter reference- Ordinance adoption procedure, § 4.6. 
Sec. 1-10. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement, may make nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. 
(4)  Change the term "this ordinance" or terms of the same meaning to "this chapter," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____." The inserted section numbers will indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code. 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or affect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this Code are hereby declared to be severable, and if any section, provision, or part thereof shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, the remainder of this Code shall continue in full force and effect, it being the legislative intent that this Code would have been adopted even if such unconstitutional matter had not been included therein. It is further declared that if any provision or part of this Code, in the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this Code and the application thereof to other persons shall not be affected thereby. 
(Code 1985, §§ 1-1-4, 1-1-8) 
Charter reference- Severability of ordinances, § 4.5. 
Sec. 1-12. - Repeal. 
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted by the city before the effective date of this Code, are included herein unless specifically repealed hereby; provided, however, that any ordinances establishing salaries, establishing any contract right, authorizing the issuance of any bonds or evidence of indebtedness of the city, relating to the annual appropriation of the annual tax levy, granting any franchise, annexing territory to the city, naming streets or alleys, creating or assessing any local improvement district, or authorizing the sale, purchase or lease of property by the city, shall not be considered to be ordinances of a general and permanent nature and the same are not hereby repealed nor included herein. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-5) 
Sec. 1-13. - Effect of repealing ordinances. 
    The repeal of any provision of any ordinance shall not affect any right which has accrued, any duty imposed, any penalty incurred, nor any action or proceedings as commenced under or by virtue of the provision repealed, nor the tenure of an office of any person holding office at the time when such repeal shall take effect. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-6) 
Sec. 1-14. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred before the effective date of this Code. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract, right, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument or obligation assumed by the city or authorizing the purchase or sale of city property. 
(3)  Any administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or any ordinance regarding franchises. 
(5)  Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(6)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes. 
(7)  Any zoning or rezoning ordinance or amendment to the zoning map or zoning regulations. 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city. 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(11)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory or any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city. 
(12)  Any ordinance establishing positions, setting salaries of city officers and employees or establishing retirement systems or other employee benefits and any personnel regulations. 
(13)  Any temporary or special ordinances. 
(14)  Any ordinance calling elections or prescribing the manner of conducting the election in accordance with state law. 
(15)  Any ordinance prescribing any rates, charges, deposits, fees or other payment of money to the city. 
All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code and are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-15. - Penalties. 
(a)  (1)  Except as otherwise specified in paragraph (2) below, whenever any provision of this Code, or any provision of a rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, or the doing of any act is required, prohibited, or declared to be unlawful and no definite fine or penalty is provided for a violation thereof, any person convicted of a violation of any such provision shall, for each offense, be punished by a fine not exceeding, at the time of the commission of the offense, the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations. 
Nothing herein shall be deemed to restrict the municipal court in the exercise of its inherent powers to impose other terms and conditions as part of any sentence, issue and enforce orders and act to protect the integrity and dignity of the court. 
(2)  The following violations, as set forth by this Code, as may be amended, shall upon conviction be punishable by imprisonment for a period of not more than one year, or by a fine not exceeding, at the time of the commission of the offense, the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations, or by both fine and imprisonment, and such other terms and conditions as the court in the exercise of its lawful powers deems appropriate: 
a.  All offenses set forth in the following articles of chapter 38 of the Code: article III, offenses against the person; article IV, offenses against property; article VI, offenses related to governmental operation; article IX, offenses relating to weapons and article VII, offenses concerning public indecency. 
b.  Disorderly conduct as set forth in article V of chapter 38 of the Code. 
c.  The following offenses set forth in article 1 of chapter 58: Speeding more than 24 miles per hour over the posted speed limit, reckless driving, eluding or attempting to elude a police officer, speed contest and compulsory insurance. 
(3)  Each 24-hour period of time that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Unless specifically designated criminal herein, any offense which is punishable by fine only without imprisonment is not criminal and is deemed decriminalized. 
(b)  Any person under 18 years of age convicted of a violation of any provision of this Code shall be, for each offense, fined in a sum not exceeding, at the time of the commission of the offense, the maximum fine established by the state for municipal ordinance violations. The municipal judge has the authority to order a child confined in a juvenile detention facility operated or contracted by the county or the state for failure to comply with a lawful order of the court, including an order to pay a fine. Any confinement of a child for contempt of a court order shall not exceed 48 hours. 
(c)  The city shall be entitled to recover all costs and expenses including reasonable attorney fees incurred in the civil prosecution and/or litigation of any person found to have violated any section of this Code or any rule or regulation promulgated under this Code. 
(d)  If a person is charged with both a violation that is subject to a jury trial and one which is not and such violations arise out of the same act or transaction, such individual may have a trial by jury on all charges. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-7; Ord. No. 08-08, § 1, 1-6-2009; Ord. No. 11-11, § 1, 11-1-2011; Ord. No. 13-10, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 16-03, § 1, 4-5-2016; Ord. No. 18-18, § 2, 4-16-2019) 
Charter reference- Penalty for violation of ordinances, § 4.11. 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of ordinance, C.R.S. § 31-16-101. 
Sec. 1-16. - Fees, rates and charges. 
    The city council shall, by resolution, establish the fees for municipal goods, amenities and services as provided for by the applicable provisions of this Code. The fees shall be based upon the city manager's analysis and recommendations. Such fees will be established with the objective of, and related to, defraying the city's costs of providing the particular goods, amenities or services and shall be in consideration of, and related to, the permissible uses of the fee revenues. Such resolutions establishing fees shall include the reasonable relationship between the fees charged and the costs of providing the services, goods and amenities for which such fees are charged. 
(Code 1985, § 1-1-10) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-1-2-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City council, art. 2; council procedure, art. 3 

Sec. 2-19. - Wards. 
(a)  The city is divided into three wards for the purpose of electing city councilmembers. For the purpose of this article, reference to streets, avenues and boulevards shall be, unless specifically noted otherwise, to the centerline of such streets, avenues and boulevards, and when reference is made to the limits, it shall be to the boundary line of the established corporate limits, or subdivision. 
(b)  The boundaries of the wards in accordance with the map on file with the city clerk shall be as follows: 
(1)  Ward 1. Beginning at the intersection of 88th Avenue and Federal Boulevard and proceeding north to the intersection of 92nd Avenue and Federal Boulevard; thence east to the intersection of 92nd Avenue and Tejon Street; thence south to 90th Avenue; thence east to the intersection of 90th Avenue and Pecos Street; thence south to the northwest corner of the Pecos/Huron Subdivision; thence east to Huron Street; thence south to 84th Avenue; thence west and north along the corporate city limits to the intersection of 88th Avenue and Federal Boulevard. 
(2)  Ward 2. Beginning at the intersection of 92nd Avenue and Federal Boulevard and proceeding east to the intersection of 92nd Avenue and Tejon Street; thence south to 90th Avenue; thence east to the intersection of 90th Avenue and Pecos Street; thence north to the corporate city limits; thence west following the corporate city limits to Warbler Street; thence west to Cascade Drive; thence north to Canary Street, including all residences on the east and west sides of Canary Street; thence west to Alder Street to the corporate city limits, including all residences on the north and south sides of Alder Street. 
(3)  Ward 3. Beginning at Hawk Street, including all residences on the north and south sides, and proceeding east to Gull Street, including all residences on the east and west sides, thence south to Cascade Drive, thence east to the intersection of Warbler Street and Zuni Street, thence north following the corporate city limits to 104th Avenue, thence west to the intersection of 104th Avenue and Federal Boulevard following the corporate city limits, thence south on Federal Boulevard along the corporate city limits to Hawk Street. 
(Code 1985, § 2-1-2) 
Charter reference- Wards, § 5.4. 
Sec. 2-20. - Compensation of mayor, mayor pro tem and city councilmembers. 
(a)  The mayor of the city shall receive $1,000.00 per month, plus those expenses, which are incurred in the necessary course of city business and consistent with the city policy on expenses. 
(b)  The mayor pro tem shall receive $850.00 per month, plus those expenses which are incurred in the necessary course of city business and consistent with the city policy on expenses. 
(c)  Every other member of the city council shall receive $750.00 per month per month, plus those expenses which are incurred in the necessary course of city business and consistent with the city policy on expenses. 
(d)  Commencing January 1, 2018, and on the first day of every year thereafter, the compensation for the mayor, mayor pro tem and other members of council shall be adjusted, to match the current percentage adjustment appropriated by city council for employee compensation. 
(Code 1985, §§ 2-1-7, 2-2-7; Ord. No. 13-18, § 1, 10-1-2013; Ord. No. 17-12, § 1, 9-5-2017) 
Charter reference- Compensation § 2.6. 
Sec. 2-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-14, § 1, adopted September 4, 2018, repealed § 2-21, which pertained to expulsion from city council; vacancies in other offices and derived from the Code of 1985, § 2-2-3; Ord. No. 14-04, adopted May 20, 2014 and Ord. No. 17-09, adopted August 1, 2017. 
Sec. 2-22. - Personnel code. 
    The city council shall adopt a personnel code by resolution and may amend it from time to time. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-5.5) 
Charter reference- Duties of the city manager, § 7.3B. 
Sec. 2-23. - Retirement plan. 
    The mayor and city councilmembers shall be immediately vested upon enrollment and eligible for matching funds in accordance with the plan's requirements. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-8; Ord. No. 04-01, § 1, 2-17-2004) 
Sec. 2-24. - Reimbursement of recall expenses. 
(a)  In accordance with C.R.S. § 31-4-504.5, an incumbent member of city council, including the mayor, who prevails in a recall attempt shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in such recall and authorized by state statute, which expenses include, or do not include, as the case may be, the following: 
(1)  Authorized expenses shall include, but are not limited to, moneys spent in challenging the sufficiency of the recall petition and in presenting to the voters the official position of the incumbent, to include campaign literature and advertising and the maintaining of a campaign headquarters. 
(2)  Unauthorized expenses shall include, but are not limited to, moneys spent on challenges and court actions not pertaining to the sufficiency of the recall petition; personal expenses for meals, lodging, and mileage for the incumbent; costs of maintaining a campaign staff, expenses incurred by a campaign committee which has solicited contributions; reimbursement of any kind for employees in the incumbent's office; and all expenses incurred prior to the filing of the recall petition. 
(b)  Reimbursement of recall expenses are subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  The incumbent shall file a complete and detailed request for reimbursement with city council not later than 60 days after the day of the unsuccessful recall election of the incumbent, or a hearing officer's determination that the recall petitions are not sufficient based upon the conduct of the circulators, whichever is later. 
(2)  The city council shall by ordinance, approve the request for reimbursement of such authorized expenses as specified in this section and in compliance with state statutes. 
(3)  Payment of reimbursement of such expenses shall be made to the incumbent within 45 days of the receipt of request for reimbursement by the council. 
(4)  An incumbent charged or convicted of violating C.R.S. § 18-8-301 et seq., regarding bribery and corrupt influences and/or C.R.S. § 18-8-401 et seq., regarding abuse of public office allegedly occurring during the term of office as councilmember or mayor, which is the subject of the recall, shall not be eligible for reimbursement. Notwithstanding the foregoing, an incumbent charged with a violation of the said offenses may, upon acquittal or dismissal of such allegations, be eligible for reimbursement and application for such reimbursement must be made within 30 days of the date of the incumbent's acquittal or dismissal of such charges. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-10) 
Charter reference- Recall, § 6.4. 
State Law reference- Reimbursement of cost of recall election, C.R.S. §§ 1-12-120, 31-4-504.5. 
Sec. 2-25. - Council conduct with staff. 
(a)  Council has the authority to direct the city manager with respect to the manager's duties, concerning the administration and operation of the city, including its codes, ordinances, resolutions, policies, procedures and directives. Individual councilors' directives however, shall be limited to requests for documents and information and subject to the following; 
(1)  Requests for public records and criminal justice records shall be made in writing to the appropriate custodian with a copy provided to the city manager. Replies to such requests shall be in accordance with the applicable law except that councilors shall not be assessed any fees. However if the custodian, with the city manager's concurrence determines that the research and retrieval time for a request exceeds 60 minutes of staff time the custodian shall notify the councilor that for staff to proceed the councilor must submit a council work request form executed by the requestor and three other councilors or in the alternative the councilor may request that the matter be placed upon the agenda for the consideration of council at an upcoming regular meeting. The custodian shall then proceed to fulfill the request only if so directed by a vote of the majority of the council present. 
(2)  Requests for information outside the scope of public or criminal justice records shall be made to the city manager. If in the city manager's determination more than 60 minutes of staff time per calendar week shall be required to obtain the required information the request will not be processed unless a councilor submits the city manager a council work request form executed by the requestor and three other councilors or in the alternative a councilor may request that the matter be placed upon the agenda for the consideration of council at an upcoming regular meeting. The city manager shall then proceed to direct staff to fulfill the request only if so directed by a vote of the majority of the council present. For the purposes of this sub-section each councilor shall be allotted 60 minutes of staff time per calendar week, however such time is not accruable nor may it be transferred or assigned to another councilor. 
(b)  Council members may discuss all matters relating to city operations and administrative services with employees but should first advise the city manager of such discussions. Council members are prohibited from giving a direct order to any city employee, or soliciting political support from any employee for any council member's campaign for any elected or appointed office. 
(c)  In interacting with staff, council members shall treat all staff as professionals, not disrupt staff in the performance of their duties, not publicly criticize individual staff members and not attend staff meetings unless invited by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 14-04, § 2, 5-20-2014; Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 2-26. - Executive session records. 
    All executive session records which are required to be kept in accordance with the Open Meetings Law, C.R.S. § 24-6-402, as amended, shall be destroyed on or after the 91st day following the executive session in which the record was made. 
(Code 1985, § 2-2-12) 
Charter reference- Executive sessions, § 3.4. 
State Law reference- Meetings open to the public, C.R.S. § 24-6-402. 
Sec. 2-27. - Council elections. 
(a)  Whenever both council seats within a ward become open at an election, all candidates must on their nominating petition declare their candidacy for either the four-year or the two-year term. 
(b)  In the event there are no candidates for one or both of the seats, such seat shall be declared vacant and filled as a "vacancy" in accordance with section 2.7 of the charter. 
(Ord. No. 17-05, § 1, 6-27-2017) 
Secs. 2-28-2-55. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-84. - Creation; composition. 
    The city shall have a police department which shall consist of one chief of police and as many officers as may, from time to time, be deemed necessary for the safety and good order of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-1) 
Sec. 2-85. - Appointment; removal; powers and duties of the chief of police. 
(a)  Appointment; removal. The chief of the police department shall be appointed and/or removed by the city manager. 
(b)  Powers and duties of the chief of police. The powers and duties of the chief of police shall be as follows: 
(1)  See that the ordinances of the city are duly enforced and the rules and regulations of the police department obeyed, and perform such duties as may be required by the council. 
(2)  Direct the operations of the police department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
(3)  Render such accounts of the police department, his duties and receipts as may be required, and keep the records of his office. 
(4)  Before entering upon the duties of such office, the chief of police shall take and subscribe an oath that he will support the constitution and laws of the state, Constitution of the United States and ordinances of the city, and that he will faithfully perform the duties of his office. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-3) 
Sec. 2-86. - Oath. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, each police officer shall take and subscribe an oath that he will support the constitution and laws of the state, the Constitution of the United States and the ordinances of the city, and that he will faithfully perform the duties of his office. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-5) 
State Law reference- Oath of office and bonds, C.R.S. § 31-4-401. 
Sec. 2-87. - Reserve police; appointment; powers. 
    There is hereby created a police reserve for the city, consisting of those persons selected as reserve police by the police chief. Said reserve police officers shall serve without compensation and at such times and places as may be designated by the chief or a command officer acting on behalf of the chief. Said reserve police officers shall have and possess all of the powers and privileges of regular police officers during the times when they are on duty and shall, under normal circumstances, be assigned to duty only when a regular police officer is also on duty. 
(Code 1985, § 2-4-10) 
Secs. 2-88-2-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-110. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a fire department for the city which shall consist of a chief, and as many officers and members, both paid and volunteer, as may be deemed necessary. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-1) 
Sec. 2-111. - Appointment; removal; powers and duties of the chief of the fire department. 
(a)  Appointment; removal. The chief of the fire department shall be appointed and/or removed by the city manager. 
(b)  Powers and duties of the chief of the fire department. The powers and duties of the chief of the fire department shall be as follows: 
(1)  Adopt suitable rules and regulations for the department such as are not in conflict with state or federal laws. 
(2)  Appoint officers and members of the fire department on the basis of qualifications for the position as determined by suitable testing and evaluation methods, and applicable provisions of city personnel policies. 
(3)  Be accountable for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the department. 
(4)  Conduct suitable drills or instruction in the operation and handling of equipment, first aid and rescue work, salvage, water supplies and all other matters generally considered essential to fire protection and safety of life and property. 
(5)  Investigate or cause to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all fire. 
(6)  Keep complete records of all fires, inspections, apparatus and equipment, personnel and other information about the department. 
(7)  Discipline, demote, dismiss, or expel any officer or member of the department for neglect or refusal to perform departmental duties, subject to review of such action as provided in the personnel policies of the city. 
(8)  Inspect or cause to be inspected buildings and premises and serve or cause to be served written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any and all fire hazards that may be found. For the purpose of conducting such inspection, the chief or his appointee is hereby empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises within the city at any reasonable hour upon prior notice to the person in charge of said property without a search warrant or other document. Any person served with a notice to abate any fire hazard shall comply therewith and promptly notify the fire chief of such compliance. It shall be unlawful to fail to comply with any notice to abate a fire hazard within the time set forth in said notice. 
(9)  Enforce or cause to be enforced all ordinances, laws and regulations of the city and state insofar as they pertain to fire and safety. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-3) 
Sec. 2-112. - Appointment and supervision of firefighters. 
(a)  Firefighters shall be appointed by the fire chief at such times as may be necessary to fill the paid and volunteer personnel complement of such department as established by the city council. 
(b)  All firefighters shall be subject to supervision by and shall be accountable to the fire chief. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-4) 
Sec. 2-113. - Entry upon adjacent property. 
    Any firefighter acting under direction of the chief or other authorized personnel may enter upon any premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or property that is on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire. It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, resist or obstruct any firefighter in the performance of any duty described in this section. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-6; Ord. No. 04-08, § 1, 7-20-2004) 
Sec. 2-114. - Equipment. 
    The department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and properly protect life and property from fire. All equipment of the department shall be safely and conveniently housed. No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purposes, nor shall any persons willfully take away or conceal any article used in any way by the department. No person shall enter any place where fire apparatus is housed or handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the department unless accompanied by, or having special permission of, an officer or authorized member of the department. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-7) 
Sec. 2-115. - Vehicles of firefighters. 
    All volunteer firefighters answering alarms in their own vehicles shall obey all state and municipal statutes and ordinances relating to the operation of such vehicles notwithstanding the emergency nature of their duties. No person shall drive any vehicle over fire hoses except upon specific orders from the chief or other officer in charge where the hoses are used. 
(Code 1985, § 2-5-10) 
Secs. 2-116-2-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMPLOYEE COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-150. - Employee compensation. 
    At least annually the city council shall establish by resolution a total compensation plan for all employees. The resolution shall, at a minimum, establish salary compensation and benefits. 
(Code 1985, § 2-10-1) 
Sec. 2-151. - Compensation recommendation. 
    Prior to submitting a recommendation to the city council, the city manager will conduct a compensation survey of public and private employers in the North Metropolitan Area. The survey shall include appropriate portions of the Colorado Municipal League's Annual Compensation Report. The recommendation of the city manager shall include wages and benefits. 
(Code 1985, § 2-10-2) 
Secs. 2-152-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Deferred compensation plans, C.R.S. § 24-52-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-171. - Nonqualified deferred compensation plan adoption. 
    There is hereby established a nonqualified deferred compensation plan to provide retirement income and other deferred benefits to eligible employees in accordance with section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended. The plan is available from multiple providers and such documents are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set out in this codification. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-1) 
Sec. 2-172. - Investment and account values of nonqualified deferred compensation plan. 
    All assets of the nonqualified deferred compensation plan, including all participant investments and all property, rights and income attributable thereto, shall be held in trust, with the city serving as trustee for the exclusive benefit of the plan participants and their beneficiaries. Accordingly, plan assets cannot be diverted for any purpose other than the further benefit of plan participants and their beneficiaries. Additionally, plan assets shall not be subject to any claim of the city's general creditors. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-2) 
Sec. 2-173. - Nonqualified deferred compensation plan amendment. 
    The terms and conditions of the nonqualified deferred compensation plan may be amended by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-3) 
Sec. 2-174. - Money purchase retirement plan adoption. 
    A money purchase retirement plan to provide retirement income and other deferred benefits to eligible employees may be adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-4) 
Sec. 2-175. - Money purchase retirement plan amendment. 
    The terms and conditions of the money purchase retirement plan may be amended by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-5) 
Sec. 2-176. - Retirement benefits plan committee. 
(a)  There is hereby created a retirement benefits committee (committee) which shall serve both the nonqualified deferred compensation plan and the money purchase pension plan. Committee members shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the city manager. Membership shall be composed of the following: 
(1)  One department head; and 
(2)  Four employees who are retirement benefit plan participants. 
The committee shall appoint a chairperson and secretary. The committee shall maintain a record of its actions. 
(b)  The committee shall have the authority to make discretionary decisions affecting the rights and benefits of plan participants as required in administration of the plan. 
(Code 1985, § 2-12-6) 
Secs. 2-177-2-205. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-206. - Plan adoption. 
    That certain document, one copy of which shall be maintained on file in the office of the clerk, designated as "The Fire and Police Money Purchase Pension Plan and Trust Agreement of the City of Federal Heights," which is dated September 1991, is hereby adopted by reference as the paid personnel fire and police pension plan for the city, as if fully set out in this codification.

Sec. 2-207. - Plan amendments.

(Code 1985, § 2-13-2)

ARTICLE V. - DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Unclaimed property, application of local law, C.R.S. § 38-13-134. 

Sec. 2-238. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 2-14-1) 
Sec. 2-239. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Intangible property means: 
(1)  Moneys, checks, drafts, deposits, interest, dividend, and income; 
(2)  Credit balances, customer overpayments, gift certificates, refunds, credit memos, and unidentified remittances; 
(3)  Stocks and other intangible ownership interest in business association; 
(4)  Security deposits, unpaid wages, and unused airline tickets; 
(5)  Amounts distributable from a trust or custodial fund established under a plan to provide health, welfare, pension, vacation, severance, retirement, death, stock purchase, profit sharing, employee savings, supplemental unemployment insurance, or similar benefits. 
    Ownership means a person or entity, including a corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity other than the city, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of same, which owns unclaimed property held by the city. 
    Unclaimed property means any tangible or intangible property, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, that is held by or under the control of the city and which has not been claimed by its owner for a period of more than one year after it became payable or distributable. Unclaimed property shall not include abandoned motor vehicles which are the subject of chapter 30, article V of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 2-14-2) 
Sec. 2-240. - Procedure of disposition of property. 
(a)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of $100.00 or more, the city manager shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address, if any, of any owner of unclaimed property. The last known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the department or agency holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property, and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city manager with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(b)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than $100.00 or having no last known address of the owner, the city manager shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall include a description of the property, the owner of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city manager with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the publication of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(c)  If the city manager receives no written claim within the above 60-day claim period, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(d)  If the city manager receives a written claim within the 60-day claim period, the city manager shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within 90 days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part. The city manager may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property. 
(e)  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the city manager may, in the city manager's sole discretion, resolve said claims, or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the register of the district court in an inter-pleader action. 
(f)  In the event that all claims filed are denied, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(g)  Unclaimed property with a value of less than $100.00 may be disposed of as deemed appropriate by the city manager. 
(Code 1985, § 2-14-3) 
Sec. 2-241. - Surplus property. 
    Personal property owned by the city which is declared by the city council to be surplus shall be disposed of by one of the following means, as directed by the city council, upon determining such surplus: 
(1)  Public auction conducted by either the city, or in conjunction with other entities. 
(2)  Sealed bid after notification and advertisement of request for bids. 
(3)  Negotiated sale to another governmental entity. 
(4)  Donation to a bona fide, nondenominational charity. 
(5)  Destruction. 
(Code 1985, § 2-14-5) 
Sec. 2-242. - City manager to establish and administer procedures. 
    The city manager is authorized to establish and administer procedures for the administration and disposition of unclaimed and/or surplus property consistent with this article, including compliance requirements for other city officers and employees in the identification and disposition of such property. 
Secs. 2-243-2-264. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CODE OF ETHICS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, adopted October 18, 2106, repealed the former article VI, §§ 2-265-2-279, and enacted a new article VI as set out herein. The former article VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1985, §§ 2-15-1-2-15-15; Ord. No. 04-07, adopted July 6, 2004 and Ord. No. 06-05, adopted October 3, 2006. 

Sec. 2-265. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Confidential information shall mean any information that is not available to the general public or is deemed confidential in accordance with local, state or federal law, and which is obtained by reason of a councilor's official position or under circumstances by which a reasonable person could anticipate that such information not be disclosed. Confidential information shall also include matters discussed in executive sessions; however, information otherwise available to the general public does not become "confidential" merely because it was discussed in executive session. 
    Financial interest shall mean a substantial interest held by a councilor that is: 
(1)  An ownership of securities of a corporation, or of any beneficial interest in a partnership or firm, the aggregate amount of which securities or interest owned by the councilor and the councilor's family is five percent or more of any class of securities of such corporation or five percent or greater ownership in such partnership or firm; 
(2)  A creditor interest in an insolvent business; 
(3)  An employment or a prospective employment for which negotiations have begun, or a contractual relationship that directly relates to a matter under consideration; 
(4)  An ownership interest in real or personal property; 
(5)  A loan or any other debtor interest; or 
(6)  A directorship or officer holder in a business. 
    Personal interest shall mean a direct or indirect interest, not shared by the general public, having value peculiar to a particular councilor, whether or not the value is related to monetary, financial, commercial, or property matters, which value may accrue to such councilor or result in such councilor's deriving or potentially deriving a personal benefit as a result of the approval or denial of any ordinance, resolution, order or other official action, or the performance or nonperformance thereof, by a public servant. Personal interest does not include any matter in which a similar benefit is conferred to all persons or property similarly situated to that of the councilor. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 10-18-16) 
Sec. 2-266. - Release of confidential information prohibited. 
    Councilors shall not use any confidential information in furtherance of any personal or financial interest, or the personal or financial interest of any other person, unless such information is obtainable by the public at large, nor shall any councilor disclose to third parties any confidential information, unless authorized to do so by a vote of two-thirds or more of the entire council. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 10-18-16) 
Sec. 2-267. - Gift ban. 
    No councilor, in his or her official capacity may solicit or accept from any one donor a present or future gift, favor, loan, service, or thing of value, whose cumulative value is more than $100.00 per annum, or under circumstances that would lead a reasonably prudent person to believe that such gift, favor, loan, service or thing of value was made or given primarily for the purpose of influencing or attempting to influence such official or employee in connection with an official act, or as a reward of official action he or she has previously taken. This prohibition shall not apply to: 
(1)  Admissions to conferences, seminars, training sessions, cultural events, award ceremonies, or conventions related to or in connection with city business. 
(2)  Acceptance of food and refreshment at conferences, seminars, training sessions, cultural events, award ceremonies, conventions, luncheons or dinner meetings, and other events related to or in connection with city business. 
(3)  Campaign contributions reported under the Fair Campaign Practices Act, C.R.S. § 1-45-101 et seq. as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 10-18-16) 
Secs. 2-268-2-306. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AMBULANCE ENTERPRISE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- enterprises, § 10.15. 
State Law reference- Local government enterprises, Colo. Const. art. X, § 20; emergency medical and trauma services, C.R.S. § 25-3.5-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-307. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ambulance enterprise means that ambulance activity business wholly owned by the city which receives under ten percent of its annual revenues in grants from all state and local governments combined and which is authorized to issue its own revenue bonds pursuant to this article or any other applicable law. It shall include, by illustration, emergency medical services and ambulance services and activities of the city. 
    Grant means the cash payment of public funds made by the state directly to a municipal activity enterprise of a local governmental entity or district, including the city, which cash payment is not required to be repaid. A grant does not include public funds paid or advanced by the state to a municipal activity enterprise of local governmental entity or district, including the city, in exchange for an agreement by a municipal activity enterprise to provide service including the provision of emergency medical rescue or ambulance services or activities. A grant does not include refunds made in the current or next fiscal years, gifts, any payments directly or indirectly from federal funds or earnings on federal funds, collections from another government, pension contributions by employees and pension fund earnings, reserve transfers or expenditures, damage awards or property sales. A grant does not include money repaid to an enterprise in consideration for any loan made by the enterprise to the state or any local government of the state. A grant does not include money realized by an enterprise from the federal government, whether or not the state or any state local government of the state acts as a conduit for such money. 
(Code 1985, § 2-16-1) 
Sec. 2-308. - Establishment and designation of ambulance enterprise. 
(a)  Effective as of January 1, 1993, there is hereby recognized, established and designated the city ambulance enterprise (the enterprise). The enterprise shall consist of the business represented by all of the city's ambulance emergency rescue and emergency medical equipment, facilities and properties, now owned or hereafter acquired, whether situated within or without the city boundaries, including all present or future possessions, enlargements, betterments, replacements or additions thereof or thereto. The enterprise shall have all of the authority, powers, rights, obligations and duties as may be provided or permitted by the laws of the state, and the state constitution, and as may be further prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the city. 
(b)  The enterprise shall continue to be a wholly owned business of the city and shall not be combined with any municipal activity enterprise owned by another district. The enterprise may continue to conduct the activities and provide the services as provided for in the ordinances of the city and the resolutions or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. This section shall not limit the authority of the enterprise to contract with any person or entity, including other districts or enterprises. 
(Code 1985, § 2-16-2) 
Sec. 2-309. - Applicability of all city powers, codes, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, nothing herein either explicitly or by implication or interpretation shall amend, change, preclude or prohibit the existing or continuing applicability and/or the exercise of the following powers, rights, activities, or administration related to ambulance activities by the city, including by illustration only: Ownership of vehicles, equipment and facilities; establishment of rates and fees; maintenance of the vehicles, equipment, buildings and facilities; purchasing and construction activities in compliance with city codes and policies; holding of ownership and title to equipment, vehicles, and assets; enforcement of codes, ordinances, rules and regulations; and all other municipal powers, controls, resolutions, rules and regulations of any nature whatsoever related to ambulance activities and services. 
(Code 1985, § 2-16-3) 
Sec. 2-310. - Governing body. 
(a)  The governing body of the enterprise (the governing body) shall be the city council, and it shall be subject to all of the applicable ordinances, resolutions, codes, laws, rules and regulations pertaining to the city council. The governing body may conduct its affairs in the same manner and subject to the same laws which apply to the city council for the same or similar matters. 
(b)  The governing body of the enterprise may exercise the city's legal authority relating to ambulance activities, but no enterprise may levy a tax which is subject to section 20(4) of article X of the state constitution. 
(c)  The governing body of the enterprise may also be referred to as the "ambulance board." 
(Code 1985, § 2-16-4) 
Sec. 2-311. - Maintenance of enterprise status. 
    The enterprise shall at all times and in all ways conduct its affairs so as to continue to qualify as an enterprise as defined in article X, section 20 of the state constitution. Specifically, but not by way of limitation, the enterprise is not authorized to and shall not receive ten percent or more of its annual revenue in grants from all state and local governments combined. 
(Code 1985, § 2-16-5) 
Secs. 2-312-2-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HONORING DECEASED ELECTED OFFICIALS, POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL, EMPLOYEES AND DIGNITARIES 

Sec. 2-341. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city will honor current and former elected officials upon their death, police and fire personnel killed in the line of duty, employees who die while in service to the city and dignitaries as chosen by city council. 
(b)  It is the city's intention to honor, subject to its resources, the wishes of the family of the deceased in commemorating such person's death. 
(Code 1985, § 2-17-1) 
Sec. 2-342. - Deceased current and former mayor and councilmembers. 
(a)  City flags will be flown at half mast as follows: 
(1)  Deceased mayor: 30 days at half mast; 
(2)  Deceased councilmember: 15 days at half mast. 
(b)  The family of a deceased mayor or councilmember will be offered police and/or fire personnel for use as pall bearers during funeral services. Police and/or fire vehicles will also be offered for use during services. A city flag may be presented to a designated family member during locally held services. For other services, a city flag may be sent to the family. 
(c)  Flowers shall be sent to a location chosen by the family of the deceased. Families of the deceased may request that in lieu of flowers a contribution be made to a charity of their choice. 
(d)  A resolution shall be presented to the city council expressing the city's gratitude for service and sympathy to the family. 
(Code 1985, § 2-17-2) 
Sec. 2-343. - Police and fire personnel killed in the line of duty. 
(a)  City flags will be flown at half mast for 30 days in honor of police and fire personnel killed in the line of duty. 
(b)  The family will be offered police or fire personnel accordingly for use as pallbearers and as part of the services. Police and fire vehicles will also be offered for use during services. A city flag may be presented to a designated family member during locally held services. For other services a city flag may be sent to the family. The city will present a uniform to the families who choose to bury deceased police or fire personnel in uniform. 
(c)  In the case of the death of police or fire personnel, all other department personnel will shroud their badges for 30 days. 
(d)  The deceased's badge will be retired by the department and presented to the family. 
(e)  Flowers shall be sent to a location chosen by the family of the deceased. Families of the deceased may request that in lieu of flowers a contribution be made to a charity of their choice. 
(Code 1985, § 2-17-3) 
Sec. 2-344. - Deceased employees. 
(a)  City flags will be flown at half mast for five days upon the death of an employee. 
(b)  The family of the deceased will be offered police and/or fire personnel for use as pallbearers during funeral services. Police and fire vehicles will also be offered for use during services. 
(c)  Flowers shall be sent to a location chosen by the family of the deceased. Families of the deceased may request that in lieu of flowers a contribution be made to a charity of their choice. 
(Code 1985, § 2-17-4) 
Sec. 2-345. - Other dignitaries. 
    Any member of the city council may choose to request that special recognition be given upon the death of a dignitary or special contributor to the city not identified above, subject to approval by the council. 
(Code 1985, § 2-17-5) 
Secs. 2-346-2-363. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - SMOKING[8] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Authority to regulate smoking, C.R.S. § 25-14-105. 

Sec. 2-385. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Smoke or smoking means the lighting or burning of any cigarette, cigar or pipe, regardless of the composition of the burning material. 
(Code 1985, § 2-18-1) 
Sec. 2-386. - Smoking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke: 
(1)  In any building or indoor facility owned or operated by the city except in designated smoking areas as established by resolution of city council. 
(2)  In any vehicle owned by the city. 
(3)  Within 50 feet of the front entrance to city hall.

ARTICLE X. - ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING PROCEDURES 

Sec. 2-416. - Legislative intent. 
(a)  The purpose of these rules of procedure is to provide a uniform procedure for conducting administrative-type hearings held by city officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions and city council and to afford persons due process of law. The city and/or its agencies may supplement the provisions of this article by adopting additional rules of procedure not inconsistent with this article. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided, this article applies whenever an administrative hearing is required or is to be conducted for municipal matters. Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to grant any person the right to appeal to any agency or to have a hearing before it unless a specific provision of the city code, rule, regulation or procedure, or state or federal constitution or law grants such a right. This article does not apply to any personnel matters involving city employees subject to the city's personnel policies and procedures. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-1) 
Sec. 2-417. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agency means the city council and any official, officer, employee or department, or other entity of the city, including boards and commissions, but excluding the municipal court. 
    Decision-maker means the city council or any other city department, employee, board, commission, officer, official or appointed hearing officer authorized to conduct a hearing. 
    Interested person means any person described as "interested" by law or any person having a legally protected interest that is subject to potential injury due to a proposed or final agency action, or any person having a right of appeal from a final agency action, or any person having a right of appeal from proposed final agency action by virtue of a specific provision of the city code, ordinance, rule or regulation, or state or federal constitution or law. The term "interested person" may include a city agency or a business, corporation, partnership, charitable or religious organization, profit or non-profit entity, or any other lawful organization or entity. 
    Law means charter provision, city ordinance, rule, regulation or code or state or federal constitution, statute or regulation, or any applicable ruling, judgment or decision of a court of law. 
    Party to a hearing means any interested person who requests a hearing, appears at a hearing, or submits a written entry of appearance at or before a hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-2) 
Sec. 2-418. - Notice. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 2-419, no agency may take final action subject to this article unless, before taking such proposed action, the agency has given notice to all known interested persons of: 
(1)  The proposed agency action; 
(2)  The legal authority for such action; 
(3)  The opportunity for any interested person to submit written information and documents with respect to the proposed action; and 
(4)  The date of a hearing if required by law; or 
(5)  The opportunity for any interested person to request a hearing on such action by filing a written request therefor that is received by the agency not more than 14 calendar days after the date the notice is deposited in the mail, hand delivered, posted, or published. 
(b)  Notice shall be given at least 14 calendar days before the date of the hearing. If the notice is mailed, it is deemed given when mailed to the address shown on the license, permit, or application at issue or in the records of the county clerk or tax assessor or any other official custodian of public records of property ownership for any specific property in question. For purposes of this subsection, the term "public records" means as defined in applicable state statutes. 
(c)  If an interested person requests a hearing as prescribed herein, the agency shall give notice by hand delivery, posting, mail or newspaper or otherwise as required by law, at least 14 calendar days before the hearing of the date, time, place, and nature of the hearing to all known interested persons. Unless otherwise provided by law, such notice shall be given to the person requesting the hearing upon depositing the notice in the mail or hand delivering the notice at least 14 calendar days before the date of the hearing to the last address furnished to the agency by the person requesting the hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-3) 
Sec. 2-419. - Emergency exceptions. 
(a)  To the extent permitted by law, the notice and hearing requirements set forth herein do not apply when the agency determines that the public health, safety, or welfare requires emergency action by the agency. If the agency takes emergency action, it shall provide timely notice of the action and shall thereafter provide notice as required by section 2-418, and an opportunity for a post-emergency action hearing of interested persons by the means prescribed in section 2-418. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit an agency from ordering interim relief to preserve the status quo pending a hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-4) 
Sec. 2-420. - Hearings and determinations. 
(a)  The agency may, if authorized by law, charge a fee for a hearing. 
(b)  The hearing shall be conducted by the agency, or any employee, hearing officer, or subcommittee of the agency, as authorized by the applicable provision of this Code, rules, regulations or other applicable law. While presiding at a hearing, the agency or hearing officer shall determine whether the proposed agency action conforms with the requirements and standards, as set forth in the applicable law. 
(c)  The decision-maker has, by illustration and not limitation, authority to administer oaths and affirmations; sign and issue subpoenas; rule upon offers of proof; compel testimony; receive evidence; decide discovery issues such as the production of documents and materials for inspection, copying, or photographing; regulate the course of the hearing; set the time and place for continued hearings; fix the time of filing of documents; direct the parties to exchange witness and exhibit lists prior to the hearing; confer with the parties to consider simplification of issues, admissions of facts, documents and witnesses to avoid redundant or repetitive proof; issue orders to control the subsequent course of the proceeding; decide motions; and control the decorum and conduct of the proceedings, including the reprimanding and exclusion from the hearing of any person engaging in improper conduct. 
(d)  Any interested person may at his expense be represented by legal counsel. 
(e)  All testimony shall be taken under oath or by affirmation. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the orders of the decision-maker, including the failure to obey any subpoena issued pursuant to this article. 
(g)  The proceedings of the hearing shall be recorded by tape recording, stenographic, or other verbatim reproduction, and copies of transcriptions of the proceedings shall be made available upon payment of the costs therefor by the party requesting same. 
(h)  Unless otherwise provided by law, the proponent of an order has the burden of proof, by a preponderance of the evidence. Every party to the proceeding has the right to present such party's case or defense by oral and documentary evidence; to submit opening and closing statements; present rebuttal evidence; and to conduct cross examination of witnesses and exhibits. The decision-maker may receive all or part of the evidence in written form if the interests of the parties will not be substantially prejudiced and if such action will expedite the hearing. The decision-maker shall not be bound by the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure or the formal rules of evidence; may exclude incompetent and unduly repetitious evidence; and may receive documentary evidence in the form of a copy or excerpt if the copy is authenticated. The decision-maker shall use its experience, technical competence, and specialized knowledge in evaluating the evidence presented. Parties to the hearing may make objections to evidentiary offers, which objections shall be included in the record. 
(i)  The decision-maker may take the matter under advisement and issue a written decision within a reasonable length of time (not to exceed 30 days), or may issue a decision at the hearing. A written decision shall be issued with findings of fact, setting forth the grounds of the decision, based on the evidence presented at the hearing. The decision shall be served on each party to the hearing by personal service or by mailing by regular mail to the party's last known address. The decision shall be effective as to such party on the date mailed or on such other date as stated in the decision. 
(j)  Unless otherwise provided by law, such decision is final, subject only to judicial review pursuant to Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 106(a)(4). No defense or objection may be presented for judicial review unless it is first presented to the decision-maker during the course of the hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-5) 
Sec. 2-421. - Ex parte contacts. 
    No ex parte communication outside the hearing shall be considered by the decision-maker unless it is fully disclosed on the record and the other party is given the opportunity to respond. 
(Code 1985, § 2-19-6) 
Secs. 2-422-2-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - EMPLOYEE PROTECTION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- State whistleblower act, C.R.S. § 24-50.5-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Disciplinary action means any form of discipline or penalty, including, but not limited to, dismissal, demotion, transfer, reassignment, suspension, corrective action, reprimand, admonishment, unsatisfactory or below standard performance evaluation, reduction in force, or withholding of work, or threat of any such discipline or penalty. 
    Disclosure of information means providing written evidence to any person, regarding any action, policy, regulation, practice or procedure, including, but not limited to, the waste of public funds, abuse of authority, or mismanagement of city matters or departments. 
    Employee means any person employed by the city. 
    Supervisor means any department head, division head or other person who supervises or is responsible for the work of one or more employees. 
(Code 1985, § 2-20-1) 
Sec. 2-442. - Retaliation prohibited. 
(a)  No supervisor shall initiate or administer any disciplinary action against an employee on account of the employee's disclosure of information. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  An employee who discloses information that the employee knows to be false or who discloses information with disregard for the truth or falsity thereof; 
(2)  An employee who discloses information which is confidential and/or nondisclosable under any provision of law. 
(b)  Any employee who wishes to disclose information under the protection of this article shall first provide such information to one's supervisor. If the matter remains unresolved, the employee shall provide the information to one's department director, then to the city manager, and finally to the mayor or a city councilmember. 
(Code 1985, § 2-20-2) 
Sec. 2-443. - Employee complaints. 
(a)  If an employee believes he/she has been subject to disciplinary action in violation of section 2-442, such employee may, within 30 days after the imposition of disciplinary action, file a written complaint with the city manager. The city manager shall, upon receipt of a complaint, cause an investigation to be conducted. Additionally, within ten days after receiving the complaint, the city manager shall send the supervisor a copy of the complaint. The supervisor shall have 14 days from the date of the notice being sent to provide the city manager with a written response to the complaint. The city manager shall complete the investigation within 40 days of receipt of the employee's complaint. If the investigation determines there is a reasonable basis for the charges, the city manager shall cause disciplinary action to commence in accordance with the personnel code. 
(b)  If an employee's complaint is directed against the city manager, the employee shall file such complaint with the mayor. The mayor shall then inform city council of the matter and city council shall cause an investigator to be appointed who shall perform the duties set forth herein in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1985, § 2-20-3; Ord. No. 04-08, § 2, 7-20-2004) 
Secs. 2-444-2-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - FINANCE[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference- Budget and finance, art. 10. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-471. - Annual budget; mill levy; appropriations. 
(a)  On or before August 15 of each year, department heads shall prepare and submit to the city manager budget estimates of department expenditures for the ensuing budget year. 
(b)  On or before October 15 of each year, the city manager shall prepare and submit to the city council a proposed budget for the ensuing budget year. 
(c)  Upon submittal of the proposed budget to the city council, there shall be published a notice stating that the proposed budget is open for inspection by the public and that the city council will consider adoption of such budget on a certain date and that any interested elector may file or register any objection thereto at any time prior to adoption. 
(d)  After receipt of the proposed budget, the city council shall convene a special study session to review the budget and revise, alter, increase or decrease the items as it deems necessary. The city council shall adopt the budget at a regular council meeting before certification of the property tax mill levy. 
(e)  On or before December 15 of each year, the city council shall certify to the board of county commissioners the property tax mill levy for the ensuing budget year. 
(f)  Before the end of the fiscal year, the city council shall enact a resolution making appropriations for the ensuing fiscal year. The amounts appropriated shall not exceed the amounts fixed in the adopted budget. 
(g)  Within 30 days of the adoption of the budget, a certified copy of such budget shall be filed in the office of the state division of local government. 
(Code 1985, § 3-1-2) 
Sec. 2-472. - Deposits; investment. 
    The city treasurer shall deposit all of the funds and moneys which come into his possession by virtue of his office as city treasurer, in one or more responsible banks located in the state, which have been designated by resolution of the city council.
