    Every person shall have the right to post a notice on his property that no peddlers or solicitors shall enter such premises. It is unlawful for any person licensed hereunder to fail to comply with such notice. 
(Code 1985, § 12-2-8) 
Sec. 14-112. - Nonassignability. 
    Licenses issued in accordance with this article shall not be assigned or be transferred without the prior written approval of the city. The city shall enforce the requirements of sections 14-106, 14-107 and 14-108 upon the assignee or transferee of licenses. 
(Code 1985, § 12-2-9) 
Sec. 14-113. - Suspension and revocation. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article may be suspended, revoked or not renewed by the city manager in accordance with the grounds set forth in section 14-78 and the procedures set forth in chapter 2, article X. 
(Code 1985, § 12-2-10) 
Sec. 14-114. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to nonprofit corporations, city-based charitable, religious, community, youth or political organizations, or events, newspaper delivery persons, yard or garage sales, route deliveries and merchants with established premises who deliver goods in the regular course of business, such as, by illustration only, food deliveries, state licensed real estate or insurance agents, employees of public utilities or other franchises authorized to do business within the city, persons under the age of 18 years, unless the same are serving as employees, agents, or representatives of any other person, persons with a current business license issued by the city and persons who, without personal contact or occupants of dwellings, businesses or places of employment, distribute handbills. 
(Code 1985, § 12-2-11; Ord. No. 14-10, § 1, 11-17-2014) 
Secs. 14-115-14-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONTRACTORS' REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, adopted August 4, 2015, repealed the former article IV, §§ 14-142-14-152, and enacted a new article IV as set out herein. The former article IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1985, §§ 12-3-1-12-3-13. 
State Law reference- Electricians, C.R.S. § 12-23-101 et seq.; plumbers, C.R.S. § 12-58-101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-142. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building trades contractor means any person permitted to construct residential garages, carports, sheds, decks, internal nonstructural and nonbearing remodeling, commercial nonstructural and nonbearing remodeling only, fences, paving, street cuts, siding, sign installations, slabs for sidewalks and driveways. 
    Contractor means any building trades, electrical, general, mechanical, plumbing or set up contractor as defined in this section. 
    Electrical contractor means any person permitted to perform all electrical work; must supply the city with a copy of the state master electrician's license. 
    General contractor means any person permitted to construct both commercial and residential new buildings; also permitted to do the same type of work as a building trades contractor; also permitted to perform structural remodeling work. 
    Mechanical contractor means any person permitted to perform all mechanical work, sheet metal, heating and air cooling systems. 
    Plumbing contractor means any person permitted to perform all plumbing and mechanical work; also permitted to install fire protection systems, but required to submit a copy of the state master plumber's license. 
    Set-up contractor means any person permitted to set up mobile homes with the exception of electrical work; also permitted to install patio covers, decks and carports on mobile homes only. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-143. - Contractor's registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business in the city as a contractor without having first obtained a registration as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-144. - Application. 
    Application for registration shall be made at the office of the city clerk. Application shall be made on a form furnished by the city clerk, which form shall require inclusion of the type of registration sought, the applicant's name, address and telephone number, business name, address and telephone number, names and addresses of corporate officers, and current registrations and/or licenses for other municipalities in the state. Registration shall not be granted if the application is not deemed complete by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-145. - Registration fees. 
(a)  The annual registration fee required for contractors, with the exception of electrical contractors shall be established by resolution of city council 
(b)  In accordance with state law, electrical contractors shall not be required to pay registration fees. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-146. - Registration contents. 
    Every contractor's registration issued shall be signed by the city clerk. In the event the application for a contractor's registration is denied, the registration fee shall be returned forthwith to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-147. - Nonassignability. 
    No registration issued pursuant to this article shall be assignable or transferable in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-148. - Displaying registration upon request of designated city employees. 
    Contractors must upon request of those employees or agents authorized by the city manager produce their current registration. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Sec. 14-149. - Exemption. 
(a)  No contractor's registration shall be required of any public utility franchised or authorized as such to do business within the city for any construction, maintenance, alteration or repair of facilities used in the production, generation or distribution of the utility product or service. 
(b)  The owner of a single-family dwelling or mobile home, provided that such person is also the occupant of said single-family dwelling or mobile home, may engage in construction, repair or alteration of said dwelling and accessory buildings and improvements without obtaining a registration provided for in this article; provided, however, that such person shall acquire all other necessary permits and conform with applicable ordinances and codes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 8-4-2015) 
Secs. 14-150-14-172. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AMUSEMENT ARCADES 

Sec. 14-173. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement arcade means a place or establishment where an individual, association, partnership or corporation maintains more than ten amusement devices. 
    Amusement center means a place or establishment where an individual, association, partnership or corporation maintains five or more, but less than 11 amusement devices, either as a sole business, or in conjunction with some other business. 
    Amusement devices means any device which upon insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, or payment of a consideration directly therein, may be used by the public as a game, entertainment, amusement, a test of skill, either mental or physical, whether or not registering a score, and shall include, but not be limited to, foosball machines, electronic games, coin-operated movies, pinball machines of every kind and description, but shall not include pool, billiards, snooker or other like games which are subject to the licensing requirements of article XIV of this chapter; or radios which provide only music; or televisions carrying only commercial broadcasts; or bowling devices such as bowling lanes; or fixed-stand, coin-operated kiddie rides. 
    Applicant means any individual, association, partnership or corporation requesting a license pursuant to this article. 
    Manager means any individual who manages, directs, supervises, oversees and administers the acts and transactions of the agents or servants of any establishment governed by this article, or who, through his own actions, directs, oversees and administers the affairs of any such establishment. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-1) 
Sec. 14-174. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to operate or conduct any amusement arcade or amusement center without first having obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-2) 
Sec. 14-175. - Application. 
    The application for an amusement arcade or amusement center license shall be made to the city clerk, and shall be accompanied by the appropriate fees as required in section 14-177, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the establishment; 
(2)  The name, address, age, date and place of birth, and prior felony convictions, if any, of the applicant and the manager of the establishment; 
(3)  The site plan, furnished by the applicant, and evidence that the location of the proposed establishment is within the proper zoning district and meets all the zoning requirements of the city; 
(4)  Where the applicant is a corporation, association, partnership or private club, the information required in section 14-144 shall be furnished on each member of the association, or each officer of the corporation and members of the board of directors of the corporation, and the holders of ten percent or more of the corporate stock of any class; 
(5)  The distance from any other amusement arcade or public school, if an amusement arcade, or the distance from any public school, if an amusement center; 
(6)  The number of amusement devices to be maintained at the amusement arcade or amusement center. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-3) 
Sec. 14-176. - Procedure for processing application. 
(a)  The application for the license shall be reviewed by the city manager, who after receipt of all information required in section 14-175, shall cause an investigation to be conducted by the police department. Upon completion of this investigation, the city manager shall schedule a public hearing before the city council and notify the applicant by certified mail to appear in support of said application. Notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the applicant not less than 15 days before the hearing date. 
(b)  Notice of such public hearing will be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the community once not less than ten days prior to the hearing date and by posting a notice of public hearing upon the premises for at least ten days prior to the hearing. 
(c)  After such public hearing, the city council may either grant or deny the license. In determining whether to grant or deny the license, the council shall take into consideration the character of the applicant, applicant's prior experience and qualifications to operate such a business, the needs of the community for such a facility and the desires of its citizens regarding such a facility, including any petitions evidencing such desires. In addition, the city council may deny the license if any of the following is found: 
(1)  The applicant is under the age of 21 years. 
(2)  The applicant or manager has made false statements upon the application. 
(3)  The applicant or manager has been convicted of a felony within the last ten years. 
(4)  The proposed amusement arcade or amusement center is located within 500 feet of any public or parochial school grounds. Said distance shall be computed by direct measurement from the nearest property line of land used for school purposes to the nearest portion of the building in which the amusement arcade or amusement center is located. 
(5)  The proposed amusement arcade or amusement center is within 300 feet of any residential district. 
(6)  The designated manager is under the age of 18 years. 
(7)  The proposed amusement arcade is located within 1,000 feet of any other amusement arcade. Said distance shall be computed by direct measurement from the nearest property line of the land used for arcade purposes to the nearest portion of the building in which the amusement arcade is located. 
(d)  If the city council denies the license application, the city council shall provide written findings of fact stating the reasons for the disapproval furnished by the applicant in evidence that the location of the proposed establishment is within the proper zoning district. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-4) 
Sec. 14-177. - Fees. 
(a)  Applicants or holders of an amusement arcade license shall pay a maximum yearly fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16. 
(b)  Applicants, or holders, of an amusement center license shall pay a maximum yearly fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16. 
(c)  Applicants for a new amusement arcade or amusement center license shall pay a maximum investigation fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16 to defray costs of the required investigation. 
(d)  The actual fees shall be as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-5) 
Sec. 14-178. - Expiration of licenses. 
    All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were issued. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-6) 
Sec. 14-179. - Renewal of license. 
(a)  Renewal of any of the licenses granted pursuant to this article may be had by payment of the license fee, along with the filing of a new application, and compliance with the requirements of this article, and all other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Failure to renew a license in a timely manner shall be grounds for termination and revocation of said license, and shall be grounds for failure to renew said license. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-7) 
Sec. 14-180. - Hours of operation. 
    Premises licensed hereunder shall be open to the public between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. daily unless the licensee also holds a liquor license issued in accordance with article IX of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-8) 
Sec. 14-181. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any patron or other person on the premises of any amusement arcade or amusement center licensed hereunder, to drink any alcoholic beverage or 3.2 percent beer unless the licensee also holds a liquor license issued in accordance with article IX of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to gamble or to permit gambling upon any pool or billiard table or coin-operated amusement game or device. The licensee of any amusement arcade or amusement center licensed hereunder is hereby specifically charged with knowledge of and made liable for the use of all tables, games and devices therein in any manner constituting a violation of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or other person in charge of the premises licensed hereunder, to permit any person under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, dangerous drug, chemical substance or narcotic to be or remain upon the premises. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or other person in charge of the premises licensed hereunder, to sell or distribute, or allow the sale or distribution of any alcoholic beverage, dangerous drug, chemical substance or narcotic upon the premises. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or other person in charge of the premises licensed hereunder, to fail to notify the city police department in the event any of the prohibited acts are committed. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-9) 
Sec. 14-182. - Security guards. 
    The owner of any amusement arcade licensed hereunder shall maintain a full-time city-licensed security guard. Notwithstanding the fact that said security guards may be full-time employees of the owner, they must comply in all other respects with all of the requirements for security guards set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 12-4-10) 
Secs. 14-183-14-202. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SECURITY GUARDS AND DETECTIVES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Security guards, C.R.S. § 24-33.5-415.4. 

Sec. 14-203. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Armed couriers means all persons who carry a firearm and are engaged in the business of traveling from one business to another for the purpose of picking up or delivering valuable items such as currency, negotiable instruments or merchandise. 
    Detective agency means a business which provides private detectives for hire. 
    Firearm means any handgun, automatic, revolver, pistol, rifle, shotgun or other instrument or device capable or intended to be capable of discharging bullets, cartridges or other explosive charges. 
    Principals of the business and principals means owner, partner, officer, manager, director or the holder of more than ten percent of the stock of a corporation. 
    Private detective means any person who is employed for the purpose of obtaining information not readily available or publicly accessible or for the purpose of determining the existence, presence or fact of some person or event, but does not include insurance adjusting or credit checking. 
    Security guard business means a business which provides security guards for hire. 
    Security guards means all persons who are directly engaged in providing protection to persons or property or to preserve the peace in the conduct of a business or activity, but excludes armed couriers. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-1) 
Sec. 14-204. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on a security guard business or detective agency in the city without first obtaining a license as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any security guard business or detective agency to employ any security guard or private detective in the city unless the person so employed has obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to become employed in the city as a security guard or private detective without first obtaining a license as provided in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-2) 
Sec. 14-205. - Exceptions to article provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or regulate the activities of: 
(1)  Any police officer while acting or engaged in his official capacity. 
(2)  Any officer of the city police department engaged in off-duty employment. 
(3)  Any security guard or private detective who does not carry a firearm. 
(4)  Any security guard business or detective agency in which none of the employees carry firearms. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-3) 
Sec. 14-206. - License application required. 
(a)  Each applicant for a security guard business license or detective agency license shall provide the city clerk with the following information: 
(1)  A description of the nature and type of business to be conducted. 
(2)  A business address. 
(3)  The name, place of residence, date of birth and citizenship of the principals of the business. 
(4)  A statement of the principals' convictions of any felony or misdemeanor excluding traffic violations. 
(5)  A cash or corporate surety bond in the amount of $10,000.00 conditioned that the principal obligor shall faithfully comply with the terms of this article and shall lawfully, and without claiming the authority of any public entity, conduct his security guard or detective agency business in compliance with the ordinances of the city and laws of the state. Such bond should be payable to the city and may be sued upon in the name of the city by and to the use of any person injured by a breach of the conditions of said bond. 
(6)  Such other information as required by the city. 
(b)  Individual security guards or detectives applying for a license shall provide the city clerk with the following information: 
(1)  Name, place of residence, date of birth and citizenship. 
(2)  A statement of the applicant's convictions of any felony or misdemeanor excluding traffic violations. 
(3)  One clear passport size photograph. 
(4)  One set of fingerprints taken by the city police department. 
(5)  Such other information as required by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-4) 
Sec. 14-207. - License application fees. 
(a)  All applications for a security guard business or detective agency license shall be accompanied by a fee. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution. 
(b)  All applications for a security guard or detective license shall be accompanied by a fee. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution. 
(c)  No application fee shall be charged on a renewal of an existing license, but a change in ownership shall require a new application, application fee and license. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-5) 
Sec. 14-208. - Maximum; license expiration. 
(a)  The maximum fee for a security guard business license or detective agency license as provided for in section 14-207 shall be from the date of issue until December 31 of the year of issue. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution. 
(b)  The fee for such security guard or detective license as provided for in section 14-207 shall be from the date of approval until December 31 of the year of issue. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution. 
(c)  License fees shall not be prorated. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-6) 
Sec. 14-209. - Issuance of license. 
    No person shall be licensed under the provisions of this article unless: 
(1)  The applicant is a citizen of the U.S. and at least 21 years of age. 
(2)  The applicant meets all provisions of this article, and article II of this chapter, if applicable. 
(3)  In the instance of a corporation as applicant, the corporation is organized or authorized to do business in the state. 
(4)  The applicant and/or principals have not been convicted of any felony within ten years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(5)  The applicant and/or principals have not been convicted of any misdemeanor involving the use of a weapon or the infliction of violence within ten years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-7(A)-(E)) 
Sec. 14-210. - License contents. 
    Every license issued under the provisions of this article shall be signed by the city clerk and shall have the seal of the city affixed thereto. It shall include the date of issuance and the expiration date of the license. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-8) 
Sec. 14-211. - Nonassignability. 
    No security guard business or detective agency license or security guard or detective license issued pursuant to this article shall be assignable, nor shall any security guard or detective license authorize any person to conduct this type of business, or to act pursuant to such license, other than the person or business to whom such license is issued. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-9) 
Sec. 14-212. - Denial of application. 
    In the event the application for a security guard or detective agency business license or security guard or detective license is denied, the license fee shall be returned forthwith to the proposed licensee. The application fees are nonrefundable. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-10) 
Sec. 14-213. - Expiration of license. 
    Every license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year of issue. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-11) 
Sec. 14-214. - Exhibition of license upon request by city officers. 
    All persons or businesses licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be required to exhibit their license when requested to do so by an officer of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-12) 
Sec. 14-215. - Rights and privileges. 
    The provisions of this article grant no authority other than the authority to engage in a security guard or detective agency business. No provision in this article shall be construed as to grant special rights or privileges in regard to the power of arrest, patrol cars, patrol car lights and sirens, waiver of any ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, or any other special right or privilege. Security guard businesses or detective agencies licensed under this article shall act completely at their own discretion or at the discretion and direction of the person whose interests such company, security guard or detective were employed to serve and the city disavows any authority to direct the individual actions of such licensees, their agents, or employees, except as provided by the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-13) 
Sec. 14-216. - Appeal from license denial. 
    Any applicant may appeal any license denial hereunder. The hearing shall be in accordance with chapter II, article X. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-14) 
Sec. 14-217. - Nonrenewal. 
    The administration or building department may notify the licensing authority, in writing, of reasons for nonrenewal. The procedures shall be the same as those used in article II, division 3, suspension and revocation. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-15) 
Sec. 14-218. - Suspension/revocation. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article may be suspended or revoked by the city manager in accordance with the procedure set forth in article II, division 3. 
(Code 1985, § 12-5-16) 
Secs. 14-219-14-244. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Mobile Home Park Act, C.R.S. § 38-12-101 et seq.; factory built housing, C.R.S. § 24-32-701 et seq.; campers and camper trailers, C.R.S. § 24-32-901 et seq. 

Sec. 14-245. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Independent travel trailer means a trailer designed to be pulled on the highway by an automobile or light truck and having a flush toilet, a bath or shower, sleeping accommodations, and kitchen facilities to include a sink, stove and refrigerator or ice box. 
    Mobile home means a single-family dwelling unit, transportable on its own wheels or on a flat bed or other trailer or detachable wheels, suitable for yearround occupancy, and containing sleeping accommodations, a flush toilet, a tub or shower bath and kitchen facilities with permanent or semi-permanent plumbing and electrical connections provided for attachment to outside systems. 
    Motor home means a self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on the highway and having a flush toilet, a bath or shower, sleeping accommodations and kitchen facilities to include a sink, stove and refrigerator or ice box. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-1) 
Sec. 14-246. - Location. 
    Independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle parks shall constitute a special use by permit only in C-1 commercial zones of the city. The applicant for such use shall prove to the satisfaction of the city council that such use will not have adverse effects on existing uses, uses in adjoining zones or potential commercial uses. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-2) 
Sec. 14-247. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the city any independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-3) 
Sec. 14-248. - License fees. 
    The annual license fee for each independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park shall be as prescribed by resolution. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-4) 
Sec. 14-249. - Expiration of license. 
    All independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park licenses shall expire at midnight of the year for which it was issued. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-5) 
Sec. 14-250. - Application for license. 
    Applications for an independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park license shall be filed with the city clerk and issued by the city council upon demonstration to the city council's satisfaction that the intended use meets the criteria for a special use permit and upon approval of the application by the building inspector. Applications shall be submitted in writing, signed by the applicant and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park. 
(3)  A complete plan of the park showing compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed or to be constructed within the independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park. 
(5)  Such further information as required by the city council, planning and zoning commission and the building inspector. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-6) 
Sec. 14-251. - Independent travel trailer and motor home recreational vehicle park plan. 
    The park shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  The park shall be located on a well-drained site properly graded to ensure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. 
(2)  Travel trailer and motor home and recreational vehicle spaces shall be provided consisting of a minimum of 1,000 square feet for each space which shall be at least 25 feet wide and clearly defined. Travel trailers and motor homes and recreational vehicles shall be so parked as to maintain at least a 15-foot clearance between such units and between the units and any building within the park. 
(3)  All spaces shall abut upon a paved driveway not less than 16 feet wide if one way and not less than 24 feet if two-way and shall have unobstructed access to a public street, alley or highway. All driveways shall be adequately lighted at night. 
(4)  An electrical outlet supplying at least 110 volts shall be provided for each space. 
(5)  A service building shall be provided with adequate laundry facilities for the patrons of the park, with a minimum of one washer and dryer per 20 spaces. 
(6)  All spaces shall have safe and sanitary means of connection to a park water distribution and sewer collection system; the park system shall be connected to the city's water and sewer systems. 
(7)  Natural gas shall be provided for each space on which residences of over three months are permitted. 
(8)  Developed play and recreational areas in the amount of eight percent of the total area shall be required if children are allowed in the park. 
(9)  The park shall be screened around its entirety with a six-foot solid fence. The fence shall be set back from the property line as determined by the city council or prevailing zoning requirements. The area outside the fence shall be landscaped in accordance with a landscaping plan approved by the city council. 
(10)  The interior of the park shall be landscaped so as to provide grassed areas and shade. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-7) 
Sec. 14-252. - Operation of the independent travel trailer and motor home and recreational vehicle park. 
    The park shall be operated in conformance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Maintain a register of occupants, to include name, permanent address, when applicable, and make, model, year and license number of travel trailers, motor homes, recreational vehicles and automobiles. This register shall be available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, public health officials, and other officials whose duties necessitate access to the information contained in the register. 
(2)  Provide adequate supervision and maintain the park in a quiet and orderly fashion. 
(3)  Make adequate and sanitary provisions for trash and garage storage and pick-up. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-8) 
Sec. 14-253. - Mobile homes. 
    The city council may, at its discretion, authorize the use of the independent travel trailer and motor home and recreational vehicle park by a mobile home 36 feet or less in length. Such mobile homes must be in presentable and safe condition and must be secure and pay for a move-in permit, pass all required inspections and be completely skirted if in the park over 120 days. Skirting and move-in permits are not required for travel trailers and motor homes and recreational vehicles regardless of length of stay. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-9) 
Sec. 14-254. - Suspension and revocation. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article may be suspended or revoked by the city manager in accordance with the grounds set forth in section 14-79 and the procedures set forth in chapter II, article XI. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-10) 
Sec. 14-255. - Miscellaneous laws and regulations. 
    In addition to the requirements set forth in this article, all independent travel trailers and mobile home parks and facilities shall be established, constructed and operated in compliance with all existing state and local statutes, ordinances, codes and regulations. 
(Code 1985, § 12-7-10) 
Secs. 14-256-14-273. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MASSAGE PARLORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Massage parlor, C.R.S. § 12-48-101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-274. - Legislative declaration. 
    The city council declares that this article is an exercise of the police powers of the city for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the people of this city. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-1) 
Sec. 14-275. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apparatus means appliance, equipment, or object used in the application of a massage, but does not include furniture, towels, linens, oils or showers. 
    External baths means water vapor, steam, sweat, electric, salt, alcohol rubs or any other kind of massage. 
    Good cause , for the purpose of denying a license renewal means: 
(1)  The licensee or applicant has violated, does not meet, or has failed to comply with any of the terms, conditions, or provisions of this article or any rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this article; 
(2)  The licensee or applicant has failed to comply with any special terms or conditions that were placed on its license in prior disciplinary proceedings or arose in the context of potential disciplinary proceedings; or 
(3)  Evidence that the licensed premises have been operated in a manner that adversely affects the public health, welfare, or safety of the immediate neighborhood in which the establishment is located, which evidence may include a continuing pattern of fights, violent activity, or disorderly conduct. 
    License means a grant to a licensee to operate a massage parlor. 
    Licensed premises means the premises specified in an approved application for a license under this article which is owned or in the possession of the licensee and within which the licensee is authorized to provide massages. 
    Local licensing authority means the city council or any authority designated by municipal ordinance. 
    Location means a parcel of land that may be identified by an address or other descriptive means. 
    Massage means a method of treating the body for remedial or hygienic purposes including, but not limited to, rubbing, stroking, kneading or tapping with the hand or an instrument, or both. 
    Massage parlor means an establishment providing massage, but it does not include training rooms of public and private schools accredited by the state board of education or approved by the division charged with the responsibility of approving private occupational schools, training rooms or recognized professional or amateur athletic teams, and licensed health care facilities. A facility that is operated for the purpose of massage therapy performed by a massage therapist is not a massage parlor. 
    Massage therapist means an individual licensed by the state to engage in the practice of massage therapy. The terms "masseuse" and "masseur' are synonymous with the term "massage therapist." 
    Massage therapy means a system of structured touch, palpation, or movement of the soft tissue of another person's body in order to enhance or restore the general health and well-being of the recipient. Such system includes, but is not limited to, techniques such as effleurage, commonly called stroking or gliding; petrissage, commonly called kneading; tapotement or percussion; friction, vibration, compression, passive and active stretching within the normal anatomical range of movement; hydromassage, and thermal massage. Such techniques may be applied with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or herbal preparations, water, heat, or a massage device that mimics or enhances the actions possible by human hands. "Massage" or "massage therapy" does not include therapeutic exercise, intentional joint mobilization or manipulation, or any of the methods described in C.R.S. § 12-35.5-110(e). 
    Person means a natural person, partnership, association, company, corporation, organization, joint venture, managing agent, servant, officer or employee. 
    Premises means a distinct location which includes, but is not limited to, a building, a part of a building, or a room or definite area contiguous to any of them. 
    Recognized school means an institution of learning which teaches the theory, method or work of massage and which requires 500 class hours for graduation and instruction in anatomy and physiology. The school shall furnish each student who satisfactorily completes these requirements a diploma or certificate of graduation. If a school is located outside this state, it shall meet the requirements of this article. If the school is located within this state, it shall meet the requirements contained in C.R.S. § 12-59-101 et seq. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-2; Ord. No. 15-06, § 1, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-276. - General licensing provisions. 
(a)  All licenses granted under this article are valid for a period of one year from the date of their issuance unless revoked or suspended as set forth in this article. 
(b)  Application for the renewal of an existing license shall be made to the city clerk not less than 45 days prior to the date of expiration. The city council may hold a hearing on the application for renewal, provided a notice of hearing has been conspicuously posted on the licensed premises for a period of ten days prior to the hearing. The city council may refuse to renew any license for "good cause," subject to judicial review. 
(c)  Upon receiving an application for a license to operate a massage parlor, the city council shall set, at its next regular meeting, the boundaries of the neighborhood to be considered pursuant to subsection (d) of this section in determining whether to grant the license. The applicant or any other interested party may attend this meeting and present evidence regarding neighborhood boundaries. 
(d)  Before granting a massage parlor license, the city council shall consider the reasonable requirements of the neighborhood, the desires of the neighborhood's inhabitants as evidenced, for example, by petitions, remonstrances, or otherwise, and the character, record, and reputation of the licensee. 
(e)  Each license issued under this article is distinct, and no person shall exercise privileges granted under any license other than that which he holds. A separate license is required for each massage parlor. 
(f)  A license granted under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable. 
(g)  The location for licensed premises shall not be changed. 
(h)  Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall specify the date of issuance, the period that is covered, the name of the licensee, and the name and location of the premises licensed. Each massage parlor shall at all times conspicuously display its license. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-3; Ord. No. 15-06, § 2, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-277. - Application for license and fee. 
(a)  A person seeking a license to operate a massage parlor shall make application to the city clerk and pay a nonrefundable application fee. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution of city council in accordance with section 1-16 of the Code. 
(b)  For each renewal of license, the applicant shall pay a nonrefundable renewal fee to the city. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution of city council in accordance with section 1-16 of the Code. 
(c)  Each applicant receiving a license shall pay an annual license fee to the city in an amount prescribed by resolution of city council in accordance with section 1-16 of the Code. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-4; Ord. No. 15-06, § 3, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-278. - Contents of application. 
    An applicant for a license shall submit to the city clerk the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the massage parlor; 
(2)  Full name and present address of applicant; 
(3)  Three previous addresses of applicant and dates of residence at each; 
(4)  Written proof that the applicant is at least 21 years old; 
(5)  Two recent portrait photographs of the applicant at least two inches square taken within six months of application; 
(6)  Detailed and complete business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the ten-year period preceding the application; 
(7)  Business license history of the applicant, including whether applicant has previously had a license revoked or suspended in this or another state, the reason therefor, and business activity or occupation subsequent to suspension or revocation; 
(8)  All criminal convictions, except traffic offenses, and the reasons therefor; 
(9)  Further identification and information if requested by the police chief to discover the truth of matters specified in the application; 
(10)  The site plan and evidence that the location of the proposed massage parlor is within the proper zoning district and complies with the city's zoning requirements; 
(11)  Where the applicant is a corporation, association, partnership, joint venture or private club, the information required in subsection (10) of this section shall be furnished for each officer of the corporation, each member of the board of directors of the corporation and each holder of at least ten percent of the corporate stock of any class; each member of the association, partnership, joint venture or private club; 
(12)  The distance from other massage parlors in the cities of Federal Heights, Westminster and Thornton and the distance from any public or private school in the city; and 
(13)  The anticipated number of masseuses and employees who shall work at the massage parlor. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-5) 
Sec. 14-279. - Investigation of license application; inspection of premises and minimum requirements for issuance of license; identity cards. 
(a)  Before granting any license, the city may investigate the fitness to conduct such business of any person, business partner or officers and directors of any corporation applying for a license. In order to determine the fitness of any applicant, licensee or employee or agent of the licensee or applicant, the city may use criminal history information furnished by criminal justice agencies. If the applicant's criminal history record is considered by the city council, the city council shall consider information provided by the applicant including, but not limited to, evidence of rehabilitation, character references and educational achievements, particularly those items pertaining to the period after the applicant's last criminal conviction and before his application for a license under this article. 
(b)  Before granting any license, an inspection of the premises shall be conducted by the building inspector and the fire department. No license shall be issued unless the inspection reveals that the premises meets each of the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  A recognizable and legible sign posted at a main entrance identifying the establishment as a massage parlor. 
(2)  Minimum lighting in accordance with the city building code, and, in addition, an artificial light of not less than 40 watts shall be provided in each room or enclosure where massage services are performed on patrons. 
(3)  Minimum ventilation in accordance with the city building code. 
(4)  Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in performing acts of massage. 
(5)  Hot and cold running water available at all times. 
(6)  Closed cabinets for the storage of clean linens. 
(7)  Adequate bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities for patrons. A minimum of one tub or shower, one dressing room containing a separate locker for each patron to be served, which locker shall be capable of being locked, and a minimum of one toilet and one wash basin by every massage parlor, provided, however, that if male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at said massage parlor, a separate massage room or rooms, separate dressing facilities, and separate toilet facilities shall be provided for male and female patrons. 
(8)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms and all other physical facilities for the establishment in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, or steam or vapor cabinets, shower compartments, and toilet rooms thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
(9)  Clean and sanitary towels and linens for each patron of the establishment. No common use of towels or linens is permitted. 
(10)  A minimum of one separate washbasin for each massage establishment for the use of employees of any such establishment, with soap or detergent and hot and cold running water at all times and located within or as close as practicable to the area used for massage services. In addition, sanitary towels are placed at each washbasin in permanently installed dispensers. 
(c)  Every applicant, licensee or agent or an employee of said applicant or licensee shall, prior to commencing work at the licensed premises, obtain an identity card and shall carry said identity card at all times while upon the licensed premises. The identity card shall state the full name and address of the person it identifies, the location of the massage parlor, the date the identity card was issued, and whether the person is authorized under this article to perform massages. The cost of the identity card shall be as set by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-6) 
Sec. 14-280. - Refusal of license by city council. 
(a)  The city council may deny a license based on any of the following findings: 
(1)  The premises on which the applicant proposes to conduct its business do not meet the requirements of this article; 
(2)  The character, record or reputation of the applicant, business partners or its officers or directors is such that violations of this article would be likely to result if a license was granted; 
(3)  The city council finds that the reasonable requirements of the neighborhood are already met and/or that the adult inhabitants of the neighborhood or other "party in interest" do not desire a massage parlor establishment; 
(4)  The applicant, or its agent, has made false statements in response to the application; 
(5)  The massage parlor is located within 500 feet of public or parochial school grounds. The distance is computed by direct measurement from the nearest property line of the land used for school purposes to the nearest portion of the building in which the massage parlor is located using a route of direct pedestrian access; 
(6)  The massage parlor is located within 300 feet of any residential district; 
(7)  The massage parlor is located within 1,000 feet of another massage parlor. The distance is computed by direct measurement from the nearest property line of the land used for massage parlor purposes to the nearest portion of the building in which the massage parlor is located, using a route of direct pedestrian access. 
(b)  If the city council denies an application or a renewal, the city council shall provide written findings of fact stating the reasons for the disapproval. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-7; Ord. No. 15-06, § 4, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-281. - Suspension and revocation. 
    In addition to any other penalties prescribed by this article, the city council has the power, on its own motion or on complaint, and after investigation and public hearing at which the licensee shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard, to suspend or revoke any license for any violation by the licensee or by any of its agents, servants, or employees of the provisions of this article, or of any of the terms, conditions or provisions of this article, or any of the terms, conditions or provisions of the license issued by the city council. In addition, the city council, in its discretion, may revoke or elect not to renew a license if it determines that the licensed premises have been inactive for at least three months or, in the case of a license approved for a facility which has not been constructed, such facility has not been constructed and placed in operation within one year of approval of the license application or construction of the facility has not commenced within one year of approval. The city council has the power to administer oaths and issue subpoenas and to require the presence of persons and production of papers, books and records necessary for any hearing authorized by this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-8) 
Sec. 14-282. - Persons prohibited as licensees. 
    No license provided by this article shall be issued to or held by: 
(1)  A corporation, any of whose officers, directors or stockholders holding ten percent of the outstanding initial capital stock are not of good moral character; 
(2)  A partnership, association, joint venture, private club or company whose officers, or members holding ten percent interest are not of good moral character; 
(3)  A person employing, assisted by, or financed by a person who is not of good moral character; 
(4)  A police officer, or prosecuting officer, or a city inspector or employee; or 
(5)  A person unsatisfactory to the city council in respect to the person's character, record or reputation. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-9; Ord. No. 15-06, § 5, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-283. - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Operate a massage parlor without holding a validly issued local license; 
(2)  Work at the licensed premises of a massage parlor without obtaining and carrying a valid identity card as required by this article; 
(3)  Obtain the services provided in a massage parlor when the person is under 18 years of age, unless such person is accompanied by his parent or has a physician's prescription for massage services; 
(4)  Allow the sale, giving or procuring of any massage service to any person under 18 years of age unless such person is accompanied by his parent or has a physician's prescription for massage services; 
(5)  Permit any person under the age of 18 years to be employed as an employee in a massage parlor. If any person who is not at least 18 years of age exhibits a fraudulent proof of age, any action relying on such fraudulent proof of age shall not constitute grounds for the revocation or suspension of a license issued under this article unless the person employing such person knew or should have known that the proof of age was fraudulent; or 
(6)  Fail to display at all times in a prominent place on the licensed premises a printed card, with a minimum height of 14 inches and a width of 11 inches, with each letter a minimum of one-half inch in height, which shall read as follows: 
WARNING 
    IT IS ILLEGAL FOR ANY PERSON UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE TO BE IN OR UPON THESE PREMISES AT ANY TIME, UNLESS HE IS ACCOMPANIED BY HIS PARENT OR HAS A PHYSICIAN'S PRESCRIPTION FOR MASSAGE SERVICES. 
    IT IS ILLEGAL FOR ANY PERSON TO ALLOW A PERSON UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE TO BE IN OR UPON THESE PREMISES AT ANY TIME, UNLESS HE IS ACCOMPANIED BY HIS PARENT OR HAS A PHYSICIAN'S PRESCRIPTION FOR MASSAGE SERVICES. 
    FINES OR IMPRISONMENT MAY BE IMPOSED BY THE FEDERAL HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL COURT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FEDERAL HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-10; Ord. No. 15-06, § 6, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-284. - Public hearing regarding premises; public notice; posting; publication; sign to be placed on premises. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application to the city clerk, except an application for renewal, the city shall schedule a public hearing on the application at least 30 days after the application and shall post and publish public notice of the application at least ten days prior to such hearing. Public notice shall be given by posting a sign in a conspicuous place on the premises for which application has been made and by publishing in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality or county in which the premises are located. 
(b)  Notice given by posting shall include a sign not less than 22 inches wide and 26 inches high, composed of letters at least one inch in height and stating the type of license applied for, the date of the application, the date of the hearing, the name and address of the applicant, and information necessary to fully apprise the public of the nature of the application. If the applicant is a partnership, the sign shall contain the names and addresses of all partners, and, if the applicant is a corporation, association or other organization, the sign shall contain the names and addresses of the president, vice-president, secretary and manager or other designated officers. 
(c)  Notice given by publication shall contain the same information as required for signs as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  If the building in which the massage parlor is to be operated is in existence at the time of the application, any sign posted as required in subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall be plainly visible to the general public. If the building is not constructed at the time of the application, the applicant shall post the premises upon which the building is to be constructed in a manner plainly visible to the general public. 
(e)  At the public hearing, any party in interest shall be allowed to present evidence and cross examine witnesses. As used in this article, the term "party in interest" includes the applicant, a resident of the neighborhood under consideration, or the owner or manager of a business located in the neighborhood under consideration. 
(f)  The city council may limit the presentation of evidence and cross examination so as to prevent repetitive and cumulative evidence or examination. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-11; Ord. No. 15-06, § 7, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-285. - Results of investigation; decision of authorities. 
(a)  At least five days before the date of the hearing, the city clerk shall make known, in writing, the city's findings based upon its investigations, to the applicant. The city council has authority to refuse to issue any license for good cause. 
(b)  Before entering any decision approving or denying the application, the city council shall consider, except where this article specifically provides otherwise, the facts and evidence produced as a result of the city's investigation, including the reasonable requirements of the neighborhood for the license for which application has been made, the desires of the inhabitants, the number, type and availability of other massage parlors located in or near the neighborhood under consideration, and pertinent matters affecting the qualifications of the applicant for the conduct of the massage parlor. 
(c)  A decision by the city council approving, denying an application, or renewal shall be in writing stating the reasons and shall be made within 30 days after the date of the public hearing, and a copy of the decision shall be mailed to the applicant at the address stated in the application. 
(d)  No license shall be issued by the city council after approval of an application until the building in which the business is to be conducted is ready for occupancy with such furniture, fixtures and equipment in place as are necessary to comply with the provisions of this article, and then only after inspection of the premises has been made by the department of building inspection to determine that the applicant has complied with the drawing and plans and specifications submitted by the applicant. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-12; Ord. No. 15-06, § 9, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-286. - Restrictions for applications for new licenses. 
    No application for the issuance of any license authorized by this article shall be received or acted upon: 
(1)  If, within two years before the date of the application, the city council has denied an application at the same location for the reason that the reasonable requirements of the neighborhood and the desires of the inhabitants were satisfied by existing massage parlors; 
(2)  Until it is established that the applicant is, or will be, entitled to possession of the premises for which application is made under a lease, rental agreement, or other arrangement for possession of the premises or by virtue of ownership; or 
(3)  For a location in an area where the operation of a massage parlor is not permitted under the applicable zoning laws of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-13) 
Sec. 14-287. - Inspections. 
    The building inspector and the fire department shall twice each year make an inspection of each massage parlor in the city for the purpose of determining that the provisions of this article are met. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-14) 
Sec. 14-288. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    No alcoholic beverages of any kind may be allowed on the premises of a massage parlor. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-15) 
Sec. 14-289. - Employees. 
    The holder of a massage parlor license shall require that all of the parlor's employees meet all the standards, terms and conditions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-16) 
Sec. 14-290. - Records of treatment. 
    Every person operating a massage parlor or establishment under a license shall keep a record of the date and hour of each treatment, the name and address of the patron, and the name of the employee administering such treatment. The record shall be open to inspection by city officials charged with the enforcement of this article. Said records shall be maintained for a period of two years. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-17; Ord. No. 15-06, § 9, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 14-291. - Sale or transfer. 
(a)  Upon the sale or transfer of ownership of any interest in a massage parlor, the license shall expire. A new application shall be made by the person, firm or entity desiring to own or operate the massage establishment. A fee as set by resolution of the city council shall be payable for each such application involving sale or other transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment. 
(b)  Any such sale or transfer of any interests in an existing massage parlor or any application for an extension of the building or other place of business of the massage parlor, shall require inspection and compliance with this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-9-18) 
Sec. 14-292. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-06, § 10, adopted July 21, 2015, repealed § 14-292, which pertained to applicability of regulations to existing businesses; state licensing requirements and derived from the Code of 1985, § 12-9-19. 
Secs. 14-293-14-317. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 14-318-14-337. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LIQUOR CODE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-07, § 1, adopted April 16, 2013, repealed the former Div. 2, §§ 14-338-14-345, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1985, §§ 12-10-1-12-10-11 and Ord. No. 11-10, adopted September 20, 2011. 

Sec. 14-338. - Local liquor licensing authority; duties and powers. 
(a)  Local liquor licensing authority; duties and powers. The local liquor licensing authority ("authority") shall have all powers and duties granted to local liquor licensing authorities as set forth in C.R.S. tit. 44, art. 1 C.C.R. 203-2, as all may be amended from time to time. The authority shall have the duty and authority, for example, to grant or refuse licenses for the possession, sale and offering for sale of malt, special malt, vinous or spirituous liquors and fermented malt beverages as provided by law, to conduct investigations, hold hearings and levy penalties against licensees in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  Composition, appointment, removal, and compensation. 
(1)  Subject to the delegation of authority set forth in subparagraph (2) below, the authority shall consist of a sole hearing officer who shall serve at the pleasure of city council. The hearing officer shall be appointed by the city council by resolution and may be removed with or without cause by a majority vote of the entire city council. City council shall establish compensation for the hearing officer. City council may, in its discretion, appoint an alternate hearing officer who may serve in the event that the appointed hearing officer is unavailable. The term "hearing officer" shall be synonymous with "local liquor licensing authority," as used throughout this division. 
(2)  Delegation of authority to city clerk. The city clerk is authorized to act as the local liquor licensing authority for the Colorado Liquor Code, C.R.S. tit. 44, art. 3, and Colorado Beer Code, C.R.S. tit. 44, art. 4, licensing functions: 
a.  Processing and issuance of special events permits pursuant to C.R.S. tit. 44, art. 5, provided that there are no parties filing a written objection to said permit. 
b.  Annual Colorado Liquor Code and Colorado Beer Code license renewals, provided that the licensee has not violated any provisions of the Colorado Liquor or Beer Codes and associated regulations during the preceding year. 
c.  Changes in shareholders, officers, directors or trade names of a licensee, provided that any investigation conducted by the city does not reveal information that may reasonably form the basis of a determination that the applicant is not qualified to hold the respective license. 
d.  The issuance of temporary permits pursuant to and in compliance with the provisions of C.R.S. §§ 44-3-302 and 44-3-303. 
    The city clerk may, nevertheless, refer any licensing decision authorized under this section to the authority if, in the clerk's discretion, the matter should be presented to the authority. 
(c)  Qualifications of hearing officer. The hearing officer shall be an individual over the age of 21 years and with sufficient knowledge and expertise to apply and enforce the State of Colorado Beer Code, Liquor Code, Special Events Code, and Liquor Rules. The hearing officer shall not hold any other city office, appointment or position, except that city council may appoint the municipal court judge as the hearing officer. Additionally, the hearing officer shall not have any financial interest in the operation of any business located or operating in the city that holds a license pursuant to Colorado Liquor or Beer Code. 
(d)  Rules of procedure; conduct of hearings. In conformity with applicable statutes and the Federal Heights Municipal Code, the authority shall have the power to adopt rules of procedure and regulations concerning the application and renewal processes, procedures for hearings before it, and the presentation of evidence at such hearings. All hearings before the authority shall be public and shall be conducted in accordance with the rules and regulations concerning the procedures for hearings adopted by the authority. 
(e)  Meetings. The authority shall hold a regular meeting once each calendar month, unless there is no business to conduct. The authority may unilaterally call special meetings upon and after consultation with the city clerk or the city clerk's designee. 
(f)  Subpoena power and violations. The local liquor licensing authority shall have the power to administer oaths and issue subpoenas to require the presence of persons and the production of documents, data compilations, and other evidence at any hearing before the authority. A subpoena shall be served in the same manner as a subpoena issued by a District Court of the State of Colorado. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any subpoena or order to produce documents, data compilations, or other evidence issued by the authority. The municipal court shall enforce the subpoenas of the authority and, upon good cause shown, shall enter orders compelling witnesses to attend and testify or produce documents, data compilations, or other evidence, and shall impose penalties or punishment for contempt in case of failure to comply with such orders. 
(g)  City staff duties. 
(1)  City clerk. In addition to the duties and authority set forth in subsection (b)(2), the city clerk or the city clerk's designee shall: 
a.  Receive all license applications and issue those licenses granted by the local liquor licensing authority upon receipt of such license fees as are required by law; 
b.  Attend all meetings of the local liquor licensing authority and serve as the secretary of the authority; 
c.  Establish a calendar of regular meetings for the local liquor licensing authority, which calendar may be modified by the authority; 
d.  Post and publish all required notices in conformance with C.R.S. tit. 44, as amended, and the regulations that may from time to time be adopted by the state licensing authority. 
(2)  City attorney. The city attorney or the city attorney's designee shall represent the city at hearings to show cause and at hearings on applications or renewals that are contested by the city, and shall present matters into evidence before the authority. The city attorney shall also represent the city and the authority in the event of an appeal of any decision of the authority. 
(Ord. No. 13-07, § 1, 4-16-2013; Ord. No. 18-11, § 1, 8-21-2018) 
Sec. 14-339. - Tastings. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the following word and term shall have the meaning set forth in this section: 
    Tastings means the sampling of malt, vinous, or spirituous liquors that may occur on the premises of a retail liquor store licensee or liquor licensed drugstore licensee by adult patrons of the licensee pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Permitting in general. 
(1)  The city hereby authorizes tastings to be conducted by retail liquor store licensees or liquor licensed drugstore licensees in accordance with this section, and pursuant to C.R.S. § 44-3-301. The local licensing authority is authorized to issue tasting permits in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person to conduct a tasting without having a tasting permit issued by the city or to conduct a tasting in violation of the rules and regulations set forth in C.R.S. § 44-3-301, or this section. 
(3)  A retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore licensee that desires to conduct tastings shall submit an application for an annual tastings permit to the local licensing authority. All applicants shall pay an application and application renewal fee in an amount determined by resolution of city council. The local licensing authority may reject the application if the applicant fails to establish that the licensee is able to conduct tastings without violating the provisions of this section or creating a public safety risk to the neighborhood. The local licensing authority shall establish the application procedure and may, subject to conditions, delegate renewal of permits to the city clerk. 
(4)  Tastings shall be subject to the following limitations: 
a.  Tastings shall be conducted only by a person who has completed a server training program that meets the standards established by the Liquor Enforcement Division of the Colorado Department of Revenue and who is a retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore licensee, an employee of a retail liquor store or liquor-licensed drugstore licensee, or a representative, employee or agent of the licensed wholesaler, brew pub, distillery pub, manufacturer, limited winery, importer, or vintner's restaurant promoting the alcohol beverages for the tasting, and on a licensee's licensed premises. 
b.  The alcohol used in tastings shall be purchased through a licensed wholesaler, licensed brew pub, or winery licensed pursuant to C.R.S. § 44-3-403, at a cost that is not less than the laid-in cost of such alcohol. 
c.  The size of an individual alcohol sample shall not exceed one ounce of malt or vinous liquor or one-half of one ounce of spirituous liquor. 
d.  Tastings shall not exceed a total of five hours in duration per day, which need not be consecutive. 
e.  Tastings shall be conducted only during the operating hours in which the licensee on whose premises the tastings occur is permitted to sell alcohol beverages, and in no case earlier than 11:00 a.m., or later than 9:00 p.m. 
f.  The licensee shall prohibit patrons from leaving the licensed premises with an unconsumed sample. 
g.  The licensee shall promptly remove all open and unconsumed alcohol beverage samples from the licensed premises, destroy the samples immediately following the completion of the tasting, or store any open containers of unconsumed alcohol beverages in a secure area outside the sales area of the licensed premises for use at a tasting conducted at a later time or date. 
h.  The licensee shall not serve a person who is under 21 years of age or who is visibly intoxicated. 
i.  The licensee shall not serve more than four individual samples to a patron during a tasting. 
j.  Alcohol samples shall be in open containers and shall be provided to a patron free of charge. 
k.  Tastings may occur no more than 156 days per year. 
l.  No manufacturer of spirituous or vinous liquors shall induce a licensee, through free goods or financial or in-kind assistance, to favor the manufacturer's products being sampled at a tasting. The licensee shall bear the financial and all other responsibility for a tasting conducted on its licensed premise. 
m.  The applicant for a tastings permit shall certify on the application that all persons serving alcohol at tastings have completed a server training program that meets the standards established by the Liquor Enforcement Division of the Colorado Department of Revenue. 
n.  Licensee's granted permits shall provide the city clerk with a schedule of dates and time for which the tastings will be conducted. Such schedule shall be provided to the city clerk no later than 72 hours prior to the tasting. 
(5)  The city recommends that permittees, without charge to its patrons, have available for consumption sandwiches or light snacks for all patrons who are served samples. 
(6)  A violation of a limitation specified in this section, by a retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore licensee, whether by the licensee's employees, agents, or otherwise, or by a representative, employee, or agent of the licensed wholesaler, brew pub, distillery pub, manufacturer, limited winery, importer, or vintner's restaurant that promoted the alcohol beverages for the tasting, is the responsibility of, and C.R.S. § 44-3-801 applies to, the retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore licensee that conducted the tasting. 
(7)  A retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore licensee conducting a tasting shall be subject to the same revocation, suspension, and enforcement provisions as otherwise apply to the licensee and are imposed by the local licensing authority. 
(Ord. No. 13-08, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 18-11, § 2, 8-21-2018) 
Secs. 14-340-14-363. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FIREWORKS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Fireworks, C.R.S. § 12-28-101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-364. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Display fireworks means large fireworks designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation and includes, but is not limited to, salutes containing more than 130 milligrams of explosive material, aerial shells containing more than 40 grams of pyrotechnic compositions, and other display pieces that exceed the limits of explosive materials for classification as consumer fireworks as defined in 16 CFR 1500.1 to 1500.272 and 16 CFR 1507.1 to 1507.12 and are classified as fireworks UN0333, UN0334, or UN0335 pursuant to 49 CFR 172.101, as amended, and including fused set pieces containing components that exceed 50 milligrams of salute powder. 
    Fireworks. 
(1)  The term "fireworks means any composition or device designed to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation, and that meets the definition of articles pyrotechnic, permissible fireworks, or display fireworks. 
(2)  The term "fireworks" does not include: 
a.  Toy caps, party poppers, and items similar to toy caps and party poppers that do not contain more than 16 milligrams of pyrotechnic composition per item and snappers that do not contain more than one milligram of explosive composition per item; 
b.  Highway flares, railroad fuses, ship distress signals, smoke candles, and other emergency signal devices; 
c.  Educational rockets and toy propellant device type engines used in such rockets when such rockets are of nonmetallic construction and utilize replaceable engines or model cartridges containing less than two ounces of propellant and when such engines or model cartridges are designed to be ignited by electrical means; 
d.  Fireworks which are used in testing or research by a licensed explosives laboratory. 
    Fireworks display operator means an individual who, by experience and training, has demonstrated the required skill and ability to safely set up and discharge display fireworks. 
    Pyrotechnic operator means an individual who, by experience and training, has demonstrated the required skill and ability to safely set up and discharge articles of pyrotechnics. 
    Storage means the possession of fireworks for safe custody, where the safekeeping is the principal object of deposit, and not the consumption or sale. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-1) 
State Law reference- Definitions, C.R.S. § 12-28-101 et seq. 
Sec. 14-365. - Possession prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, use, or possess with intent to use, any fireworks as defined in section 14-364. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-2) 
Sec. 14-366. - Sale prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, expose for sale or sell any fireworks; or to have fireworks in his possession with intent to offer for sale or sell. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-3) 
Sec. 14-367. - Public display by approved city departments and other groups; permit required. 
    The city council may grant permits within the corporate boundaries of the city for supervised public displays of fireworks conducted by departments of the city, fair associations, recreation districts or other organizations and groups, subject to the rules and regulations set forth in this article. Every display shall be handled by competent operators, have fire department officials in attendance, and shall be of such character and so located, discharged and fired as to not be hazardous to property or endanger any person or property. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-4) 
Sec. 14-368. - Permit application. 
(a)  Contents. Any person desiring to conduct a supervised public display of fireworks shall submit to the city clerk a written application for a permit to conduct such fireworks display. The application shall be submitted to the city clerk not less than 30 days in advance of the date of the fireworks display, and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee. The fee shall be as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the person or organization sponsoring the display, together with the names and addresses of the persons who will actually be operating the display; 
(2)  The date and time of day at which the display is to be held; 
(3)  The address and description of the exact location planned for the display; 
(4)  A diagram of the grounds on which the display is to be held, showing the point at which the fireworks are to be discharged, the location of buildings and streets within the vicinity, and the location of all nearby trees, telephone and utility lines, or any other overhead obstructions; 
(5)  The names and addresses of the competent fireworks operators who will be supervising the discharge of the fireworks, and written evidence regarding their competency as fireworks operators. At least two competent fireworks operators are to be provided, along with members of the city fire department; 
(6)  The type and class of fireworks to be discharged and the number of set pieces, shells (specifying single or multiple break), and other items including experimental or model rockets or missiles; 
(7)  The manner and place of storage of such fireworks prior to and during the display; 
(8)  Proof that satisfactory compensation insurance is carried by the applicant for all of the applicant's employees who will be working at the display; and 
(9)  Proof that the applicant has public liability insurance with the limits and coverage as set forth in section 14-373, protecting the city, fire department, applicant, manufacturer, wholesaler, seller, supplier, property owner and operators of the display from any liability or claims of damages arising out of or as a result of or related to the fireworks display. 
(b)  Review procedures. 
(1)  Upon receipt of an application for a fireworks display permit, the city clerk shall submit copies thereof to the chief of police and the fire chief. 
(2)  The fire chief and chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the location proposed for the fireworks display, for the purpose of determining if the fireworks display will be of such character or so located as to be hazardous to property or dangerous to any person.
