(3)  Upon completing their investigations provided for in subsection (b)(2) of this section, the fire chief and police chief shall submit to the city manager their written reports, setting forth the results of their investigations and their recommendations for the granting or denial of the permit, together with their recommendations with respect to the prescribing of reasonable conditions for the display, taking into account locations, parking of vehicles, control of spectators, storage and firing of fireworks, and precautions in general against danger to life and property from fire, explosion and panic. 
(4)  Before any permit is granted by the city council, the location and handling of the fireworks display shall first have been approved, after the investigations provided for in subsections (b)(2) and (b)(3) of this section, by the fire chief and police chief. 
(5)  No permit shall be granted by the city council unless the operators of the fireworks display have been first approved by the fire chief and police chief. 
(6)  No permit shall be granted where discharge, faulty firing or fallout from any fireworks or their objects would endanger persons, buildings, structures, woods and trees, brush, parks or similar areas and/or facilities. 
(7)  If, after and based upon the investigation and review criteria provided for in subsections (b)(2) through (b)(6) of this section, the fire chief's or police chief's report finds and concludes that the permit application be denied, then no such permit shall be granted. The city manager shall advise the applicant, in writing, that such application has been denied, and shall provide the applicant with a written summary of the reasons for such denial. 
(8)  If, after and based upon the investigations and review criteria provided for in subsections (b)(2) through b)(6) of this section, the permit application receives the approval of the fire chief and police chief, then the city manager shall submit copies of the fire chief's and police chief's reports and recommendations to the city council. 
(9)  The city council will review the permit application for compliance with the provisions of this article and will review the reports and recommendations of the fire chief and police chief. After completing its review, the city council will either grant the permit, grant the permit with conditions, deny the permit, or refer the permit application back to the applicant and/or to the fire chief or police chief for further information and/or review. Any applicant for a fireworks display permit whose permit application has received the approval of the fire chief and police chief shall be afforded an opportunity to make a presentation to the city council regarding the permit application at the city council meeting at which such permit application is scheduled to be considered by the city council. 
(Code 1985, §§ 12-11-5, 12-11-6) 
Sec. 14-369. - Permit issuance. 
    If the city council grants or grants with conditions, a display permit, the city manager shall provide the applicant with a written public fireworks display permit. The permit shall have included thereon such conditions of approval as may have been established by the city council and such conditions shall be an integral part of the permit. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-7) 
Sec. 14-370. - Transferability of permit. 
    No public fireworks display permit shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-8) 
Sec. 14-371. - Experienced operators required; duties. 
    No public fireworks display permit shall be granted unless at least two experienced fireworks operators are provided. Such operators shall be those individuals named in the permit application and shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for and have charge of the fireworks display with respect to preparation for the transporting, unloading and storing of all fireworks to be used at the display; 
(2)  Be responsible for setting all fireworks, including without limitation, mortars, finale batteries (hedgehogs) and rocket launchers, at locations designated by the fire chief; 
(3)  Be responsible for the loading and firing of all fireworks used at the display, and take into account wind direction and velocity predicted for the firing time in setting the firing angles. Shells, rockets, missiles and related types of fireworks shall not be permitted to cross or burst above areas occupied by persons; 
(4)  Be responsible for the safe disposal of all unfired or defective fireworks; and 
(5)  Be responsible for acts of all persons employed by the applicant, whether remunerated or not, in connection with the fireworks display. Such operators shall have authority to dismiss or discharge any employee or person at any time during the operation of the display who, through smoking, carelessness, negligence, or any other act, endangers the safety of any person or property. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-9) 
Sec. 14-372. - Permit; suspension and revocation. 
    The fire chief, police chief or other authorized fire or police officer may suspend any public fireworks display permit issued pursuant to this article whenever the fireworks display is in violation of any of the provisions of this article. In the event such violations are not corrected by the permittee, the fire chief or police chief or other authorized firefighters or police officers are authorized to revoke a public fireworks display permit. It is unlawful for any person to conduct a public fireworks display while any suspension or revocation is in effect. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-10) 
Sec. 14-373. - Liability insurance required. 
    Each applicant for a fireworks display permit shall have a policy of public liability insurance coverage with coverage of at least $100,000.00/$300,000.00 and a policy of property damage insurance in the amount of at least $50,000.00, all protecting from liability the applicant, the manufacturer, the supplier, the seller, the buyer, the property owner, the user, the manufacturer and the city. Prior to the issuance of a fireworks display permit, the applicant shall file a copy of the public liability insurance policy with the city clerk, who shall forward same to the city attorney for review. If the city attorney determines that the liability insurance policy is not satisfactory or does not comply with the requirements of this section, then the display permit to which the insurance policy is applicable shall not be issued. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-11) 
Sec. 14-374. - Bond required. 
    Prior to and as a condition to the issuance of a public fireworks display permit, and in addition to the public liability insurance required by section 14-373, the applicant for a permit shall file with the city clerk, with good and sufficient justification of sureties, a bond in the sum of $5,000.00, conditioned for payment of all damages which may be caused either to persons or property by reason of the licensed fireworks display and arising from any act of the permittee, his agents, employees or subcontractors, as well as conditioned on a thorough cleaning of the display area, except that the city shall not be required to file such a bond for its fireworks displays. The city clerk shall forward the bond to the city attorney for review. If the city attorney determines that the bond is not satisfactory or does not comply with the requirements of this section, then the display permit to which the bond is applicable shall not be issued. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-12) 
Sec. 14-375. - Conduct of public fireworks displays. 
    Every public fireworks display shall be conducted at such times, and at such places and pursuant to the conditions which may have been established by the city council. No public display of fireworks shall be conducted by any person or organization without a public fireworks display permit granted and issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-13) 
Sec. 14-376. - Crowd control. 
    Spectators at public displays of fireworks shall be retained behind lines or barriers, as designated and/or approved by the fire chief and police chief. Only authorized persons and those in actual charge of the display shall be allowed inside these lines or barriers during the unloading, preparation or firing of the fireworks. 
(Code 1985, § 12-11-14) 
Secs. 14-377-14-395. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 14-396. - Legislative intent. 
    It is the intent of this article to impose reasonable time, place and manner restrictions upon adult entertainment establishments to serve the substantial government interest of protecting and preserving the quality and vitality of the city and its citizens and not to prohibit adult entertainment nor constitutionally protected speech. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-1) 
Sec. 14-397. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin-operated or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projections or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images which are distinguished or characterized by the depicting or describing of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult bookstore or adult video store means a business having as a substantial and significant portion of its stock and trade, revenues, space or advertising expenditures, resulting from the sale, renting or viewing of one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes or video reproductions, laser discs, slides or other visual representations which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or 
(2)  Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for specified sexual activities. 
    Adult cabaret means a nightclub, bar, restaurant or similar business which regularly features: 
(1)  Persons who appear in a state of nudity; 
(2)  Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities; or 
(3)  Films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult entertainment establishment means an adult arcade, adult bookstore, adult video store, adult cabaret, adult motel, adult motion picture theater, adult theater, sexual encounter establishment, all as defined in this section, or other similar business, and includes: 
(1)  The opening or commencement of any adult entertainment establishment as a new business; 
(2)  The conversion of an existing business to an adult entertainment establishment; 
(3)  The addition of an adult entertainment establishment to any existing adult entertainment establishment; 
(4)  The relocation of any adult entertainment establishment; or 
(5)  The continuation of any adult entertainment establishment. 
    Adult material means books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, videocassettes or video reproductions laser discs, slides or other visual representations which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for specified sexual activities. 
    Adult motel means a hotel, motel or similar business which offers private rooms to the public and provides patrons live performances or closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult motion picture theater means a business where films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult theater means a theater, concert hall, auditorium, or similar business which regularly features persons who appear in a state of nudity or live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities. 
    Employee means any person who is paid by the licensee for services performed on the premises whether such person would otherwise, as a matter of law, be classified as an employee, agent, manager, entertainer or independent contractor. 
    Manager means any person other than a licensee who is employed by an adult entertainment establishment to act as manager or supervisor of the employees, finances, patrons of the establishment or is otherwise responsible for operation of the establishment. 
    Sexual encounter establishment means a business or commercial establishment which, as one of its primary business purposes, offers, for any form of consideration, a place where two or more persons may congregate, associate or consort for the purpose of specified sexual activities or the exposure of specified anatomical areas, when one or more of the persons exposes any specified anatomical area. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: human genitals, pubic region, buttocks and female breast below a point above the top of the areola; and 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernable turgid state even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means acts, simulated acts, exhibitions, representations, depictions or descriptions of: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(2)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; 
(3)  Intrusion, however slight, of any object, any part of an animal's body, or any part of a person's body into the genital or anal openings of any person's body or into the body of an animal; 
(4)  Cunnilingus, fellatio, analingus, masturbation, bestiality, lewd exhibition of genitals or excretory function; 
(5)  Flagellation, mutilation or torture for purposes of sexual arousal, gratification or abuse. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-2) 
Sec. 14-398. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of an adult entertainment establishment without having first obtained a license therefor from the city as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-3) 
Sec. 14-399. - Application. 
    An applicant for a license under this article must file with the city clerk an application, provided by the city clerk, which application shall include the following: 
(1)  The legal names, any aliases, residence and current photograph of passport size and quality of each individual applicant, partner, director and holder of ten percent or more of the shares of the corporation. 
(2)  The trade name of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of authority to do business in Colorado, including articles of incorporation, agent for service or process, and trade name affidavit, if any. 
(3)  A written statement from the applicant listing the proposed types of adult entertainment to be offered at the establishment. 
(4)  Whether the applicant, any partners, officers, directors or stockholders holding more than ten percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation have, within ten years from the date of the application, had any adult entertainment establishment license requested or issued from any other governmental entity denied, suspended, revoked or not renewed and if so, the name and address of such establishment and dates and reasons for such denial, suspension, revocation or nonrenewal. 
(5)  If the applicant, any partners, officers, directors or stockholders holding more than ten percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation has, within ten years from the date of the application, ever been convicted or pled guilty or no contest to any specified criminal acts as defined herein and, if so, a complete description of any such offense; including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether the terms of any sentence have been fully completed. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "specified criminal acts" means acts which include sexual crimes against children, sexual abuse, rape, distribution of obscenity, sale, distribution or display of harmful material to a minor, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, aggravated promotion of prostitution, compelling prostitution, sexual performance by a child, possession of child pornography, public lewdness, indecent exposure, indecency with a child, and, as defined by state law, organized criminal activity, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, incest, solicitation of a child, harboring a runaway child, kidnapping, aggravated kidnapping, robbery, aggravated robbery, bribery, felony violation of the Colorado Controlled Substances Act or Dangerous Drugs Act, or tax violations associated with adult entertainment establishments, or crimes involving the use of or trafficking narcotic drugs. 
(6)  A floor plan of the proposed premises. The floor plan shall designate those rooms or other areas of the premises where patrons are not permitted and shall also designate the use of each room or other area of the premises. The floor plan need not be professionally prepared, but must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises. The plan shall designate the place at which the license will be conspicuously posted and the location of any stage. 
(7)  Address of the premises to be licensed. 
(8)  Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct. Each applicant shall have a continuing duty to report, in writing, to the city clerk, any change regarding the information required in this section within 30 days of such change. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-4) 
Sec. 14-400. - Application and license fees. 
(a)  Each applicant shall, at the time of submitting an application, pay a nonrefundable application fee. Additionally, each individual applicant, partner, officer, director or stockholder holding more than ten percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation shall pay a nonrefundable application fee. Such fee shall be reduced for each individual who, at their own expense, provides a current criminal history obtained from the Colorado Bureau of Investigation. All application fees shall be as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(b)  Each applicant shall at the time of submitting an application pay an annual license fee, the amount of which shall be as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. Such fee to be prorated based upon the date of issuance of the license. If a license is not issued, the license fee shall be returned in full to the applicant. 
(c)  No application fee shall be charged on a renewal of an existing license; however, any change in ownership of an adult entertainment establishment shall require submission of a new application, application fee and license. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-5) 
Sec. 14-401. - Investigation; application review. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a properly completed application as determined by the city clerk, the city clerk shall refer the application for investigation to the police department and to the city's building inspector and fire chief who shall inspect the applicant's premises for compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code. The police department, building inspector and fire chief shall furnish the results of their investigations and inspections to the city manager. The city manager shall, within 30 days from the city clerk's receipt of a completed application, either grant the license or inform the applicant in writing that there is probable cause to believe that one or more of the grounds for denial as set forth in subsection (b) of this section exist and that the matter shall be set for a public hearing before the city council. Such hearing shall be held within 20 days of the city manager's notice to the applicant. The hearing shall be held in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 14-404(c). 
(b)  The city council may deny an application where, after a public hearing, it finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the applicant provided false statements on the application; or failed to provide information reasonably necessary for the issuance of a license; or the applicant's premises and use are not in compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code; or a corporate applicant is not in good standing with the state; or where, because of an applicant's or any partner's, officer's, director's or stockholder's of more than ten percent of the outstanding shares of a corporation conviction of a specified criminal act as defined in section 14-399, or revocation, suspension, denial or nonrenewal of an adult entertainment license, specified criminal offense would result from the issuance of a license. 
(c)  If an application is denied, the applicant shall be notified of such in writing by the city manager within ten days of the public hearing. The notice shall specify the grounds for denial and the city council's findings regarding the same. The city council's decision may be appealed as provided in Rule 106(A)(4) of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure (C.R.C.P.). 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-6) 
Sec. 14-402. - Transfer. 
    No license issued in accordance with this article may be transferred or assigned. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-7) 
Sec. 14-403. - Posting of license. 
    Each license issued in accordance with this article shall be posted on the licensed premises in a conspicuous location open to public view. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-8) 
Sec. 14-404. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  The city council shall suspend an adult entertainment license for a period not to exceed six months or may revoke a license if the city council, after a public hearing, finds that a licensee or a licensee's employees have violated or are not in compliance with any provision of this article, refused to allow an inspection of the premises as authorized by this article or knowingly permitted an unlawful act upon the licensed premises. 
(b)  The city council shall revoke an adult entertainment license if the city council, after a public hearing, finds the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months, or the licensee has provided false information in the application process, or where a licensee or employee has knowingly allowed the possession, use or sale of controlled substances as defined in part 3 of C.R.S. § 12-22-301 et seq., as the same may be amended from time to time, on the licensed premises, prostitution on the licensed premises, operated an adult entertainment establishment when such establishment's license was suspended or allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation or other sexual conduct to occur on the licensed premises. 
(c)  Public hearings, as set forth in this article, shall be conducted in compliance with due process requirements, including, without limitation, written notice of charges, violations, hearing dates and decisions, issuance of subpoenas and oaths by the city clerk, representation of the applicant or licensee by legal counsel if so desired, presentation of evidence and witnesses, examination and cross examination of evidence and witnesses, presentation of rebuttal evidence or testimony and preservation of the hearing by recording or written transcript. 
(d)  The city shall have the burden of showing sufficient cause to suspend or revoke an adult entertainment license by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(e)  Public hearings, as provided for in subsection (c) of this section, shall be held within 20 days after notice of same to the licensee. The city manager shall notify the licensee in writing of the city council's decision within ten days after the hearing. If a license is suspended or revoked, then the notice shall specify the grounds for suspension or revocation, the city council's findings regarding the same and the effective dates for such suspension or revocation. The city council's decision may be appealed as provided in Rule 106(A)(4) C.R.C.P. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-9) 
Sec. 14-405. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-20, § 1, adopted January 2, 2018, repealed § 14-405, which pertained to manager and employees license required and derived from the Code of 1985, § 12-12-10. 
Sec. 14-406. - Minimum age requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to be upon the premises of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-11(A)) 
Sec. 14-407. - Hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any adult cabaret, adult theater or sexual encounter establishment to offer live performances after 4:00 a.m. and before 7:00 a.m. each calendar day. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-12; Ord. No. 17-04, § 1, 4-18-2017) 
Sec. 14-408. - Lighting requirements. 
(a)  All off-street parking areas and premises entries of adult entertainment establishments shall be illuminated from dusk to closing hours of operation with a lighting system which provides an average maintained horizontal illumination of four footcandles of light on the parking surface and/or walkways. 
(b)  The premises of all adult entertainment establishments, except adult motion picture theaters, shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access and to provide an illumination of not less than two footcandles of light as measured at the floor level. 
(c)  Adult motion picture theaters and adult arcades shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access and to provide an illumination of not less than one footcandle of light as measured at the floor level. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-13) 
Sec. 14-409. - Standards of conduct; live performances or performers. 
    All employees or performers of adult entertainment establishments which offer, conduct or maintain live adult entertainment shall adhere to the following standards of conduct: 
(1)  No employee or performer shall mingle with patrons or serve food or drinks while nude. 
(2)  No employee or performer shall encourage or knowingly permit any person upon the premises to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals of any other person. 
(3)  No employee or performer shall perform any obscene acts which simulate specified sexual activities. 
(4)  No live adult entertainment performance shall be visible anywhere outside of the licensed establishment. 
(5)  All performances shall take place upon a stage which shall be fixed and immovable. No audience seating shall be permitted within three feet of any edge of the stage. No audience member shall be permitted upon the stage or within three feet of any edge of the stage. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-14) 
Sec. 14-410. - Requirements regarding interior doors; display of materials; manager stations; booths; accessibility of materials to underage persons. 
(a)  All interior doors of any adult entertainment establishment, except restrooms, which provide access to any public area, shall remain unlocked at all times during which patrons are upon the premises. 
(b)  Adult bookstores and adult video stores shall display all adult materials so that they cannot be seen, or are not accessible to any person other than patrons who have entered the licensed premises. 
(c)  In addition to all other requirements of this article, adult arcades shall comply with the following: 
(1)  There shall be a manager's station(s) located within the premises from which there shall be an unobstructed line of sight to each booth, room or cubicle, except restrooms, upon or within which patrons are permitted access. Restrooms shall not contain video display equipment. The line of sight shall remain unobstructed at all times when patrons are upon the premises. At least one employee shall be on duty and situated at each manager's station at all times when patrons are upon the premises. 
(2)  All booths shall be accessible to and from public areas and any door, screen, or covering which prevents an unobstructed view into such booth from public areas or a manager's station shall be prohibited. 
(3)  All booths must be separated from other viewing booths by a solid, uninterrupted physical divider that is a minimum of one-quarter inch thick and prevents any physical contact between occupants of any booth. 
(4)  No booth may be occupied by more than one person at any time. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any adult bookstore or adult video store to allow adult material to be visible or accessible to any person under 18 years of age. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-15) 
Sec. 14-411. - Right of entry. 
    The application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall constitute consent of the licensee and such licensee's agents or employees to permit the city police department or any other agent of the city to conduct routine inspections of the adult entertainment establishment during the hours the establishment is open for business. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-16) 
Sec. 14-412. - Exemptions. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article if a person appearing nude did so in a modeling class operated: 
(1)  By a state-licensed school, licensed by the State of Colorado; a college, junior college or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
(2)  By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(3)  In a structure: 
a.  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; 
b.  Where, in order to participate in a class, a student must enroll at least three days in advance of that class; and 
c.  Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time. 
(Code 1985, § 12-12-17) 
Secs. 14-413-14-437. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PAWNBROKERS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, C.R.S. § 12-56-101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-438. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contract for purchase means a contract entered into between a pawnbroker and a customer pursuant to which money is advanced to the customer by the pawnbroker on the delivery of tangible personal property by the customer, on the condition that the customer, for a fixed period of time, not less than 30 days, has the option to cancel said contract. 
    Fixed price means the amount agreed upon to cancel a contract for purchase during the option period. Said fixed price shall not exceed one-fifth of the original purchase price each month, plus the original purchase price. 
    Fixed time means that period of time, not less than 30 days, as set forth in a contract for purchase, for an option to cancel said contract. 
    Manager means any person other than a licensee who is employed by a pawnbroker to act as a manager or supervisor of the employees, finances, customers or is otherwise responsible for the operation of the business. 
    Option means the fixed time and the fixed price agreed upon by the customer and the pawnbroker in which a contract for purchase may be, but does not have to be, rescinded by the customer. 
    Pawnbroker means a person regularly engaged in the business of making contracts for purchase or purchase transactions in the course of business. 
    Pawnbroking means the business of a pawnbroker. 
    Purchase transaction means the purchase by a pawnbroker in the course of his business of tangible personal property for resale, other than newly manufactured tangible personal property which has not previously been sold at retail, when such purchase does not constitute a contract for purchase. 
    Tangible personal property means all personal property other than choses in action, securities, or printed evidences of indebtedness, which property is deposited with or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in the course of business in connection with a contract for purchase or purchase transaction. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-1) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, C.R.S. § 12-56-101. 
Sec. 14-439. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate as a pawnbroker without having obtained a license issued by the city as provided in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-2) 
Sec. 14-440. - Application requirements; bond/fee. 
(a)  A license application shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk and containing information which includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of each individual applicant, partner, or if a corporate applicant, each officer, director and holder of ten percent or more of corporate stock, each of whom shall be photographed and fingerprinted by the city's police department; 
(2)  Proof, to the city's satisfaction, that the proposed business is in compliance with all applicable city building and zoning requirements and that the applicant has lawful possession of the proposed pawnbroking establishment; 
(3)  A current financial statement and consent to release financial information, such financial statement and information shall be deemed confidential and accessible only to the city manager or the administrator's designee; 
(4)  Each corporate applicant shall provide proof that it is in good standing and licensed to do business in the state; and 
(5)  Proof to the city's satisfaction that the applicant has adequate fire and property damage insurance. 
(b)  If the applicant is an individual, that person must sign the license application. If the applicant is other than an individual, every person who has a ten percent or greater interest in the business must sign the license application. If the applicant is a corporation, every person owning ten percent or more of the outstanding shares of any class of stock, all officers, and all directors of the corporation must sign the license application. If the applicant is a limited liability company, every member holding a ten percent or greater interest in the company and every manager must sign the license application. 
(c)  Each applicant shall furnish a cash or surety bond, as approved by the city, in the amount of $10,000.00. Such bond shall be conditioned upon the applicant's compliance with all requirements set forth in this article and upon the safekeeping and return of all tangible personal property. 
(d)  Upon submission of an application, an applicant shall pay to the city clerk a nonrefundable application fee as set by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-3) 
Sec. 14-441. - License issuance/denial; fee. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application as determined by the police department, the police department shall conduct an investigation of the background, experience, moral character and financial responsibility of each individual applicant, all partners and if a corporation, all officers, director and holders of ten percent or more of corporate stock. A license shall be issued unless the city clerk determines that the issuance of a license would be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare for reasons to include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  An applicant is overdue in payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines or penalties assessed against the applicant or imposed upon the applicant in relation to a pawnbroking establishment; 
(2)  An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form; 
(3)  An applicant has had prior pawnbroking licenses in other jurisdictions suspended, revoked or not renewed; 
(4)  A finding that an individual applicant, partner, or if a corporate applicant, any director, officer or holder of ten percent or more of corporate stock or any pawnbroker establishment manager: 
a.  Is or has violated any of the requirements of this article; or 
b.  Has been convicted of a felony or any offense including moral turpitude including, but not limited to, theft, fraud, robbery, burglary, larceny or deceit. 
(b)  A license, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the licensee, the expiration date, and the business address. The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the pawnbroking establishment's entrance so that it may be easily read at any time. 
(c)  The city clerk shall decide whether to accept or deny any application no later than 30 calendar days after the city clerk has received all required forms, documents and items required of the applicant and the results of the police department's investigation. 
(d)  If an application is denied, the city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing, setting forth the reasons for denial. An applicant may appeal the city clerk's decision to the city manager by request in writing a hearing before the city manager within ten calendar days of the date of the city clerk's decision. Such hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the standards of due process applicable to administrative hearings including, by way of illustration only, the right to representation by legal counsel, and the right to present evidence and confront witnesses. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-4) 
Sec. 14-442. - License fee/renewal. 
(a)  Holders of a pawnbroker's license shall pay an annual fee as set forth in section 14-43. 
(b)  Each license shall expire at the end of the calendar year in which it is issued and may be renewed only by submitting and obtaining approval of an application as provided in section 14-43(c) and payment of a renewal fee as set forth in section 14-43(c). Licensees seeking renewal of an existing license shall not be required to pay the application fee set forth in section 14-43(c). 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-5) 
Sec. 14-443. - Manager registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be employed as a manager of a pawnbroker establishment without first registering with the city clerk. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-6) 
Sec. 14-444. - Inspection. 
(a)  The licensee shall permit the city to inspect the premises for the purpose of ensuring compliance with all applicable requirements of this Code. 
(b)  The city shall conduct such inspections in a reasonable manner and only as frequently as may be reasonably necessary. 
(c)  Inspections shall take place during the regular business hours or when any person is on the premises. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the licensee to refuse to permit such lawful inspection of the premises as provided in this article. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" includes the holder of the license and his agents, officers, employees, servants and managers. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-7) 
Sec. 14-445. - Suspension; revocation. 
    Any suspension or revocation of a pawnbroker license shall be in accordance with article II, division 3 of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-8) 
Sec. 14-446. - Ownership notification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to report to the city clerk within 14 days of such event any change of owner, partner or if a corporate licensee, any officer, director or holder of ten percent or more of corporate stock. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-9) 
Sec. 14-447. - Transfer. 
    No license issued hereunder shall be transferred or assigned in any manner. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-10) 
Sec. 14-448. - Required acts of licensees. 
(a)  A licensee shall keep a numerical register, either manually or electronically, in which shall be recorded the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and date of birth of each customer; 
(2)  The customer's driver's license number or the identification number from any other form of identification which is allowed for the sale of valuable articles pursuant to C.R.S. § 18-16-103, as amended, or for secondhand property pursuant to C.R.S. § 18-13-114S., as amended; 
(3)  The date, time and place of each contract for purchase or purchase transaction; 
(4)  An accurate and detailed account and description of each item of tangible personal property, including, but not limited to, any trademark, identification number, serial number, model number, brand name, or other identifying marks on such property; and 
(5)  The licensee shall also obtain a written declaration of the customer's ownership which shall state that each piece of the tangible personal property is totally owned by the customer, or shall have attached to such declaration a power of sale from the partial owner to the customer, how long the customer has owned each piece of property, whether the customer or someone else found the property, and if the property was found, the details of the finding. 
(b)  If the contract for purchase or other purchase transaction involves more than one item, each item shall be recorded on the licensee's register and on the customer's declaration of ownership. 
(c)  Each customer shall sign his or her name in such register or other tangible or electronic record and on the declaration of ownership and receive a copy of the contract of purchase or a receipt for the purchase transaction. 
(d)  Such register or other tangible or electronic record as well as the contract for purchase or a receipt of the purchase transaction shall be made available to any representative of the police department for inspection at any reasonable time. 
(e)  The licensee shall keep each register for at least three years after the date of the last transaction entered in the register. 
(f)  A licensee shall hold all contracted goods within his or her possession for a period of ten calendar days following the maturity date of the contract of purchase, during which time such goods shall be held separate and apart from any other tangible personal property, and shall not be changed or altered in any way. 
(g)  A licensee shall hold all property purchased by him or her through a purchase transaction for 30 calendar days following the date of purchase, during which time such property shall be held separate and apart from any other tangible personal property, and shall not be changed or altered in any way. 
(h)  Every licensee shall provide the police department, on a weekly basis, with two copies of the records, on a form to be provided or approved by the police department, of all tangible personal property accepted during the preceding week and one copy of the customer's declaration of ownership. The form shall contain all information required to be recorded in the register or other tangible or electronic record pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. The police department shall designate the day of the week on which the records and declarations shall be submitted. 
(i)  The licensee shall pay the city a fee for every transaction form. The amount of the fee shall be as established by the city council on an annual basis in accordance with section 1-16. It is the intent of this subsection to encourage licensees to identify and/or develop measures to reduce the amount of time or expense incurred by the city in processing required information. 
(j)  Every licensee shall, at his or her expense, keep records or provide reports in such manner and by such methods as may be determined from time to time by the city. 
(k)  The licensee shall accept intermediate payments, without penalty, upon contracts of purchase which have not yet matured when presented with the pawn ticket, and shall treat the amount tendered as a payment upon the existing contract for purchase. A receipt showing the date of the payment and the amount shall be given to the customer for all monies received on account of or in payment of loans made under a contract for purchase. The total amount of monies presented shall be applied against the amount of indebtedness. In no event shall late charges, collection fees or other such service charges be deducted from the amount of the payment tendered to the licensee. 
(l)  If a customer fails or neglects to redeem such property upon the maturity of the contract for purchase by repayment of the balance of the principal and payment of all accrued interest charges, the licensee shall immediately, upon maturity of the contract for purchase, mail with sufficient postage a notice of the impending sale of the property delivered under the contract. Such notice shall be mailed to the customer at the address shown on the contract for purchase pertaining to the transaction. Ten days shall be allowed from the date of the mailing of the notification for the customer to appear and reclaim the property or make satisfactory payment upon it. The licensee shall not sell or otherwise dispose of the property prior to the expiration of the ten-day period. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-11) 
State Law reference- Required acts, C.R.S. § 12-56-103. 
Sec. 14-449. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No licensee shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction with any person under the age of 18 years or with any visibly intoxicated person. 
(b)  No licensee shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction with any person known to the licensee to be convicted of larceny or burglary, without first notifying the city police department. Such notice shall not be deemed as authorization by the city of the licensee to enter into any contract with such person. 
(c)  No licensee shall permit any customer to become obligated on the same day in any way under more than one contract for purchase agreement which would result in the licensee obtaining a greater amount of money than would be permitted if the licensee and customer had entered into only one contract or purchase covering the same tangible personal property. 
(d)  No licensee shall violate the terms of the contract for purchase. 
(e)  No licensee shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction for any tangible personal property wherein the identification number, serial number, model number, brand name, owner's identification number or other identifying marks on such property have been totally or partially obscured. 
(f)  No licensee shall enter into a contract for purchase or purchase transaction when the property which is the subject of the contract for purchase or purchase transaction is other than tangible property. 
(g)  No licensee shall ask, demand or receive any greater rate of interest, commission and compensation than the total rate of one-tenth of the original purchase price for each month, plus the original purchase price, on amounts of $50.00 or over, or one-fifth of the original purchase price for each month, plus the original purchase price on amounts under $50.00. No other charges shall be made by the licensee upon renewal of any contract for purchase or at any other time. In the event any such charges are made, the contract shall be void. Any contract for the payment of commissions by the customer for making a contract for purchase of tangible personal property shall be null and void. 
(h)  No licensee shall engage in a purchase transaction or shall enter into a contract for purchase transaction with any customer without securing one of the following kinds of then current and valid identification: 
(1)  A valid state driver's license; 
(2)  Identification card issued in accordance with C.R.S. § 42-2-402, as amended, which is an identification card issued by the state; 
(3)  A valid driver's license containing a picture, issued by another state; 
(4)  A military identification card; 
(5)  A valid passport; 
(6)  An alien registration card; or 
(7)  A nonpicture identification document issued by a state or federal government entity, if the pawnbroker also obtains a clear imprint of the customer's right index finger. 
(i)  For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" includes the holder of the license and such persons, agents, officers, employees, servants and managers. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-12) 
State Law reference- Prohibited acts, C.R.S. § 12-56-104. 
Sec. 14-450. - Hold orders and surrender of property. 
(a)  Any officer of the police department may order a licensee to hold any tangible personal property deposited with or in the custody of any pawnbroker for purposes of further investigation. A hold order shall be effective upon verbal notification to the licensee by a police officer. No sale or other disposition may be made of such property held by any licensee while the hold order remains in effect. A hold order shall supersede all other provisions of this section and any sale or other disposition of the property after notification by a police officer of a hold order shall be unlawful. 
(b)  If any police officer determines that any article of personal property held by a licensee is stolen or illegally obtained property, such officer may immediately confiscate such property and shall provide the pawnbroker with a receipt and case report number. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" includes the holder of the license and such persons, agents, officers, employees, servants and managers. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-13) 
Sec. 14-451. - Liability of licensee. 
(a)  Any licensee who accepts any article in a purchase or contract for purchase transaction from a customer who is not the owner thereof obtains no title in the article either by reason of the expiration of the contract or by transfer of the receipt to the pawnbroker by the customer or holder thereof. Ignorance of the fact that the article was lost or stolen shall not be construed to affect the issue of title. If the licensee shall sell such article to a third person, the licensee shall recover the article or reimburse the fair market value of the article. The lawful owner may, upon proof of his or her ownership of the article lost or stolen, claim the same from the licensee or recover the same by the appropriate legal means including, without limitation, forfeiture of the fair market value of such article out of the bond required by section 14-440(c). 
(b)  A licensee shall be liable for the loss of tangible personal property or part thereof or for damage thereto, whether caused by fire, theft, burglary, or otherwise, resulting from his failure to exercise reasonable care. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-14) 
Sec. 14-452. - Hours of pawnbrokers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroking establishment to operate after 10:00 p.m. and before 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1985, § 12-13-15) 
Secs. 14-453-14-472. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - DANCEHALLS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Dancehalls, C.R.S. § 12-18-101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-473. - Legislative declaration. 
    The city council hereby finds and declares that the operation of dancehalls within the city requires regulation. Such businesses customarily attract large numbers of patrons at late hours, many of whom have been consuming alcoholic beverages. As a result, such businesses generate a disproportionate number of police calls, create traffic, noise and parking problems, negatively impact nearby businesses and residences and generally require increased levels of city services. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-1) 
Sec. 14-474. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dancehall means any commercial premises open to public dancing on a regular or continuing basis or to which the public is admitted upon payment of an admission fee or charge of any kind, and which is not licensed for the sale of fermented malt beverages or malt, vinous or spirituous liquors. Dancehall does not include commercial dance studios where dance instruction is given on a regular and continuing basis. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-2) 
Sec. 14-475. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any dancehall without first obtaining a license and paying all fees as required by this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-3) 
Sec. 14-476. - License application. 
(a)  The applicant for a license shall submit a verified application to the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. The application shall include, for example, complete plans and specifications for the interior of the premises to be licensed, a copy of the lease or other evidence of the applicant's right to possession of the premises, information regarding the zoning for the location of the premises, and the fee required by this article. 
(b)  Within ten days of receipt of an application, the city clerk shall, if the application is complete, schedule a hearing before the city council. Such hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days of the city clerk's determination that an application is complete. The city clerk shall also refer the application for investigation to the police department and to the city's building inspector and fire chief who shall inspect the applicant's premises for compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code. The police department, building inspector and fire chief shall furnish the results of their investigations and inspections to the city clerk. 
(c)  Notice of such hearing shall be mailed by the city clerk to the applicant not less than ten days before the hearing date. Notice of such hearing shall also be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the community once, not less than ten days prior to the hearing date and by posting a notice of the hearing upon the premises for at least ten days prior to the hearing. Publication and posting shall be done by the city clerk. 
(d)  Within ten days after the public hearing, the city council shall either grant or deny the license and in granting a license, city council may, based upon evidence presented at the hearing, impose reasonable conditions upon the license. 
(e)  In determining whether to grant or deny the license, the city council shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  The applicant's prior experience and qualifications to operate such a business; 
(2)  The desires of the citizens regarding such a facility, including any petitions or remonstrances evidencing such desires; 
(3)  Pedestrian safety; 
(4)  Traffic volume and adequacy of parking and access; 
(5)  Essential character of the neighborhood and the applicant's effect on the peace of the neighborhood; 
(6)  Compliance of the structure with all applicable zoning and building regulations; 
(7)  Police activity in comparable businesses; 
(8)  Architectural compatibility with the character of the neighborhood. 
(f)  If a license is denied, the city council shall, within seven days of its decision, provide written notice to the applicant, which notice shall specify the grounds for denial. 
(g)  Decisions of the city council are final subject only to appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-4) 
Sec. 14-477. - Fees. 
(a)  All applications must include a nonrefundable fee to defray the cost of reviewing and evaluating the application. 
(b)  The annual renewal fee must be paid in full at the time of filing an application for renewal. 
(c)  All fees shall be as established by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-5) 
Sec. 14-478. - Renewal. 
(a)  Dancehall licenses shall expire one year from the date of issuance unless canceled, suspended or revoked, and may be renewed annually upon application, payment of all fees and, if necessary, a public hearing before the city council. 
(b)  A license renewal may be denied after a hearing by the city council in accordance with the grounds and procedure set forth in section 14-479 or upon changed circumstances of the factors originally considered in section 14-476(e). 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-6) 
Sec. 14-479. - License denial, suspension, revocation. 
(a)  The city council may, after notice and a public hearing, deny renewal, or suspend or revoke any license upon finding any of the following: 
(1)  That repeated disturbances of the public peace have occurred within the licensed establishment or upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds adjacent to or used by patrons of the licensed premises involving patrons, employees, or the licensee. For the purpose of this article, the term "repeated disturbances" shall mean more than one report to the police department within any two-month time period. 
(2)  That the licensee or any employee thereof is offering for sale, or allowing to be consumed upon the licensed premises, or upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds immediately adjacent to the licensed premises, illegal drugs. 
(3)  That the licensee or a responsible manager is not on the premises at all times that the dance hall is open to the public. 
(4)  That vinous, spirituous or fermented malt beverages are being consumed on the premises with or without the consent of the licensee by patrons of the establishment or where such beverages are being consumed by patrons of the establishment upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds immediately adjacent to the establishment. 
(5)  That the dancehall is being maintained in such a way as to violate any building code, or zoning or public health requirement imposed by the city, county or state ordinance, law or regulation. 
(6)  That any provision of this article has been violated by the licensee or any of its employees or agents. 
(b)  Notice of such hearing shall be mailed by the city clerk to the applicant not less than ten days before the hearing date. Notice of such hearing shall also be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the community once, not less than ten days prior to the hearing date and by posting a notice of the hearing upon the premises for at least ten days prior to the hearing. Publication and posting shall be done by the city clerk. 
(c)  The city manager may summarily suspend a license for not more than 30 days when the city manager deems such is necessary for the immediate protection of the public health, safety and welfare. A public hearing as provided herein for renewal, suspension or revocation shall be scheduled as soon as reasonably possible. 
(d)  The city council shall, within ten days of the public hearing, issue its decision regarding the license's nonrenewal, suspension or revocation. A copy of such decision setting forth the grounds for or conditions of a license's nonrenewal, suspension or revocation shall be provided to the licensee within five days of the city council's decision. 
(e)  Decisions of the city council are final, subject only to appeal in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-7) 
Sec. 14-480. - Change in nature of business. 
(a)  At least 30 days prior to the commencement of expansion, remodeling, or other change in the nature of the licensed business, the licensee shall submit an application for a change in the nature of the business to the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. The application shall be reviewed by the city manager who, within ten days, shall determine whether the proposed change in the nature of the business is significant. For purposes of this subsection, the term "significant change" shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  An increase or decrease in the total size or capacity of the licensed premises; 
(2)  The sealing off, creation of or relocation of a common entryway, doorway, or passage or other means of public ingress or egress; and 
(3)  Any material change in the interior of the premises that would affect the basic character of the premises or the physical structure that existed in the plan on file with the latest prior application. 
The term does not include painting and redecorating of premises; the installation or replacement of electric fixtures or equipment, plumbing, refrigeration, air conditioning or heating fixtures and equipment; the lowering of ceilings; the installation and replacement of floor coverings; the replacement of furniture and equipment, and other similar changes. 
(b)  After investigation, the city manager may approve the proposed change or, in the manager's sole discretion, recommend to the city council that a public hearing be held regarding the proposed change, at which parties in interest may be heard. Posting, publication and notice requirements shall be the same as are required for a hearing on an original application. Criteria for approval shall be as for an original application. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-8) 
Sec. 14-481. - Management and supervision. 
    Each licensee shall individually manage such premises or employ a manager on the premises of at least 21 years of age, and such licensee or manager shall be present and responsible for the premises during all hours of operation. The licensee shall report the name of the manager to the city clerk and shall report any change in managers within ten days after the change. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-9) 
Sec. 14-482. - Occupancy limits. 
    The occupancy capacity of the premises shall be determined according to the requirements of the applicable city code. There shall be posted on the premises in a place open to the view of the occupants thereof a sign stating the maximum number of occupants permitted at any one time. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-10) 
Sec. 14-483. - Hours of operation. 
    Premises licensed hereunder shall open to the public no earlier than 7:00 a.m. and close no later than 2:00 a.m. daily. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-11) 
Sec. 14-484. - Transfer. 
    No license issued in accordance with this article may be transferred or assigned. 
(Code 1985, § 12-15-12) 
Secs. 14-485-14-506. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - POOL HALLS 

Sec. 14-507. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pool hall means any commercial premises open regularly to the public upon which are located four or more tables or devices where patrons may, for consideration, engage in pool, billiards, snooker or other like games. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-1) 
Sec. 14-508. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any pool hall without first obtaining a license and paying all fees as required by this article. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-2) 
Sec. 14-509. - License application. 
(a)  The applicant for a license shall submit a verified application to the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. The application shall include, for example, complete plans and specifications for the interior of the premises to be licensed, a copy of the lease or other evidence of the applicant's right to possession of the premises, information regarding the zoning for the location of the premises, and the fee required by this article. 
(b)  Within ten days of receipt of an application, the city clerk shall, if the application is complete, schedule a hearing before the city council. Such hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days of the city clerk's determination that an application is complete. The city clerk shall also refer the inspector and fire chief shall furnish the results of their investigations and inspections to the city clerk. 
(c)  Notice of such hearing shall be mailed by the city clerk to the applicant not less than ten days before the hearing date. Notice of such application for investigation shall be sent to the police department and to the city's building inspector and fire chief who shall inspect the applicant's premises for compliance with the applicable provisions of this article. The police department building hearing shall also be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the community once, not less than ten days prior to the hearing date and by posting a notice of the hearing upon the premises for at least ten days prior to the hearing. Publication and posting shall be done by the city clerk. 
(d)  Within ten days after the public hearing, the city council shall either grant or deny the license and in granting a license, city council may, based upon evidence presented at the hearing, impose reasonable conditions upon the license. 
(e)  In determining whether to grant or deny the license, the city council shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  The applicant's prior experience and qualifications to operate such a business; 
(2)  The desires of the citizens regarding such a facility, including any petitions or remonstrances evidencing such desires; 
(3)  Pedestrian safety; 
(4)  Traffic volume and adequacy of parking and access; 
(5)  Essential character of the neighborhood and the applicant's effect on the peace of the neighborhood; 
(6)  Compliance of the structure with all applicable zoning and building regulations; 
(7)  Police activity in comparable businesses; 
(8)  Architectural compatibility with the character of the neighborhood. 
(f)  If a license is denied, the city council shall, within seven days of its decision, provide written notice to the applicant, which notice shall specify the grounds for denial. 
(g)  Decisions of the city council are final subject only to appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-3) 
Sec. 14-510. - Fees. 
(a)  All applications must include a nonrefundable fee to defray the cost of reviewing and evaluating the application. 
(b)  The annual renewal fee must be paid in full at the time of filing an application for renewal. 
(c)  All fees shall be as established by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-4) 
Sec. 14-511. - Renewal. 
(a)  Pool hall licenses shall expire one year from the date of issuance unless canceled, suspended or revoked, and may be renewed annually upon application, payment of all fees and, if necessary, a public hearing before the city council. 
(b)  A license renewal may be denied after a hearing by the city council in accordance with the grounds and procedure set forth in section 14-478 or upon changed circumstances of the factors originally considered in section 14-476(e). 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-5) 
Sec. 14-512. - License denial, suspension, revocation. 
(a)  The city council may, after notice and a public hearing, deny renewal, or suspend or revoke any license upon finding any of the following: 
(1)  That repeated disturbances of the public peace have occurred within the licensed establishment or upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds adjacent to or used by patrons of the licensed premises involving patrons, employees, or the licensee. For the purpose of this article, the term "repeated disturbances" shall mean more than one report to the police department within any two-month time period. 
(2)  That the licensee or any employee thereof is offering for sale, or allowing to be consumed upon the licensed premises, or upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds immediately adjacent to the licensed premises, illegal drugs. 
(3)  That the licensee or a responsible manager is not on the premises at all times that the pool hall is open to the public. 
(4)  That in establishments without a liquor license vinous, spirituous or fermented malt beverages are being consumed on the premises with or without the consent of the licensee by patrons of the establishment. 
(5)  That vinous, spirituous or fermented malt beverages are being consumed by patrons of the establishment upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, accessways or grounds immediately adjacent to the establishment. 
(6)  That the pool hall is being maintained in such a way as to violate any building code, or zoning or public health requirement imposed by the city, county or state ordinance, law or regulation. 
(7)  That any provision of this article has been violated by the licensee or any of its employees, officers or agents. 
(b)  Notice of such hearing shall be mailed by the city clerk to the applicant not less than ten days before the hearing date. Notice of such hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the community once, not less than ten days prior to the hearing date and by posting a notice of the hearing upon the premises for at least ten days prior to the hearing. Publication and posting shall be done by the city clerk. 
(c)  The city manager may summarily suspend a license for not more than 30 days when the city manager deems such is necessary for the immediate protection of the public health, safety and welfare. A public hearing as provided herein for renewal, suspension or revocation shall be scheduled as soon as reasonably possible. 
(d)  The city council shall, within ten days of the public hearing, issue its decision regarding the license's nonrenewal, suspension or revocation. A copy of such decision setting forth the grounds for or conditions of a license's nonrenewal, suspension or revocation shall be provided to the licensee within five days of the city council's decision. 
(e)  Decisions of the city council are final, subject only to appeal in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-6) 
Sec. 14-513. - Change in nature of business. 
(a)  At least 30 days prior to the commencement of expansion, remodeling, or other change in the nature of the licensed business, the licensee shall submit an application for a change in the nature of the business to the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. The application shall be reviewed by the city manager who within ten days shall determine whether the proposed change in the nature of the business is significant. For purposes of this subsection, the term "significant change" shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  An increase or decrease in the total size or capacity of the licensed premises; 
(2)  The sealing off, creation of or relocation of a common entryway, doorway, or passage or other means of public ingress or egress; and 
(3)  Any material change in the interior of the premises that would affect the basic character of the premises or the physical structure that existed in the plan on file with the latest prior application. The term does not include painting and redecorating of premises; the installation or replacement of electric fixtures or equipment, plumbing, refrigeration, air conditioning or heating fixtures and equipment; the lowering of ceilings; the installation and replacement of floor coverings; the replacement of furniture and equipment, and other similar changes. 
(b)  After investigation, the city manager may approve the proposed change or, in the manager's sole discretion, recommend to the city council that a public hearing be held regarding the proposed change, at which parties in interest may be heard. Posting, publication and notice requirements shall be the same as are required for a hearing on an original application. Criteria for approval shall be as for an original application. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-7) 
Sec. 14-514. - Management and supervision. 
    Each licensee shall individually manage such premises or employ a manager on the premises of at least 21 years of age, and such licensee or manager shall be present and responsible for the premises during all hours of operation. The licensee shall report the name of the manager to the city clerk and shall report any change in managers within ten days after the change. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-8) 
Sec. 14-515. - Occupancy limits. 
    The occupancy capacity of the premises shall be determined according to the requirements of the applicable city code. There shall be posted on the premises in a place open to the view of the occupants thereof a sign stating the maximum number of occupants permitted at any one time. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-9) 
Sec. 14-516. - Transfer. 
    No license issued in accordance with this article may be transferred or assigned. 
(Code 1985, § 12-16-10) 
Secs. 14-517-14-540. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - RESERVED[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, adopted April 17, 2018, repealed article XV, §§ 14-541-14-563, which pertained to rights-of-way permits and derived from the Code of 1985, §§ 12-17-1-12-17-24. See article II of chapter 46 for similar provisions. 

Secs. 14-541-14-580. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - BUS BENCHES, KIOSKS AND SHELTERS 

Secs. 14-581. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City administrator means the city administrator or the administrator's designee. 
    Kiosk means a free standing structure located upon the city's real property or rights-of-way along a bus route used for the purpose of posting advertisements or notices. 
    Shelter means any structure located upon the city's real property or rights-of-way along a bus route used for the purpose of providing shelter to bus patrons. 
(Code 1985, § 12-14-1) 
Secs. 14-582. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain upon the city's real property or rights-of-way any bench, kiosk or shelter along a bus route without first having obtained a permit for such from the city. 
(Code 1985, § 12-14-2) 
Secs. 14-583. - Permit application. 
    An application for a permit shall be submitted to the city administrator and shall contain information to include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  A non-refundable application fee, the amount of which shall be in accordance with section 1-16; 
(2)  A detailed map showing the proposed location of all benches, kiosks and shelters, including the location of street, curb, gutter, sidewalk, right-of-way limits, property lines and adjacent driveways; 
(3)  Detailed specifications of all proposed benches, kiosks and shelters; 
(4)  Such other information as may be specified by the city administrator. 
(Code 1985, § 12-14-3) 
Secs. 14-584. - Application review. 
(a)  The city administrator shall cause applications to be reviewed by the appropriate staff including, but not limited to, the police, fire and public works departments. Based upon the staff's input, the city administrator shall prepare a recommendation for city council. 
(b)  City council shall review all applications and in determining whether or not to grant an application, shall consider, along with all other relevant factors, the following: 
(1)  The applicant's ability to comply with all the requirements set forth in this article and all other applicable rules, regulations and ordinances of the city; 
(2)  A permit's impact upon pedestrian and vehicular traffic and safety; 
(3)  A permit's impact upon other users of the affected areas, including public utilities or municipal services; 
(4)  Architectural and use compatibility of any bench, kiosk or shelter with the surrounding area. 
(c)  Approval of an application shall be by resolution of city council. Such resolution shall set forth an annual permit fee and other terms and conditions deemed necessary by city council. See section 1-16 annex for actual annual permit fee. 
(Code 1985, § 12-14-4) 
Secs. 14-585. - Permit requirements. 
    In addition to other requirements which city council may specify, each permittee shall adhere to the following: 
(1)  The permittee shall obtain written permission of any affected property owner if the permittee shall encroach upon private property when installing any bench, kiosk or shelter. 
(2)  The permittee shall, within a reasonable period of time, move any bench, kiosk or shelter when requested to do so by the city for accommodating bus route changes or municipal projects affecting the site. 
(3)  The permittee shall be responsible for the regular maintenance of all benches, kiosks and shelters and the surrounding area by: 
a.  As soon as practicable, repairing or replacing any damaged benches, kiosks or shelters; 
b.  Regularly cleaning all benches, kiosks and shelters; 
c.  Regularly picking up all litter and removing all snow within a ten-foot radius of the off street area surrounding all benches, kiosks and shelters. 
(4)  The permittee shall, without any charge to the city, display any public announcements requested by the city. 
(5)  The permittee shall, in a conspicuous place, affix its name, address and the telephone number of its maintenance personnel to all shelters. 
(6)  The permittee shall obtain input from the regional transportation district (RTD) concerning the location of all benches, shelters and kiosks. Additionally, the permittee shall, at all shelters, post in a conspicuous location RTD bus schedule information. 
(7)  If the requested permit necessitates modifications or alterations to existing, or planned, public property or right-of-way improvements or landscaping, the full cost of such modifications or alterations shall be the responsibility of the permittee. The city may require the permittee to install such modifications or alterations, or at the city's option, require that a cash contribution be made by the permittee in an amount equal to the estimated cost of completing the alteration or modification. The installation of improvements or payment of costs and expenses by virtue of this Section shall not confer upon the permittee any rights in excess of those otherwise associated with the granting of such permit. In the event of the non-renewal, termination, cancellation or revocation of a permit, the permittee shall not be entitled to a refund of any cost or expenses expended under the provisions of this subsection. 
(8)  All private sector permittees shall indemnify, defend and save harmless the city, its officers, employees and agents against any and all claims arising from any occurrence occasioned by the permitted use. The permittee shall maintain comprehensive general public liability and property damage insurance with limits equal or exceeding the maximum liability which may be imposed by the Colorado Governmental Immunity Act, Colorado Revised Statutes (C.R.S.) 24-10-101 et seq. The policy shall name the city, its officials, officers, employees and agents as additional insured parties and no other insurance maintained by the city shall be required to contribute to a loss covered by the policy. A certificate of insurance demonstrating compliance with this section shall be given to the city prior to issuance of a permit. 
(9)  All private sector permittees shall provide a performance bond to the city in an amount and form acceptable to the city.
