Section 1204, Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places. 
    Section 1204(8) of the Model Traffic Code is repealed in its entirety and enacted to provide: 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon any private property without the consent of the owner, lessee or person in possession of such property. 
Section 1205, Parking at curb or edge or roadway. 
    Section 1205(2) and (3) are amended by deleting the phrase "by ordinance" in both sections. 
Section 1206, Unattended motor vehicle-Definitions. 
    Section 1206 of the Model Traffic Code to provide as follows: 
(1)  A person driving or in charge of an unlocked motor vehicle shall not permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key from the ignition, and effectively setting the brake thereon. When the vehicle is standing upon any grade, the person shall turn the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway in such a manner as to prevent the vehicle from rolling onto the traveled way. 
(2)  The use or operation of a remote starter system and adequate security measure is sufficient to comply with subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)  As used in this section: 
(a)  "Adequate security measures" includes, but is not limited to: 
1.  Using a vehicle that requires a key to put the vehicle into gear and move the vehicle; 
2.  Keeping a keyless start fob out of proximity of the vehicle; or 
3.  Employing steering wheel security devices. 
(b)  "Remote starter system" means a device installed in a motor vehicle that allows the engine of the vehicle to be started by remote or radio control. 
Section 1209, Owner liability for parking violations. 
    Section 1209 of the Model Traffic Code is amended by the addition of the following: 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any provision of this Part 12 governing the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute an evidentiary prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the location where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
Section 1210, Designated areas on private property for authorized vehicles within unincorporated areas of a county. 
    Section 1210 of the Model Traffic Code is repealed in its entirety. 
Section 1212, Buses and taxicabs regulated. 
    Section 1212 of the Model Traffic Code is enacted to provide: 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street or at any place other than a bus stop so designated by an official sign. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street or at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at bus stop so designated by an official sign, except in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop on a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage, shall be in position with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than 18 inches from the curb and with the bus substantially parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street or at any place other than at a taxicab stand so designated by an official sign. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other parking, standing or stopping regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the loading or unloading of passengers or baggage. 
Section 1213. Immobilization of vehicles. 
    Section 1213 of the Model Traffic Code is enacted to provide: 
(a)  When an operator, owner or person in charge of a vehicle has failed to respond to a summons and complaint for illegal stopping, standing or parking and received all applicable notices as provided herein, officers of the police department and other authorized city employees may for a period up to and including seventy-two (72) hours, immobilize such vehicle by installing on, or attaching to such vehicle, a device designed to restrict the normal movement of such vehicle, and if such vehicle is so immobilized, the city employee or police officer so installing or attaching such device shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice, in writing, on a form provided by the police department, advising the owner, driver or person in charge of such vehicle, that such vehicle has been immobilized by the city for violation of the stopping, standing or parking provisions of this code and that release from such immobilization may be obtained at a designated place; that unless arrangements are made for the release of such vehicle within seventy-two (72) hours, the vehicle will be removed from the streets at the direction of the city employee, or by a police officer, and that removing or attempting to remove the device before a release is obtained as herein provided, or to move any such vehicle before a release is obtained is unlawful, and containing such other information as the police department shall deem necessary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or attempt to remove any such device before a release is obtained as herein provided, or to move any such vehicle before the same is released by the police department, clerk of the municipal court or any municipal judge, and where such vehicle has been properly immobilized in such manner, a fee as established by resolution of city council shall be charged by the police department or clerk of the municipal court before releasing such vehicle, and the parking restrictions, if any, otherwise applicable shall not apply while such vehicle is so immobilized. 
(c)  If a vehicle has remained immobilized for a period of seventy-two (72) hours and release has not been obtained, the police officer or city employee causing such immobilization may have the vehicle impounded. 
(d)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to prohibit the city from immediately removing any vehicle deemed to constitute a traffic hazard, obstruction to emergency vehicle(s) or lawful access to property. 
Section 1305, Open alcoholic beverage container-motor vehicle prohibited. 
    Section 1305 of the Model Traffic Code is enacted to provide: 
(1)  Definitions . As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: 
(a)  "Alcoholic beverage" means a beverage as defined in C.R.S. 12-47-103(2). 
(b)  "Motor vehicle" means a vehicle driven or drawn by mechanical power and manufactured primarily for use on public highways but does not include a vehicle operated exclusively on a rail or rails. 
(c)  "Open alcoholic beverage container" means a bottle, can, or other receptacle that contains any amount of alcoholic beverage, and: 
(I)  That is open or has a broken seal; or 
(II)  The contents of which are partially removed. 
(d)  "Passenger area" means the area designed to seat the driver and passengers while a motor vehicle is in operation and any area that is readily accessible to the driver or a passenger while in his or her seating position, including, but not limited, to the glove compartment. 
(2)  (a)  Except as otherwise permitted in paragraph (b) of this subsection (2), a person while in the passenger area of a motor vehicle that is on a public roadway or highway of this state or the right-of-way of a public roadway or highway of this state may not knowingly: 
(I)  Drink an alcoholic beverage; or 
(II)  Have in his or her possession an open alcoholic beverage container. 
(b)  The provisions of this subsection (2) shall not apply to: 
(I)  Passengers, other than the driver or a front seat passenger, located in the passenger area of a motor vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of persons for compensation; 
(II)  The possession by a passenger, other than the driver or a front seat passenger, of an open alcoholic beverage container in the living quarters of a house coach, house trailer, motor home or trailer coach as defined in Appendices, Definitions, (58) and (114(a)); 
(III)  The possession of an open alcoholic beverage container in the area behind the last upright seat of a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk; or 
(IV)  The possession of an open alcoholic beverage container in an area not normally occupied by the driver or a passenger in a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk. 
Section 1417, Permits required for parades or processions. 
    Section 1417 of the Model Traffic Code is enacted to provide: 
    No funeral procession or parade except that of the armed forces of the United Services, the military forces of this State, and the police and fire departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along any highway or roadway within the city except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police in compliance with such other regulations of this code or requirements of the city which may apply.

    Part 17, Penalties and Procedures, Preface of the Model Traffic Code is deleted in its entirety.

    Section 1701 of the Model Traffic Code is deleted in its entirety. 
Section 1702, Counties traffic offenses classified schedule of fines. 
    Section 1702 of the Model Traffic Code is repealed in its entirety. 
Section 1709, Penalty assessment notice for traffic offense. 
    Section 1709(1) of the Model Traffic Code is amended by inserting the phrase "or code provision" after the phrase "citation of the statute" and by inserting the phrase "or municipal" after the phrase "county court at a specified time." 
Section 1710, Failure to pay penalty for traffic offenses. 
    Section 1710(3) of the Model Traffic Code is amended by adding the phrase "or Rule 248(b) of the Colorado Municipal Court Rules" after the phrase "in section 18-1-405, C.R.S." 
Section 1710, Failure to pay penalty for traffic offenses. 
    Section 1710(5) of the Model Traffic Code is enacted to provide: 
(a)  Upon the date and at the time for appearance, if the defendant fails to appear and if the municipal judge determines that venue is proper and that defendant was served a summons and complaint at least ten (10) calendar days prior to the appearance date, the judge may, for traffic offenses of not more than four (4) points (except for compulsory insurance), or a six (6) point offense of speeding, not more than twenty-four (24) miles over the posted speed limit, enter judgment and impose sentence, including costs against the defendant. 
(b)  Failure to appear on any date scheduled for trial shall constitute cause for entering a default judgment for all traffic offenses of not more than four (4) points (except for compulsory insurance) or a six (6) point offense of speeding not more than twenty-four (24) miles over the posted speed limit, and upon entry of such default, the judge may impose sentence including costs against the defendant. 
(c)  On the grounds of excusable neglect, the judge may by motion of the defendant set aside an entry of default and the judgment entered thereon. Such motion must be filed with the court within seven (7) calendar days of the entry of judgment for such matter. A motion under this section shall not affect the finality of a judgment or suspend its operation. 
(d)  Any default entered in accordance with this section shall be certified to the State Motor Vehicle Division for enforcement. 
(e)  The court shall not issue a warrant for the arrest of any defendant against whom a default is entered and upon which a sentence is imposed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 10-17, § 1, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 17-16, §§ 1-5, 11-21-2017) 
Secs. 58-3-58-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLES IN PROHIBITED PLACES 

Sec. 58-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle means any machine propelled by other than human power which is designed to travel along the ground or through water by use of wheels, treads, runners, slides and to transport persons or property or pull non-self-propelled vehicles or machinery and includes, without limitation, automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, motor scooter, all-terrain vehicle, moped, buggy and wagon. 
(Code 1985, § 5-4-0.5; Ord. No. 04-09, § 1(5-4-0.5), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-22. - Operation of vehicles in prohibited places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in any of the following places without first obtaining the permission or authorization herein required in subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  On any property owned by the city, other than public streets. 
(2)  On any park or recreation property within the city, owned by the city or by any other public entity or agency. 
(3)  On any property owned by a school district or any public school grounds or campus, except a designated parking lot. 
(4)  Motorized vehicles used for authorized maintenance or construction activities on the above-identified properties shall not be subject to the prohibitions set forth in this article. 
(b)  Permission or authorization for exception to the uses prohibited above require application to and written permission from the city manager. 
(Code 1985, § 5-4-1; Ord. No. 04-09, § 4(5-4-1), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-23. - Avoiding traffic control devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any public or private property for the purpose of avoiding a traffic control device. 
(b)  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection (a) of this section upon a showing that: 
(1)  A motor vehicle was operated at or in the vicinity of an official traffic control device as defined by the model traffic code as adopted by the city. 
(2)  The vehicle left the main traveled portion of the roadway at or near such traffic control device. 
(3)  The vehicle subsequently reentered the same or another roadway. 
(4)  No apparent purpose for exiting the roadway existed aside from the purpose to evade the requirement or potential requirement imposed by the existence or operation of said traffic control device. 
(Code § 5-4-2; Ord. No. 04-09, § 4(5-4-2), 8-17-2004) 
Secs. 58-24-58-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING 

Sec. 58-41. - Privately owned parking lots. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to park said vehicle in any privately owned parking lot adjacent to any wholesale or retail place of business, commercial activity or manufacturing plant, except while actually in or upon one or more of the aforesaid wholesale or retail businesses, commercial activities or manufacturing plants adjacent to and for which the parking facility is provided, together with a reasonable time beforehand in which to park said vehicle and afterward in which to return to said vehicle. 
(b)  Owner responsibility. In the event the driver of the vehicle parked in violation of this article cannot be found, it shall be presumed that the registered owner as reflected by the current records of the state department of motor vehicles, was the driver so illegally parking said vehicle and the registered owner shall be charged accordingly. 
(c)  Signs. The provisions of this article shall apply only when a permanent sign not less than two feet square in size and kept illuminated at night, is posted in a conspicuous location at each and every entrance to said privately owned parking area, and in such other locations as the city manager may require, warning trespassing parkers, in lettering not less than two inches in height, that said trespassing parkers are subject to fine or imprisonment. 
(d)  Parking area owner. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or other person in control of the privately owned area to initiate appropriate regulatory procedures to establish whether any vehicle is parked in violation of this article and the period of time for which it has been so parked. 
(Code 1985, § 5-5-1; Ord. No. 04-09, § 5(5-5-1), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-42. - Residential zones. 
(a)  No truck or van with a carrying capacity rated in excess of one ton, nor any truck, tractor, boat, detached camper or camper shell, bus, mobile home, motor home, travel trailer or trailer of any kind shall be stored, kept or parked on any public right-of-way in the R-1, R-2, R-3 or R-5 zoning districts. The prohibition contained herein shall not apply, however, in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Parking for the purpose of loading, unloading, or making routine deliveries. 
(2)  Parking as authorized by a permit issued by the city police department. Such a permit may be issued only for a vehicle that has been issued a for a person with a disability license plate by the state. 
(3)  Parking of motor homes, travel trailers or boats, including a trailer for a boat, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and ending at 8:00 p.m., provided that the movement of traffic is not impeded thereby. 
(b)  No prohibited motor vehicle, other than a motor home or travel trailer shall be stored or parked in the R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or R-5 zone districts or in any area designated for residential use in any city-approved P.U.D. plan unless it is being loaded or unloaded. For purposes of this subsection, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Loaded or unloaded means the continual activity by a person or persons of removing items from or placing items in the vehicle without any lull in such activity, other than what is normal under the circumstances. For example, generally, it would be normal for there to be a single overnight lull in activity in connection with the loading or unloading of a residential moving van or moving truck. 
    Motor home means a self propelled vehicle not more than 400 square feet in total floor area, designed for travel on the highway and having a flush toilet, a bath or shower, sleeping accommodations and kitchen facilities to include a sink, stove and refrigerator or ice box. Total floor area of said travel trailer shall mean the floor area exclusive of all tip-outs, slide outs and hinged extensions. The term "motor home" does not include a manufactured home as defined in chapter 70. 
    Parked means placed or left standing for any period of time. 
    Prohibited motor vehicle means the following: Semitrucks; semitractors; semitrailers; dump trucks with a carrying capacity greater than one ton (see figure 58-42 A); commercial, vehicle hauling trailers; utility trailers with beds over 18 feet in length; tractors; vehicles with three axles or three or more sets of axles (a set of axles shall mean two connected axles) or any combination thereof; construction equipment vehicles such as a backhoe, street grader, front-end loader or other similar vehicle; commercial, nonpassenger vehicles with a gross vehicle weight exceeding 10,000 pounds; trucks constructed or adapted for purposes of transporting or delivering gasoline or petroleum products in bulk and designed to hold 100 or more gallons of gasoline or 100 or more gallons of diesel fuel; and any vehicle with a tractor license plate (identified by the letters TVU along the left margin) or a GVW truck license plate (identified by the letters GVW along the left margin). A pickup truck, regardless of its gross vehicle weight, and regardless of how much gas it is designed to hold, shall not be considered a prohibited motor vehicle for purposes of this chapter. 
Figure 58-42 A. Dump truck 

    Semitrailer means a trailer so designed and used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of its own load rests upon or is carried by such motor vehicle and as shown in figure 58-42 B. 
    Semitruck or semitractor means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing a semitrailer and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn (see figure 58-42 B). 
Figure 58-42 B. Prohibited vehicle types. 

    Storage means parked for a period in excess of five consecutive days. 
    Travel trailer means a trailer not more than 400 square feet in total floor area, designed to be pulled on the highway by an automobile or light truck and having a flush toilet, a bath or shower, sleeping accommodations and kiPtchen facilities to include a sink, stove and refrigerator or ice box. Total floor area of said travel trailer shall mean the floor area exclusive of all tip-outs, slide outs and hinged extensions. The term "travel trailer" does not include a manufactured home as defined in chapter 70. 
    Utility trailer means a trailer so designed for use and typically used in conjunction with a pick-up truck, including but not limited to trailers used by landscapers, horse trailers and trailers used to haul small recreational vehicles such as snow mobiles. 
(Code 1985, § 5-5-2; Ord. No. 06-04, § 1(5-5-2), 9-5-2006; Ord. No. 07-11, §§ 1-3, 9-4-2007) 
State Law reference- License plate for persons with disabilities, C.R.S. § 42-3-204. 
Sec. 58-43. - Commercial zones. 
(a)  No truck, van or trailer in excess of one-ton carrying capacity or truck tractor or bus shall park on any unpaved lot in the C-1 zoning district. 
(b)  No truck, van or trailer in excess of one-ton carrying capacity or truck tractor or bus shall park on any lot in the C-1 zoning district if such lot does not have a curb cut constructed in accordance with city specifications. A combination of curb, gutter and sidewalk is not considered a curb cut. 
(Code 1985, § 5-5-5) 
Sec. 58-44. - External vehicle immobilization device (boot). 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, business or entity of any nature except for the city as authorized by the model traffic code, as adopted by the city, to place any external vehicle immobilization device (boot) upon any motor vehicle located upon any public or private street within the city. 
(Code 1985, § 5-5-6; Ord. No. 04-09, § 5(5-5-6), 8-17-2004) 
Secs. 58-45-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY 

Sec. 58-61. - Emergency vehicle access. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owners or managers of mobile home parks and apartment complexes to fail to keep the sidewalks, streets and parking lots within such locations free of all obstructions of any nature which may or do impair or prohibit the access and passage of emergency vehicles (such as by illustration police, fire, emergency and health care vehicles) upon or over such sidewalks, streets and parking lots. 
(Code 1985, § 5-7-1) 
Sec. 58-62. - Mobile home parks; snow and ice removal. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owners or managers of mobile home parks to allow snow or ice to remain upon the sidewalks or traveled portions of the streets within such parks used by persons or motor vehicles later than 15 hours after accumulation of ice or more than one inch of snow. 
(Code 1985, § 5-7-2) 
Sec. 58-63. - Disabled persons parking areas; snow and ice removal. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owners or managers of property upon which Disabled persons parking spaces are located to allow snow or ice to remain upon such spaces or upon any accessway from the building or facility served by such spaces longer than 12 hours after ice accumulates or one inch of snowfall. 
(Code 1985, § 5-7-3) 
State Law reference- Parking for persons with a disability, C.R.S. § 42-3-204. 
Secs. 58-64-58-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, C.R.S. §§ 42-4-1801 et seq., 42-4-2101 et seq. 

Sec. 58-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means: 
(1)  Any vehicle left unattended on private property for a period of 72 hours or longer without the consent of the owner, occupant or tenant of such property or such person's agent; 
(2)  Any vehicle left unattended on public property, including any portion of a street or highway right-of-way, within the limits of the city for a period of 24 hours or longer, unless the owner of driver has conspicuously affixed thereto a dated notice, or otherwise notified the city's police department of such person's intention to remove such vehicle within 72 hours, or the vehicle is parked in a public street within 50 feet of the property of the owner; 
(3)  Any "junk vehicle" as defined in section 30-166; or 
(4)  Any vehicle stored in an impound lot at the request of its owner or the owner's agent or the police department and not removed from the impound lot according to the agreement with the owner or agent or within 72 hours of the time the police department notifies the owner or agent that the vehicle is available for release upon payment of any applicable charges or fees. If the police department requested the storage, the provisions of this article governing public tows apply as of the time of abandonment, and the police department shall be deemed the responsible law enforcement agency. Otherwise, the private tow provisions of this article apply as of the time of abandonment. 
    Appraisal means a bona fide estimate of reasonable market value made by any vehicle dealer licensed in this state or by any employee of the state patrol, the county sheriff's department or the police department whose appointment for such purpose has been reported by the head of the appointing agency to the executive director of the department of revenue of the state. 
    Department means the state department of revenue acting directly or through its duly authorized officers and agents. 
    Disabled vehicle means any vehicle which is stopped or parked, either attended or unattended, upon a street, highway or right-of-way generally open to the use of the public and which is, due to any mechanical failure or any inoperability because of a collision, a fire or any other such damage, temporarily inoperable under its own power. 
    Impound lot means a parcel of real property that is owned or leased by the city or an operator at which motor vehicles are stored under appropriate protection. 
    Operator means a person or firm licensed by the public utilities commission of the state as a towing carrier. 
    Private property means any real property that is not public property. 
    Private tow means any tow of an abandoned vehicle not requested by the police department. 
    Public tow means any tow of an abandoned vehicle requested by the police department. 
    Vehicle means any machine propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides to transport persons or property or pull machinery and includes, without limitation, automobile, airplane, truck, trailer, motorcycle, motor scooter, tractor, buggy and wagon. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-5), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-82. - Abandonment; authority to impound; public tow. 
    Any police or code enforcement officer who finds a vehicle which such officer has probable cause to believe has been abandoned on public property may, without notice or delay, require such vehicle to be removed or cause the same to be removed and placed in storage in any impound lot designated or maintained by the city or to any other place under any of the circumstances hereinafter described: 
(1)  The driver of the vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and it is necessary to tow the vehicle to a storage lot to secure it and its contents. 
(2)  Removal of the vehicle is necessary in the interest of public health or safety because of fire, flood, snow, storm or other natural or manmade disaster or emergency. 
(3)  There is probable cause to believe the vehicle is stolen. 
(4)  The vehicle is parked in a designated no parking or tow-away zone. 
(5)  The vehicle is illegally parked in a designated handicapped parking space or zone. 
(6)  There is probable cause to believe the vehicle has been vandalized or its parts stolen. 
(7)  The engine number, vehicle identification number or manufacturer's serial number has been altered, changed or obliterated. 
(8)  The vehicle is parked, stopped or standing in a manner which creates an obstruction or hazard or potential obstruction or hazard to any lawful function or use of any public street or other public or private property. 
(9)  The vehicle is blocking access to fire hydrants, fire standpipe outlets or fire sprinklers. 
(10)  The vehicle is parked, stopped or standing in designated safety zones or safety lanes. 
(11)  The vehicle is parked in a designated fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-10), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-83. - Report; notice; public tow. 
(a)  Upon having an abandoned vehicle towed, the police department shall ascertain, if possible, whether or not the vehicle has been reported stolen, and, if so reported, the police department shall recover and secure the vehicle, notify its owner and terminate the abandonment proceedings under this article. The police department shall have the right to recover from the owner its reasonable costs to recover and secure the vehicle. 
(b)  As soon as possible, but in no event later than ten working days after having an abandoned vehicle towed, the police department shall report the same to the department by first class or certified mail, personal delivery or internet communication, which report shall be on a form prescribed and supplied by the department. The report shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The fact of possession, including the date possession was taken, the location of storage of the abandoned vehicle and the location from which it was towed, the business address, telephone number and the name and signature of a representative from the police department; 
(2)  If applicable, the identity of the operator possessing the abandoned vehicle, together with such person's business address and telephone number and the carrier number assigned by the public utilities commission; and 
(3)  A description of the abandoned vehicle, including the make, model, color, and year of such vehicle; the license number, issuing state, and the expiration date of the license plate; the vehicle identification number; and a list of the names and addresses of any known owners. 
(c)  The police department, upon receiving the department's report as required by state statute, shall determine, from all available information and after reasonable inquiry, whether or not the abandoned vehicle has been reported stolen, and, if so reported, shall recover and secure the vehicle and notify its owner and terminate the abandonment proceedings under this article. The police department shall have the right to recover from the owner its reasonable costs to recover and secure the vehicle. 
(d)  As required by state statute, the police department, within ten working days of the receipt of the department's report, shall notify by certified mail or personal service, the owner of record, if ascertained, and any lien holder, if ascertained, of the fact of such report and the claim, if any, and shall send or serve a copy of such notice to the operator. The notice shall contain information that the identified motor vehicle has been reported abandoned to the department, the location of the vehicle, and the location from which it was towed, and that, unless claimed within 30 calendar days from the date the notice was sent or served as determined from the postmark on the notice, the vehicle is subject to sale. 
(e)  Such notice shall also inform the owner of record of his opportunity to request a hearing concerning the legality of the towing of the abandoned vehicle, pursuant to this article, and the fact that the owner must contact the police department to request, in writing, a hearing within ten days of the postmarked date or date of service of the sending of the notice required by subsection (d) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-15), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-84. - Hearing. 
(a)  Any hearing requested under this article shall be conducted before the municipal judge or a hearing officer appointed by the municipal judge, within 72 hours (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and city holidays) of receipt of a written demand for such hearing, unless the person requesting the hearing waives the right to a speedy hearing. The sole issue before the municipal judge or hearing officer shall be whether there was probable cause to impound the vehicle. In this section the term "probable cause to impound" means a state of facts to allow a person of ordinary care and prudence to believe that there was a sufficient breach of municipal, state or federal laws, rules or regulations to grant legal authority for the removal of the vehicle. 
(b)  The hearing shall be conducted in an informal manner and shall not be governed by the formal rules of evidence. The person demanding the hearing shall have the burden of establishing that such person has the right to possession of the vehicle. The police department shall have the burden of establishing that there was probable cause to impound the vehicle. The municipal judge or hearing officer shall only determine that either there was probable cause to impound the vehicle, or there was not probable cause to impound the vehicle. The decision of the municipal judge or hearing officer shall be a final judgment. 
(c)  Upon a finding of no probable cause, towing and storage fees shall be paid by the city in accordance with arrangements made between the city and the operator. If the possessor of the vehicle fails to claim the vehicle from the operator within 24 hours of a finding of no probable cause, excluding hours when the operator is not open for business, the possessor shall assume liability for all subsequent storage charges. It shall be the responsibility of the police department to notify the operator in writing of a finding of no probable cause within one working day after such finding is made. 
(d)  Failure of the owner of the vehicle: 
(1)  To request a hearing in writing to the police department within ten days of the postmarked date of service of the notice; or 
(2)  To attend a scheduled post-seizure hearing 
shall be deemed a waiver of the right to such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-20), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-85. - Abandonment; private tow. 
(a)  Any owner, tenant, lessee or such person's authorized agent may have an abandoned vehicle removed from such person's property by having it towed and impounded by an operator. 
(b)  Any operator in possession of any abandoned vehicle from a private tow shall immediately notify the police department as to the operator's name and the location of the impound lot where the vehicle is located and a description of the abandoned vehicle, including make, model, color and year of such vehicle; the license number, issuing state and expiration date of the license plate; and the vehicle identification number. Upon such notification, the police department shall ascertain, if possible, whether or not the vehicle has been reported stolen and, if so reported, shall recover and secure the vehicle and notify its owner and terminate the abandonment proceedings under this article. The police department shall have the right to recover from the owner its reasonable costs to recover and secure the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-25), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-86. - Appraisal and sale of impounded vehicles. 
(a)  Public tow abandoned vehicles or vehicles abandoned in an impound lot subsequent to a public tow shall be appraised and sold by the police department or its designated representative at a public or private sale held not less than 30 nor more than 90 days after the date of issuance of the notice required by section 58-83. 
(b)  If the appraised value of an abandoned vehicle sold pursuant to this section is $200.00 or less, the sale shall be made only for the purpose of junking, scrapping or dismantling such vehicle, and the purchaser thereof shall not, under any circumstances, be entitled to a state certificate of title. The police department shall cause to be executed and delivered a bill of sale, together with a copy of the required state report to the person purchasing such vehicle. The bill of sale shall state that the purchaser acquires no right to a certificate of title for such vehicle. The police department shall promptly submit a report of sale, with a copy of the bill of sale, to the department and shall deliver a copy of such report of sale to the purchaser of the vehicle. 
(c)  If the appraised value of an abandoned vehicle sold pursuant to this section is more than $200.00, the sale may be made for any intended use by the purchaser thereof. The police department shall cause to be executed and delivered a bill of sale, together with a copy of the required state report and application for a state certificate of title signed by a legally authorized representative of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-30), 8-17-2004) 
Sec. 58-87. - Proceeds of sale. 
(a)  If the sale of any vehicle and its attached accessories or equipment under the provisions of this article realizes a monetary amount less than or equal to the sum of all charges of the operator who has perfected a lien pursuant to state statute, then the operator shall have a valid claim against the owner of record for the full amount of such charges, less the amount received upon the sale of such vehicle. 
(b)  If the sale of any vehicle and its attached accessories or equipment under the provisions of this article realizes a monetary amount greater than the sum of all charges of the operator who has perfected a lien pursuant to state statute, then the proceeds of the sale shall be distributed as provided by state statute unless the city has entered into a towing agreement with an operator which provides for a specified contractual distribution. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 9(5-9-35), 8-17-2004) 
Secs. 58-88-58-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARKING RESTRICTIONS DURING SNOWSTORMS 

Sec. 58-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City manager means the city manager or designated representative. 
    Police chief means the chief of police or designated representative. 
    Public works director means the public works director or designated representative. 
    Snow route means a street which has been designated a snow route by the public works director and which has been posted with a snow route sign. 
    Street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every publicly maintained right-of-way open to the use of the public for the purposes of vehicular travel. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-1) 
Sec. 58-102. - Designation of snow routes and posting of signs. 
(a)  The public works director may designate specific streets as snow routes within the city after consultation with the police chief. The designation shall be based upon a determination as to which streets should be free of parked, stopped or stalled vehicles when a snowstorm condition has been declared in order to expedite motor vehicle traffic or to facilitate snow removal. 
(b)  Along each street designated a snow route, the public works director shall cause to be posted at reasonable intervals traffic signs indicating that the street has been designated as a snow route and that parking prohibitions shall apply during a snowstorm alert or severe snowstorm alert. The lack of visibility of any such sign when a parking restriction is in effect shall not excuse the owner or operator of any vehicle from complying with the parking requirements. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-2) 
Sec. 58-103. - Declaration of snowstorm alert. 
    The city manager, upon recommendation of the public works director or police chief, may declare a snowstorm alert to be in effect. The recommendation may be made upon learning of a forecast of or the existence of accumulations or drifting of snow or sleet or freezing rain. When a snowstorm alert has been declared, the city manager shall issue a press release, or notice to the public, declaring the existence of a snowstorm alert and requesting that vehicle use be restricted to four-wheel drive vehicles or vehicles equipped with adequate snow tires or chains. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-3) 
Sec. 58-104. - Declaration of severe snowstorm alert. 
    The city manager, upon recommendation of the public works director or police chief, may declare a severe snowstorm alert to be in effect. The recommendation may be made upon learning of a forecast of or the existence of accumulations or drifting of snow which, in the opinion of either the public works director or police chief, are or will be substantial or learns of a forecast of or the existence of amounts of sleet or freezing rain which are or may become substantial. When a severe snowstorm alert has been issued, the city manager shall issue a press release, or notice to the public, declaring the existence of a severe snowstorm alert and requesting that persons not engage in vehicular travel except for the purpose of meeting essential needs or providing necessary public services, and that vehicles used for such purposes be limited to four-wheel drive vehicles or vehicles equipped with adequate snow tires or chains. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-4) 
Sec. 58-105. - Parking restriction during snowstorm alert or severe snowstorm alert. 
(a)  When a snowstorm alert or severe snowstorm alert has been declared, the parking restrictions provided in this article shall be in effect. The city manager shall issue a press release, or notice to the public, stating that the restriction is in effect. 
(b)  When a snowstorm alert or severe snowstorm alert has been declared, no person shall stop, stand, or park any vehicle on any portion of a snow route, or leave, abandon or permit to remain any vehicle which is stalled on any portion of a snow route. This subsection shall not apply to any official emergency vehicle, including an ambulance, fire or police vehicle, during the course of immediate and on-going service. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense in any prosecution for a violation of subsection (b) of this section that the owner or operator of a stalled vehicle was at the time of the issuance of a citation attempting, with due diligence, to secure assistance to move the stalled vehicle. The availability of such affirmative defense shall not affect the imposition of responsibility for any costs incurred as a result of enforcement of this article, including the cost of removing the vehicle from the snow route. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to permit parking, stopping or standing in violation of any other regulation concerning the parking, stopping or standing of vehicles. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-5) 
Sec. 58-106. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any police officer or code enforcement officer of the city may issue a citation for any violation of this article. If the owner or operator of the vehicle is present when the violation is discovered, no citation shall be issued until the owner or operator has been ordered to cause the vehicle to be removed immediately from the snow route and such owner or operator has failed or refused to comply with such order. 
(b)  The public works director, any police officer or code enforcement officer may order the removal of any vehicle which is in violation of this article and for which a citation has been issued pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. The vehicle shall be removed to the nearest place, where in the judgment of the public works director, the vehicle will not obstruct a snow route. 
(c)  The owner or operator of a vehicle removed from a snow route shall be responsible for all costs incurred as a result of such removal, in addition to other fines or penalties. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-6) 
Sec. 58-107. - Termination of restriction by city manager. 
    Whenever weather conditions are such that the parking restriction is no longer necessary to be in effect in all or part of the city, the city manager may declare the restriction completely or partially terminated. The city manager shall provide information relating to the termination of the restriction and information relating to the locations to which vehicles have been removed. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-7) 
Sec. 58-108. - Announcements by city manager. 
    Announcements regarding parking restrictions during snowstorm alerts and severe snowstorm alerts shall be provided to area radio and television stations, or made public in any other manner. The failure of any announcement to be disseminated by radio and television stations shall not excuse the owner or operator of any vehicles from complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 5-12-8) 
Secs. 58-109-58-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRAFFIC CALMING DEVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Safe routes to school, C.R.S. § 43-1-1601. 

Sec. 58-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Standards and specifications shall mean the City of Federal Heights' Standards and Specifications for Design and Construction of Public Improvements as adopted by resolution of city council and including all amendments and addendums thereto. 
    Traffic calming devices means roadway design measures which include but are not limited to speed bumps, speed humps, narrowing of roadways, construction of traffic islands, medians and other barriers and landscaping for the purpose of controlling the speed and movement of vehicles. 
(Code 1985, § 5-14-1; Ord. No. 10-09, § 7, 7-6-2010) 
Sec. 58-122. - Restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, construct, operate or maintain any traffic calming device on any private street, roadway, parking lot or alley within the city without first obtaining approval for such from the city. 
(Code 1985, § 5-14-2) 
Sec. 58-123. - Application. 
(a)  Application for approval of traffic calming devices shall be submitted to the city engineer on forms provided by the city. Within 30 days of receipt of a completed application and payment of a review fee as set by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16, the city engineer shall either deny, approve or conditionally approve an application and so inform the applicant in writing. 
(b)  All proposed traffic calming devices must meet all applicable requirements set forth in the standards and specifications for the design and construction of public improvements. Additionally, in reviewing an application, the city engineer shall consider additional factors that include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Existing speed limits, warning signs and other traffic control signs or devices. 
(2)  Roadway dimensions and conditions including length and width; type of construction; shoulders or sidewalks; curves, grade, topography, drainage, sight lines and landscaping. 
(3)  Proximity to other arterial and collector roadways. 
(4)  Road usage information including average and peak use traffic volume, percentage of traffic exceeding posted speed limits, and recent accident history. 
(5)  Neighborhood information including the number of businesses, private residences, and the number of residences per mile fronting on the street; proximity of multifamily housing; schools; churches; child day care centers; parks; playgrounds; or facilities utilized by children. 
(6)  Impact upon response time and safety of fire and police departments in providing fire, rescue and emergency service. 
(7)  Any necessary maps, plans or survey data. 
(8)  Traffic engineering guidelines identifying the appropriate type, construction and location of traffic calming device(s) after consideration of the requirements and factors contained herein. 
(Code 1985, § 5-14-3; Ord. No. 10-09, § 8, 7-6-2010) 
Sec. 58-124. - Appeal. 
    Decisions of the city engineer may be appealed to the city council. To appeal an applicant must, within ten days of the date of the city engineer's decision, submit a written notice of appeal to the mayor. Such notice must specifically state the grounds for the appeal. The city council shall, within 30 days of receipt of a notice of appeal, hold a public hearing on the matter in accordance with the procedure set forth in chapter II, article X. Within seven days of completion of the hearing, the city council shall issue a written decision in which it will uphold, overturn or uphold with conditions the decision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1985, § 5-14-4) 
Sec. 58-125. - Removal/improvement. 
    If a traffic-calming device is not removed or improved within the required time, the city may, upon notice to the property owner, cause the work to be done at the expense of the owner, and that cost, including an administrative fee of 15 percent, shall constitute a lien against the property. Such lien shall be recorded in the office of the county clerk and recorder, and the city may collect upon such lien as provided for in section 30-109. 
(Code 1985, § 5-14-5) 
Chapter 62 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall mean as follows unless otherwise specified: 
    Standards and specifications shall mean the City of Federal Heights' Standards and Specifications for Design and Construction of Public Improvements as adopted by resolution of city council and including all amendments and addendums thereto. 
(Ord. No. 10-09, § 9, 7-6-2010) 
Secs. 62-2-62-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 62-20. - Water connection. 
(a)  All structures, buildings or other use or occupancy of property that requires the use of potable water shall be connected to the city's municipal water distribution system. The means, manner and method of such connection shall be as specified this article and the standards and specifications for the design and construction of public improvements. No building, structure, or use of property requiring such connection shall be constructed or established until the city has issued a water tap. 
(b)  Any existing structure, building or use of property whose occupancy requires the use of potable water, that is or becomes within 400 feet of a city water main, shall be connected to the city's municipal water system at the property owner's expense, including all fees as required by this article having been paid. Such connection must be established, and all fees paid, within 12 months of any written notice of the city of the required connection under this subsection. 
(c)  No more than one building may be supplied water from the same service connection unless permission is first obtained, in writing, from the city. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-1; Ord. No. 10-07, § 1, 5-4-2010; Ord. No. 10-09, § 10, 7-6-2010) 
Sec. 62-21. - Water tap application. 
(a)  An applicant for any new connection to the city's water system shall submit an application in the name of the property owner accompanied by the required tap fee. The application shall contain the following: 
(1)  Address of the premises; 
(2)  Name and address of the owner; 
(3)  Proposed size of water meter and tap; 
(4)  Type of use (for example, residential, mobile home park, commercial, retail or industrial); 
(5)  Square footage total of structure(s) and maximum number and type of fixtures to be served; 
(6)  A map showing the proposed location of the tap to the main, the service connections, the location of the meter pit and the location of the backflow prevention assembly, if required. 
(b)  The city engineer shall, based upon the information provided by the applicant, determine the required tap, meter and backflow prevention assembly, if required. The meter type and model must be approved by the director of public works prior to installation. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-2; Ord. No. 11-05, § 1, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 62-22. - Water tap modification. 
    No increase in the size of a water tap or water meter will be permitted without first having obtained a water tap modification permit from the city. A tap fee will be required and shall be the difference in the current tap fee schedule between the existing tap and the larger tap. The issuance of such a modification shall conform to section 62-23. An application for such modification shall be filed with the city containing the following: 
(1)  Address of the premises; 
(2)  Name and address of the owner; 
(3)  Number of fixtures now served; 
(4)  Number of additional fixtures to be served. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-3) 
Sec. 62-23. - Cross-connection control program. 
(a)  Legislative intent. It is the intent of the city council to protect the city's potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution by backflow from an owner's internal distribution system or private water system, and to provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-connection control, which will systematically prevent the contamination or pollution of the city's potable water distribution system. 
(b)  Authority. In addition to the city's home rule powers, the authority to implement and maintain controls and regulations on cross-connections is contained in the following legislation and regulations: 
(1)  Clean Water Act 33, United States Code (U.S.C.) § 1251 et seq. (1977). 
(2)  Safe Drinking Water Act, Title XIV-Safety of Public Drinking Water Systems of the Public Health Service Act, codified as 42 U.S.C. § 300f et seq. (1974), Public Law 99-399 Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of 1986. 
(3)  National Primary Drinking Water Regulations authorized through the Safe Drinking Water Act, 42 U.S.C. § 300g-l. 
(4)  Colorado Department of Health Law Title 25-1-114, 25-1-114.1, Colorado Revised Statutes (C.R.S.). 
(5)  Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations Section 14.1 (Hazardous Cross-Connections). 
(6)  Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual, 5th Edition, August 2004, published by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, Water Quality Control Division, 4300 Cherry Creek Drive South, Denver, Colorado, 80246-1530. 
(7)  Occupational Safety and Health Administration Federal Register #202 Part 2, Page 22234, Subpart J. 
(8)  Chapter 10, Building and Building Regulations, of the Code. 
(c)  Responsibility. 
(1)  The community services director is delegated the responsibility for implementing and enforcing a cross-connection control program in accordance with this section. If a backflow prevention device is required at the city water service connection to any owner's premises for the protection of the city's potable water distribution system, the community services director shall give notice in writing to the owner to install an approved backflow prevention device at each service connection to the premises. The owner shall, at the owner's expense, install and maintain an approved backflow prevention device(s). 
(2)  No provision of this section exempts a user from the cross-connection control requirements for water distribution systems as otherwise contained in the code. 
(3)  Except for irrigation systems, residential dwelling units are exempt from the requirements of this section. For purposes of this section, residential dwelling units are defined as single-family, duplex, and townhouse units. 
(d)  Definitions. When not clearly otherwise indicated by the context, the following words and phrases in this section have the following meanings: 
(1)  Annual due date means the annual date, as established by the community services director, when required tests must be completed and proof received by the city. In those years when the annual due date does not fall on a regular business day, the due date for that year will be the next regular business day. 
(2)  Approved means accepted by the community services department as meeting the applicable specifications set forth in this section, or as suitable for the proposed use. 
(3)  Certified inspector means any person who has passed a state approved or sponsored testing and inspection course, and who meets the definition of a certified cross-connection control technician as set forth in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. 
(4)  City means the City of Federal Heights. 
(5)  Community services director means the person appointed by the city manager to be in charge of the city's potable water distribution system and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities as set forth in this section, or the community services director's authorized designee. 
(6)  Hazardous connections means any proposed or actual cross-connection that poses a pollution or health hazard as defined in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual to the city's potable water distribution system. 
(7)  Isolation means the control of cross-connections within the plumbing system of a customer of the city's potable water distribution system by isolating individual cross-connections at or near the point of potential contamination or pollution with approved backflow prevention devices or methods. 
(8)  User means the person billed for water service provided by the city's public works department or the owner of the property served by city water. In the event that the property owner and the person billed for city water service are different, the owner shall be solely responsible for all obligations and duties of this section. 
(e)  Water system. The city's potable water distribution system consists of the source and distribution facilities of the water system to the point of the user's system. The source includes all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the distribution system. The system includes the network of conduits used for the delivery of water from the source to the water service connection. 
(f)  Plan approval. 
(1)  All building plans involving water/waste water service, plumbing plans for additions or alterations to existing plumbing systems, and/or irrigation system installation submitted to and reviewed by the community services department must be approved prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(2)  Submitted plans must show: 
a.  Water service type, size and location. 
b.  Meter size and location. 
c.  Backflow prevention device size, type and location. 
d.  Fire sprinkling systems service line, size and type of backflow prevention device. 
(g)  Installation. 
(1)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at or near the property line, after the meter and before the first branch line leading off the service line in accordance with the installation details contained in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual whenever any of the following conditions exist: 
a.  In the case of premises having an auxiliary water supply the city's potable water distribution system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow prevention device in the service line appropriate to the degree of hazard. 
b.  In the case of premises in which any industrial fluids or any other objectionable substance is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or potential hazard to the city's potable water distribution system, the city's system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow prevention device in the service line appropriate to the degree of hazard. This will include the handling of process waters and waters originating from the city's potable water distribution system which have been subject to deterioration in quality. 
c.  In the case of premises having internal cross-connections that cannot be permanently corrected and controlled, or having intricate plumbing and piping arrangements, or where entry to all portions of the premises is not readily accessible for inspection purposes making it impracticable or impossible to ascertain whether or not dangerous cross-connections exist, the city's potable water distribution system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow prevention device in the service line. 
(2)  Backflow prevention devices shall, to the extent practicable, be installed in an accessible location to facilitate inspection, testing and maintenance. Adequate drainage area for the device must be provided for in the event that water is released. 
(3)  Backflow prevention devices shall not be used as the inlet or outlet valve of the water meter. Test cocks shall not be used as supply connections. 
(4)  In order to ensure that backflow prevention devices continue to operate satisfactorily, they shall be tested by a certified inspector, at the time of installation, and as required herein thereafter. Such test shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. The backflow device test results shall be supplied to the community services department within ten days of the test, in the manner as prescribed in this section. 
(5)  The community services department will inspect all containment installations and isolation installations that are installed for compliance with this section. 
(6)  In addition to the requirements of this section, including the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual, backflow prevention devices shall be installed and inspected in accordance with all other applicable requirements set forth in this code. 
(7)  Backflow prevention device installations shall be inspected and approved for use by the community services department. Inspections must be scheduled at least 24 hours in advance of the desired inspection time. 
(h)  Standards. 
(1)  Backflow prevention devices shall adhere to the following standards: 
a.  Any backflow prevention device required herein shall be of a model and size approved by the community services department. The term approved backflow prevention device shall mean a device that has been manufactured in full conformance with the standards established by the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. 
b.  Backflow prevention devices currently installed that are not approved shall be replaced with properly installed approved devices. 
c.  Backflow prevention devices currently installed that are not approved shall be replaced with an approved backflow prevention device, unless the device passes an annual operational test. If the device fails any such test, it shall be replaced within ten working days with an approved backflow prevention device. 
d.  A user may upon the prior written approval of the community services director install isolation devices in lieu of containment devices; provided, however, that all isolation devices shall be in compliance and subject to all requirements for containment devices as set forth in this section. 
(2)  Any mobile unit using water from a city hydrant shall employ either an approved backflow prevention device subject to the same requirements for a containment device as set forth in this section or an air gap as defined in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. Air gaps shall require at least an annual inspection and verification of air gap requirements as set forth in the latest edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. Verification shall be performed by the owner of the mobile unit, or the owner's agent, on a notarized form available from the community services director. 
(i)  Inspections, testing, and repair. It is the responsibility of the user of all connections to the city's potable water distribution system to have operational tests made on the backflow prevention device upon installation and at least annually thereafter. The user is also responsible to ensure that proof of such test is provided to the city no later than the annual due date. These tests shall be made at the expense of the user and must be performed by a certified inspector. A backflow prevention device shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the owner whenever a device is found to be defective. 
(1)  Where the community services director deems necessary, the director may require operational tests at more frequent intervals. The cost for any test shall be at the user's expense. All tests shall be performed by a certified inspector. 
(2)  As necessary, the device shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the user whenever the device(s) are found to be defective. Records of all tests, repairs or replacement shall be kept by the certified inspector and the user, and a copy of all such records shall be sent to the community services department within ten working days of performance of such work, in the manner as prescribed in this section. 
(3)  All testing gauges shall be tested and calibrated for accuracy yearly, or more often, in the event of questionable readings. 
(4)  The community services director retains the right, at any time, to test or inspect the installation and operation of any containment device or any device, including air gaps used for compliance with this section. 
(j)  Right of entry. 
(1)  The community services director and/or certified inspector assigned to inspect premises relative to possible hazards shall carry proper credentials of his or her office and, upon exhibit of which, said person shall have the right of entry to inspect any and all buildings and premises for cross-connections in the performance of his or her duties. If such entry is refused, the city shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(2)  This right of entry shall be a condition of continuation of water service in order to protect the city's potable water distribution system and the health, safety and welfare of the community. Questions regarding proper credentials should be directed to the community services director. 
(k)  Reporting and record-keeping duties and requirements. The certified inspector shall report on a form approved by the city, the results of tests and maintenance to the community services director and the user. This report will be submitted to the community services director within ten working days following the completion of the test or maintenance of the device. The certified inspector shall also, on a form approved by the city, attach a card to the backflow prevention device following each test or maintenance activity to document and date the activities performed. Records of all tests or maintenance activities, including materials and parts changed, shall be kept by the certified inspector, the user, and the community services director for a period of not less than three years. Certified inspectors, who in the determination of the community services director, fail to comply with the requirements of this section may be removed either temporarily or permanently from the city's list of approved inspectors and reported to the applicable authorities. 
(l)  Compliance. Any user who fails to comply with the requirements of this section shall be subject to the following actions and penalties: 
(1)  Upon failure to comply, a notice of reminder will be mailed to the party billed for water service. In the event that the property owner is different than the party billed for water service, a notice of reminder will also be mailed to the listed owner, at the address on file with the applicable county assessor's office. The user will have 30 calendar days from the annual due date to comply. 
(2)  In the event that the user does not comply within 30 days of the annual due date, a first violation notice will be mailed to the party billed for water service as well as the property owner, if different from the billed party. If the user is the person billed for water service, a $1,000.00 charge will be added to the water bill for the property as a civil penalty. If the user is not the same as the person billed for water service, a bill reflecting the $1,000.00 civil penalty will be mailed to the user. If the user provides proof of compliance to the water department within 60 days of the annual due date, $600.00 of this charge will be waived. 
(3)  In the event that the user does not comply within 60 days of the annual due date, a second violation notice will be mailed to the party billed for water service as well as the property owner, if different from the billed party. If the user is the person billed for water service, a $2,000.00 charge will be added to the water bill for the property as a civil penalty. If the user is not the same as the person billed for water service, a bill reflecting the $2,000.00 civil penalty will be mailed to the user. 
(4)  In the event that the user does not comply within 90 days of the annual due date, notice of termination of service will be posted upon the property and mailed to the party billed for water service and the property owner if different from the billed party. Water service may be terminated seven days after notice and may remain terminated until such time as the user complies with the requirements of this section. 
(5)  Any penalty imposed pursuant to this section may be appealed to the community services director. 
(6)  Service of water to any premises may also be discontinued by the community services director if unprotected cross-connections exist on the premises, if any defect is found in an installed backflow prevention assembly, if a backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed or does not adequately protect the public health. Service shall not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected to the satisfaction of the community services director. 
(7)  Discontinuance of service may be summary, immediate and without written notice whenever, in the judgment of the community services director, such action is necessary to protect the city's potable water supply or the safety of the city's potable water distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 10-07, § 2, 5-4-2010; Ord. No. 10-21, §§ 1-4, 1-4-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-07 repealed the former section and enacted a new one as set out herein. The former section pertained to backflow prevention assemblies modification and derived from Code 1985, §§ 9-2-3.5, 9-2-17.5. 
Sec. 62-24. - Water tap fees. 
(a)  Fees for water taps shall be as established by resolution of city council as provided in section 1-16. Applicants shall also pay the City of Westminster water tap fees in effect at the time of the application. 
(b)  No fee is required for a water tap for a fire line only. However, the property owner shall acquire, install and maintain a service connection, backflow prevention assembly, tap meter and meter pit for such line, which is subject to city approval. 
(c)  A tap fee may be reduced by up to 25 percent by the city council upon its determination that the required main extension substantially upgrades the city's utility service, which determination shall be based upon factors such as the improvements to capacity, equipment, lines and physical characteristics of the service. 
(d)  The tap fee for any connection not otherwise specified by resolution of the city council shall be as established by the city council upon negotiation of such fee with the applicant. 
(e)  Commercial and industrial users may install, at their sole expense, a separate metered water tap for irrigation only. An additional tap fee as specified in subsection (a) of this section shall be required of the user and a separate application for service, along with the required cash deposit, filed in accordance with section 62-26. Water from a separate irrigation meter shall be used only for lawn and landscape irrigation. The city shall not impose a sewer charge for any water from a separate irrigation meter. An irrigation system shall not be connected to the domestic supply except for the system's connection to the city main. All irrigation systems shall be fitted with an approved backflow prevention assembly and installed as required by the city engineer. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-5) 
Sec. 62-25. - Tapping. 
(a)  Prior to the actual tapping to a city water main, a building permit and a pavement cut permit (if a city street is to be cut) shall be obtained and all fees shall be paid. The city building inspector shall be notified 48 hours in advance of construction. The tap, fittings and service line between the main and the meter must conform to the standards and specifications for the design and construction of public improvements and must be approved by the inspector prior to backfilling. 
(b)  Authorization to install any tap or meter may be withheld by the city if the applicant is in violation of any law of the city or in default of any agreement with the city. It shall be unlawful to use, or permit to be used, any water tap installation until the meter has been set or approved by the city. Upon approval, the entire installation, including the water meter, shall become the property of the city. 
(c)  No new tap and/or meter shall be permitted for any property, which has delinquent utility fees or charges for any property within the city under common ownership. 
(Ord. No. 10-09, § 11, 7-6-2010; Ord. No. 11-05, § 2, 5-3-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-09 repealed the former section and enacted a new one as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1985, § 9-2-6. 
Sec. 62-26. - Application for service. 
    Application for the use of water shall be made to the city's utility clerk, in writing, and shall contain: 
(1)  Address of the premises; 
(2)  Owner's name and address; 
(3)  A signed statement, by the owner, agreeing to all provisions of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-7) 
Sec. 62-27. - Meter required. 
    All premises using the city water supply shall be equipped with a water meter of a size required by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-8) 
Sec. 62-28. - Distribution. 
    No water shall be sold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city water supply to any person or premises other than the premises, and the occupants thereof, for which application has been made, and tap granted, except in the case of fire or similar emergency. No occupant or owner shall purchase water from any other source except the city. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-9) 
Sec. 62-29. - Water rates. 
    The owner or occupant of each property served by the city's water system shall pay the following monthly water service charges for water purchased: 
(1)  Residential users: All residential users, including mobile home parks, shall pay a rate predicated on per thousand gallons of water used as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(2)  Commercial/industrial: All commercial and industrial users, except "commercial-recreation" users, shall pay a rate predicated on per thousand gallons for water used as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(3)  Commercial-recreational users: All commercial-recreational users shall pay a rate predicated on per thousand gallons of water used as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. The term "Commercial-recreational" users shall be defined as those non-residential users whose primary use of such water is to facilitate water-related recreational activities. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-10; Ord. No. 17-10, § 1, 8-1-2017) 
Sec. 62-30. - Payment of water bills. 
(a)  Water bills are sent monthly and payment is due by the tenth day of the month in which the user receives the bill for the prior month's service. If a bill is not paid by the 25th day of the month in which it is received, the account shall be deemed delinquent and a fee imposed in the amount as prescribed by resolution the city council in accordance with section 1-16. 
(b)  If any account, including any late fee, is not paid in full within 35 days of its due date, the city may discontinue water service to the premises and/or proceed with any lawful collection remedy. 
(c)  The owner of the premises served shall be responsible to the city for the payment of all water charges arising out of the provision of such services to the owner's property. Such liability shall be joint and several with that of the occupant and shall not relieve the occupant from his/her obligation of payment for services when the occupant is different from the owner. 
(d)  All water charges prescribed by this article, together with interest, penalty and reasonable costs of collection, including attorneys fees, shall constitute a perpetual and continuing lien upon the property to which water or wastewater services are provided. The penalty and interest shall be assessed at a rate equivalent to that which is assessed by state law upon delinquent general property taxes. Such lien shall have priority over all other liens except general taxes and shall, upon the city's certification and filing with Adams County, be collected and paid to the city by the county treasurer in the same manner as delinquent general property taxes. 
(e)  For individually owned properties within multi-family residential structures and/or multi-unit commercial structures to which water is furnished by means other than by metering the consumption of each individually owned unit, the lien for unpaid water and wastewater service charges, interest, and costs imposed by this section attaches upon each unit in an amount computed by dividing the total amount of the lien by the number of units served through the master meter. 
(f)  The city may enforce the lien against the property, or the personal property of the owner and occupant, or both. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-11; Ord. No. 04-05, §§ 1, 2, 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 10-12, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 62-31. - Suspension of water service. 
(a)  The city shall, at least ten days prior to the suspension of water service, send written notice of such suspension to the user and property owner. Such notice shall inform the parties of the amount due, the shut-off date and that suspension of service may be avoided by payment in full before the shut-off date of the outstanding balance, including any late fees. The notice will be sent by regular mail to the parties' last known address as shown on the utility department records. 
(b)  To reinstate service, the property owner or user must pay in full the outstanding balance due, including any late fees, plus a turn-on fee as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 9-2-11.5; Ord. No. 04-05, § 3, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 62-32. - Suspension of water service for noncompliance with backflow prevention assembly requirements.
