ARTICLE VII. - GROUNDWATER RIGHTS 

Sec. 62-291. - Water supply. 
    All property located within the city or annexed to the city and requiring a potable water supply for human consumption shall be connected with the water utility of the city. A private water supply may be used for irrigation purposes on property connected to the water utility, but water from the private supply shall not be used for human consumption. 
(Code 1985, § 9-4-1) 
Sec. 62-292. - Assignment of water rights. 
    Any party desiring to: 
(1)  Make a new connection to the city water utility or commence the use of water therefrom; 
(2)  Connect an enlarged tap to the city water utility; 
(3)  Acquire a building permit for any new building or addition to an existing building which would result in a 20 percent or greater increase in the total square feet of building area on the property; 
(4)  Subdivide, resubdivide, zone or rezone property within the city; 
(5)  Annex property to the city; or 
(6)  Take or use water from the city water utility to serve property situated outside the corporate limits of the city; shall assign to the city all ground water, tributary and non-tributary, underlying all the contiguous property under the same ownership for which the owner wishes to take any of the actions referred to in this subsection or subsections (1)-(5) of this section, together with the exclusive right to appropriate, produce, use and otherwise dispose of said ground water, including the right to reuse and otherwise dispose of sewage effluent or other return flows attributable to said ground water. 
None of the proposed actions in subsections (1)-(6) of this section shall be approved by the city until after the completion of the said ground water assignment which shall be accomplished by the execution by the property owner and delivery to the city of the Consent and Agreement form (Appendix 1). 
(Code 1985, § 9-4-2) 
Sec. 62-293. - Tap application limitations. 
    Water tap applications shall be considered based on a priority list determined from the chronological order of assignment of ground water rights to the city. All applications for water taps filed by parties who assigned their ground water rights to the city prior to October 1, 1978, shall be given an equal first priority. In granting water tap applications, the city shall continue to impose limits as to number of taps per development or structure and other reasonable and necessary conditions and restrictions upon the installation and use of water taps. Assignment of ground water rights to the city shall in no way guarantee the availability of water taps in the future. 
(Code 1985, § 9-4-3) 
Chapter 66 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, adopted Sept. 1, 2009, repealed the former ch. 66., §§ 66-1-66-27, and enacted a new ch. 66 as set out herein. The former ch. 66 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code 1985, §§ 7-6-1-7-6-8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Vegetation Ordinance of the City of Federal Heights." 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-2. - Purpose of the chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a guide to appropriate vegetation selection within the city; to prohibit the use of invasive vegetation species; and to deter inappropriate vegetation selection based on factors to include, but not limited to, site and scale limitations. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-3. - Approved and prohibited vegetation. 
    The City of Federal Heights' Approved and Prohibited Vegetation List shall govern the species of vegetation that are allowed and prohibited from use within the city. This document shall be adopted by resolution, which can be amended or updated by city council as it deems necessary. The city manager may, upon notification of city council, approve for use vegetation not specifically prohibited by the list. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-4. - Requirements/prohibitions. 
(a)  It is unlawful to sell or import into the city or to plant or cause to be planted within the city any species of vegetation prohibited by the City of Federal Heights Approved and Prohibited Vegetation List. 
(b)  It is unlawful to plant or cause to be planted any species of trees in the right-of-way of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public property or public place within the city that by its habitat or growth would obstruct, restrict, or conflict with necessary and safe use of the public rights-of-way, including without limitation, pedestrian, bicycle and vehicular traffic. 
(c)  Sites with approved landscape plans are required to maintain those landscape plans and replace vegetation should it die with the same plant material listed on the plan in accordance with chapter 70, article IX of the Code. Should any plant material identified by an approved landscape plan be in violation of this article, the city manager or his designee may approve a substitution of plant material so long as the substituted material does not violate the character of the original approved landscape plan. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-5. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the city manager or designee. Violations of this provision constitute a nuisance as defined in chapter 30, article IV of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Secs. 66-6-66-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREES, SHRUBS AND BUSHES 

Sec. 66-23. - Duty to prune. 
    Any person who is an owner, lessee or occupant, or any servant, agent, representative or employee of such owner, lessee or occupant having control of any lot or parcel of land in the city (also referred to as "responsible party" herein), including without limitation, public and utility easements and drainage way within such property and the adjacent area of land between the property line and the traveled portion of any street or roadway commonly known as the "planter strip," with a tree, shrub, or bush overhanging any sidewalk, street, alley, or right-of-way within the city, shall prune same so that it will not obstruct the view or line of sight of any street or alley, intersection or traffic control device or sign, and so that there shall be a clear space of at least seven feet above the surface of the sidewalk and a clear space of at least 14 feet over any street. Said persons shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous (defined as a potential or actual threat to the safety and well being of persons, real property or personal property) trees, shrubs, bushes or other vegetation, or broken or decayed limbs, and remove all stumps to a depth of at least two inches below grade. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-24. - Right of inspection. 
(a)  The city, through its delegates, agents and employees, shall have the right in accordance with the requirements of this section to enter upon any premises, lands, or places, whether public or private, during reasonable business hours for the purpose of inspecting for compliance with the requirements of this chapter, when at least one of the following circumstances has occurred: 
(1)  Any party having control of the lot or parcel has requested an inspection; 
(2)  A neighboring landowner or occupant has reported a suspected violation and requested an inspection; or 
(3)  An authorized employee or agent of the city has made a visual observation from a public right-of-way or public area and has reason to believe that a violation exists. 
(b)  No entry upon any premises, lands, or places shall be permitted until a responsible party has been notified, either orally or by certified mail, that such inspection is pending. Where possible, inspections shall be scheduled and conducted with the concurrence of a responsible party. If, after receiving notice that an inspection is pending the inspector is denied access to the property, the inspector may seek an inspection warrant issued by the city's municipal court. The court shall issue an inspection warrant upon presentation by the city, through its agent or employee, of an affidavit stating: the information that gives the inspector reasonable cause to believe that any provision of this chapter is being or has been violated; that access has been denied to the inspector; and a general description of the location of the affected land. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-25. - Notice and imposition of cost. 
    When it is determined by the city that a violation of the approved and prohibited vegetation list or section 66-23 exists, the city may, in addition to commencing an action in municipal court, cause a written notice to be personally served or mailed by certified mail to the property address and the address of the property owner as provided in the county public records, directing the property owner and/or responsible party to remedy such violation within 30 days or the city may remedy the violation and the cost shall be assessed against the property. In the event the property is not brought into compliance with the notice, the city may prune or remove and dispose of the tree, shrub, bush or vegetation at the expense of the property owner. Such expense shall include the cost of the work performed plus the actual inspection and administrative costs. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-26. - Certification of work done. 
    After causing the trees, shrubs, bushes or vegetation to be pruned and/or removed and disposed, the city shall certify to the city clerk the legal description of the property upon which the work was done and the name of the owner as last shown by the county public records, with a statement of the work performed, the date thereof, and the total cost. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Sec. 66-27. - Owner liable; assessment of costs; lien. 
    Upon receipt of the statement of cost from the city, the city clerk shall mail a written notice to the owner of the property as last shown upon the county public records, by certified mail, return receipt requested, notifying the owner that work has been performed, stating the date of performance of the work, the nature of the work, and demanding payment of the cost, plus the actual inspection and administrative costs. The notice shall also provide that, if the amount is not paid within 30 days of mailing the notice, it shall become an assessment upon and a lien against the property of the owner and will be certified as an assessment against the property and enforced and collected in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 30-109. 
(Ord. No. 09-04, § 1, 9-1-2009) 
Chapter 70 - ZONING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Zoning Ordinance of the City of Federal Heights," and may be so cited and pleaded. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-1) 
Sec. 70-2. - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to place in effect a comprehensive plan for the city; to encourage the most appropriate use of land throughout the city; to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provision for transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks and other public requirements; to improve housing standards; to conserve property values; and in general to promote health, safety and the general welfare. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-2) 
Sec. 70-3. - Administration. 
    No building or structure shall be erected, reconstructed or structurally altered or used, nor shall any property be used, except in accordance with the regulations provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-3) 
Sec. 70-3.5. - Interpretation and enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter shall be regarded as the minimum requirements for the protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. This chapter shall be regarded as remedial and shall be liberally construed to further its underlying purposes. 
(b)  This chapter is not intended to interfere or conflict with, abrogate, or annul any other regulation, ordinance, statute, or provision of law. 
(c)  Whenever a provision of this chapter and a provision of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation of any kind, including any other provision of this chapter, contain restrictions covering the same subject matter, the more restrictive shall govern. 
(d)  The foregoing principles notwithstanding, the city council directs those city officials responsible for enforcement of this chapter to utilize a reasonable common sense approach to the interpretation and application of the specific provisions of this chapter. To this end, city officials charged with the responsibility for enforcement and administration of provisions of this chapter shall be entitled to utilize discretion in waiving specific application requirements, provided that such discretion shall be exercised in a manner to preserve the purposes and intention of this chapter and to not jeopardize the health, safety or general welfare of the public. When exercising discretion to waive or modify any specific application requirements, said city officials shall consider: 
(1)  The scope and nature of the proposed project. 
(2)  The impact of the project on the properties in the general vicinity of the project. 
(3)  The impact of the project on municipal facilities and services, including without limitation, streets, water, sewer, drainage, police, and fire protection services. 
(4)  Whether the information contained in a requirement sought to be waived is reasonably and readily available from other materials submitted in conjunction with the application. 
(e)  Strict enforcement of each provision of this chapter shall not be required, but the city officials charged with enforcement of this chapter shall be entitled to utilize the legal principal of prosecutorial discretion. 
(Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 70-4. - Definitions. 
(a)  Word usage. Words in the present tense include the future, the singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular. The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is permissive. 
(b)  Terms defined. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory building means a subordinate building, the use of which is customarily incidental to that of the principle building and which is located on the same lot with the principle building. 
    Accessory use means a use which: 
(1)  Is subordinate (in area and intensity) to, serves, and is in conjunction with an established principal building or use; and 
(2)  Is subordinate in area, extent and purpose to the principal building or use served; and 
(3)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the principal building or use served. 
    Adult entertainment establishment means any establishment which is distinguished or characterized by the sale, rental, exhibition, performance, use, display or other offering of material, apparatus, entertainment, services and supplies which depict, describe or relate to specified sexual activities which include, but are not limited to, acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, touching, caressing or fondling of the human breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals, or any sexual acts prohibited by law; or specified anatomical areas, which means less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttocks and female breasts below the point immediately above the top of the areola; and the human genitals in a discernible turgid state, even if completely covered. 
    Alley means a minor public thoroughfare upon which the rear of lots generally abut, used for service purposes and not intended for general travel. 
    Arts and crafts fair means a gathering of producers to promote the sale of goods or commodities, the majority of which are made by hand. An arts and crafts fair shall not include a flea market. 
    Building means a structure having a roof supported by columns or walls for the housing or enclosure of persons, animals or property. 
    Building frontage means the horizontal lineal dimension of that side of a building that faces a street, a parking area, a mall or other circulation area open to the general public and having a public entrance to the building. The public entrance shall be directly adjacent to and shall front on said street, parking area, mall or other circulation area open to the public. 
    Carnival means a traveling amusement show usually including rides, games, and sideshows. A carnival is a type of commercial temporary use. 
    Carport means an accessory or secondary structure, designed to be used to shelter automobiles, enclosed on two or less sides. When a carport is attached to a mobile home or building, said structure shall constitute one side. 
    Child day care facility means a facility or home required to be licensed by the state that provides less than 24-hour care of two or more children under the age of 16 years, and not related to the owner, operator or manager thereof, whether such facility or home is operated with or without compensation for such care and with or without stated educational purposes. The term shall not apply to classes given in connection with any public, private or parochial school system or recreation facility. 
    Church means a building and accessory buildings and uses where persons regularly assemble for religious worship, ceremonies or meetings, and which is maintained and controlled by a religious body organized for the purposes of worship. 
    Circus means a public entertainment consisting typically of a variety of performances by acrobats, clowns, and trained animals. A circus is a type of commercial temporary use. 
    Commercial temporary use means any use listed in section 70-364(b), (c), or section 70-415. Commercial temporary uses are a subset of temporary uses. 
    Convenience store means a small scale store or food marts primarily engaged in retailing a limited line of goods that generally includes milk, bread, soda, and snacks. 
    Dwelling, multiple-family, means a building occupied by two or more families living independently of each other but not including hotels or motels. 
    Dwelling, single-family , means a detached building arranged and designed as a dwelling unit and intended to be occupied by not more than one family, which has not less than one bathroom. Single-family dwellings shall include any home built according to the standards of the International Building Code, as adopted by the city. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms, including at least one single kitchen, designed for or occupied as a unit by one family for living and cooking purposes, located in a one-family or multiple-family dwelling. 
    Excessive right-of-way means a right-of-way for which there are no plans, either master plans or construction plans, or the state, city or the Denver Regional Council of Governments to utilize the right-of-way for public thoroughfare. 
    Factory built home means a dwelling unit designed for one family that is partially or entirely manufactured in a factory and designed for long-term residential use when placed upon a permanent foundation. Factory-built homes must be constructed to the standards of the state Factory Built Housing Construction Certification Code (8 CCR 1302-3), as the same is amended from time to time, and must bear the insignia indicating compliance with those standards. 
    Family means a group of persons related by blood, marriage, adoption, living together and, normally but not always, consisting of one or two parents and their children, or persons living together in the relationship and for the purpose of guardian, ward or foster family who may not necessarily be related by blood or marriage to the head of the household, or a group of not more than four unrelated persons living together in a dwelling unit, except that a family shall not, with the exception of adjudicated delinquent children in foster care, include more than one individual, or two more individuals related by blood or marriage, required to register as a sex offender in accordance with state law. 
    Fence means any open or closed structure made of fencing materials used to enclose any lot or parcel of ground or use. 
    Flea market means market consisting typically of a collection of vendors selling wares from booths who pay a fee or rent to occupy a space. A flea market is not a commercial temporary use. 
    Floor area means the gross floor area of the building measured along the outside walls of the building and including each above ground floor level, but not including basements, open balconies, garages, other enclosed automobile parking area, and not including one-half of all storage and display areas for hard goods. 
    Garage means an accessory or secondary structure, designed to be used to shelter automobiles, that is enclosed on three or more sides, and which may or may not have a garage door. 
    Garbage shall have the same meaning as set forth in section 42-2. 
    Hazardous materials means any material, solid, gas or liquid, or any combination of materials which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, poses a present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, or disposed of, or otherwise managed; or which, if exposed to fire, flood or other disaster, could cause an explosion, augment a fire, render firefighting abnormally dangerous, or create a health and/or environmental hazard. Hazardous materials include, but are not limited to, explosives, reactive materials, radioactive materials, oxidizing materials, toxic materials such as pesticides and herbicides, materials corrosive to human tissue, and flammable materials with a flash point below 140 degrees excluding vehicle fuels that are regulated by the Colorado Oil Inspection Department. 
    Hazardous substance means all hazardous substances as defined in the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980 (42 USC 9601 et seq.) and in C.R.S. § 25-5-502, as amended, and petroleum or petroleum products. 
    Heavy equipment means nonmotorized merchandise of 6,000 pounds or more of empty weight, or motorized merchandise of more than 6,000 pounds empty weight, having motors of 20 horsepower or more performance. 
    Height means the vertical distance from the highest point on a structure, excepting any chimney or antenna on a building, to the average ground level of the grade where the walls or other structural elements intersect the ground. 
    Home occupation means an accessory use conducted within a dwelling that is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for dwelling purposes. 
    Hotel and motel mean a building designed for temporary occupancy by individuals who are lodged with or without meals, in which there are six or more guestrooms. 
    Junk means as set forth in section 42-2. 
    Landscaping or landscaped means any combination of living plant materials, such as trees, shrubs, grass and herbaceous plants, or decorative materials such as gravel, rock and bark, which is no more than three feet in height where within ten feet of a public street. 
    Lot means the contiguous land in the same ownership which is not divided by any public highway or alley, including any part thereof subject to any easement for any purpose other than a public highway or alley, but excluding any part thereof severed from another lot where the severance creates any nonconformity of use of a structure or a plot of land designated as a lot in any plat approved by the city and filed with the county clerk and recorder. 
    Lot, corner, means a lot bordered on the front and one or more sides by public streets. 
    Lot, enclosed, means a lot bordered on all sides by other lots. 
    Lot, interior, means a lot that is bordered on both sides by other lots and is not itself a corner lot. 
    Lot line, front, means the property line dividing a lot from a street. On a corner lot, only one street line shall be considered as a front line, and the shorter street frontage shall be considered the front line. 
    Lot line, rear, means the line opposite the front lot lines. 
    Lot line, side, means any lot lines other than front lot lines and rear lot lines. 
    Manufactured home means a dwelling unit built entirely in a factory and certified pursuant to the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. 5401 et seq., as amended. 
    Manufacturing and industrial uses means the use of a building or land for commercial production of a product, research facilities, testing laboratories, warehousing, processing, distributing, and oil and/or gas drilling or production. 
    Microbrewery means an establishment, licensed by the appropriate state and/or federal authorities, where malt liquors are manufactured, and packaged and distributed on- or off-premises, with manufacturing not to exceed 15,000 barrels of malt liquor on its licensed premises each calendar year. 
    Microwave link antenna means any spherical shape antenna which emits microwave signals that allow a central switch or relay to transfer a call between a central computer switching system and the appropriate transmitting or receiving antennas. This antenna also allows point-to-point source connection. 
    Mobile home means a factory built dwelling unit built on a permanent chassis designed for long-term residential occupancy by a single family produced prior to June 15, 1976. Mobile home does not include travel trailers, campers, camper buses, motor homes, or any closed vehicle designed to be towed by an automobile or truck. 
    Modular home means a factory built home that is built in accordance with the requirements of International Residential Code, as adopted by the city. Modular homes are transported to the residential site and installed. 
    Movable building means a building that is readily transferable. 
    Outdoor concert means a live performance, usually of music, before an audience where the venue is an outdoor location. An outdoor concert is a type of commercial temporary use. 
    Owner means a person, firm, corporation or other legal entity recorded as such on the records of the applicable county clerk and recorder, including a duly authorized agent or attorney, a purchaser, devisee, fiduciary or a person having a vested or contingent interest in the property in question. 
    Panel antenna means any antenna with vertical and horizontal planes aiming signals in specific directions for the transmission or reception of wireless communication signals. 
    Pawnshop means the business of making "contracts for purchase" or "purchase transactions." The term "contracts for purchase" means a contract wherein money is advanced to a customer on the delivery of tangible personal property by the customer on the condition that the customer, for a fixed price and within a fixed period of time not less than 30 days, has the option to cancel the contract. The term "purchase transactions" means the purchase in the course of business of tangible personal property for resale, other than newly manufactured tangible property which has not previously been sold at retail, when such purchase does not constitute a "contract for purchase." 
    Petting zoo means a collection of farm animals, such as goats, ducks, and sheep, and sometimes docile wild animals such as turtles or deer, for children to feed and pet. A petting zoo is a type of commercial temporary use. 
    Principle building or use means the main or primary purpose for which a structure or land or use thereof is designed, arranged or intended or for which it may be occupied or maintained under the regulations of this chapter. 
    Roof means the cover of any building, including eaves and similar projections. 
    Setback means the minimum distance, extending across the full width of the lot or site, between the lot line or designated boundary and that part of the building or structure closest to the respective lot line or designated boundary (excluding measurement from any building surface which, by provisions of this chapter, may occupy the respective setback area). Eaves or roof overhangs may encroach up to 24 inches into the required setback. 
    Specific uses (when used in conjunction with defining the allowable or permitted uses in the various zone districts) means those individual uses that are specifically listed under the relevant provisions of this chapter. Specific uses shall not include uses which are incorporated by reference to uses allowed in other zone districts. 
    Standards and specifications shall mean the City of Federal Heights' Standards and Specifications for Design and Construction of Public Improvements as adopted by resolution of city council and including all amendments and addendums. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected of which the use requires location on the ground or attached to something having a permanent location on the ground, except mail boxes, light fixtures, flag poles, railroad tracks and fences. For the purposes of this chapter, mobile homes shall be considered a structure. 
    Structure, temporary, means anything constructed or erected of which the use requires location on the ground or attachment to something having a temporary, non-permanent location on the ground; and necessarily associated with and ancillary to a temporary use. 
    Telecommunications facilities means the plant, equipment, and property, including but not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antennas, towers, alternative tower structures, electronics and other appurtenances used to transmit, receive, distribute, provide, or offer telecommunication services. 
    Temporary use means a use which is temporary or transitory in character, approved by the city manager or designee, or city council as necessary, and granted for a period of time determined by the specified reviewing authority within the limits provided by a temporary use permit, for the purposes provided by and pursuant to the requirements of article XIV of this chapter. By way of illustration, not limitation, temporary uses include: commercial temporary uses, community festivals, outdoor concerts, arts and crafts fairs, farmers markets, block parties, community garage sales, small scale recycling drop off locations, food drives. A privately operated flea market is not a temporary use. 
    Temporary use permit means a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of article XIV of this chapter or for a use provided by ordinance as a temporary use in any specified zone district. 
    Trash means as set forth in section 42-2. 
    Use means a use of land or property that is allowed to be carried on in that particular area under this chapter. 
    Vehicle means any motorized conveyance capable of carrying or transporting. 
    Whip antenna means any antenna cylindrical in shape that emits signals in a 360-degree horizontal plane for the transmission or reception of wireless communications signals. 
    Zone lot means a parcel of land occupied or to be occupied by a building or group of buildings and any accessory buildings identified with each, together with such open areas as are required under this chapter and having its principle frontage on a public right-of-way and having at least the minimum dimensions required by the density schedule for each zone district. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-10; Ord. No. 04-02, §§ 1, 2, 3-16-2004; Ord. No. 06-03, §§ 2, 3, 8-15-2006; Ord. No. 08-01, § 1, 1-15-2008; Ord. No. 10-09, § 15, 7-6-2010; Ord. No. 10-15, § 1, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 12-05, §§ 4-6, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 14-03, § 2, 4-15-2014; Ord. No. 17-14, § 1, 9-5-2017; Ord. No. 18-03, § 1, 4-3-2018) 
Secs. 70-5-70-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Planning commission, C.R.S. § 31-23-201 et seq. 

Sec. 70-27. - Established; composition. 
    A seven-citizen-member planning and zoning commission is established as follows: 
(1)  Two members from each ward appointed by the city council; 
(2)  One member at large from the city appointed by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 10-21-1; Ord. No. 10-01, § 1, 1-19-2010) 
Sec. 70-28. - Requirements and terms of office. 
(a)  All members shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  All members shall serve on the commission without compensation. 
(c)  No member shall also serve as a member of the board of adjustment during their term of office. 
(d)  The term of each member shall begin on January 1, following appointment by the city council. In the event that the city council appointment of a member falls after January 1, the member's term will be deemed to have begun on the January 1 prior to such appointment. The term of each member shall be two years or until his/her successor takes office. 
(e)  Members shall be appointed and may be removed by an affirmative vote of a majority of the city council. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. 
(f)  Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by the city council. 
(g)  Unless excused by the commission, a member of the commission shall be deemed to have vacated his or her position upon failure to attend required training or upon failure to attend four regular meetings within a calendar year. A member shall, after being absent from three regular meetings within a calendar year, be provided with written notice from the mayor that such member shall be deemed to have vacated his or her position if absent from any other regular meeting that year. 
(h)  All members shall attend the first available training session approved by the city council and provided during their terms of office. 
(Code 1985, § 10-21-2; Ord. No. 05-04, § 1, 5-3-2005; Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 3-5-2013; Ord. No. 14-06, § 1, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 70-29. - Chair. 
    The commission shall elect the chair with the chair's term to be one year. The chair shall be eligible for re-election. 
(Code 1985, § 10-21-3; Ord. No. 14-06, § 2, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 70-30. - Meetings. 
(a)  Subject to the cancellation provisions of this section, the commission shall hold one regular meeting each month. Such regular meeting shall be held on the last Monday of each month; provided, however, that the commission may reschedule the regular meeting for any particular month if the last Monday falls on a legal holiday or for such other good cause as may be determined by the commission. 
(b)  In the event that the chair is informed by the city staff that there will be no substantive business to be considered by the commission at the regular meeting for any particular month, the chair may, in his or her discretion, cancel the regular meeting for such month. In the event of such cancellation, members of the commission shall be notified of the cancellation by the most practical means available. A notice of cancellation shall be posted at the city's designated location for public notices. 
(c)  In the event that the chair is informed by the city staff that the review of an item is required at an earlier date than the regularly scheduled meeting, the chair may schedule a special meeting on a date when a quorum of commissioners is available to meet. Commissioners shall be notified of the rescheduled meeting by the most practical means available. A notice of the rescheduled meeting shall be posted at the city's designated location for public notices. 
(Code 1985, § 10-21-4; Ord. No. 04-03, § 1, 4-6-2004; Ord. No. 14-06, § 3, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 18-19, § 1, 1-15-2019) 
Sec. 70-31. - Duties. 
(a)  Subject to the approval of and appropriation by the city council the commission may contract with municipal planners, engineers and architects and other consultants for service as it requires. 
(b)  The commission shall make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city. Such plan shall include, but not be limited to, streets, bridges, waterways, parks, utilities, open space, buildings and zoning. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in single resolutions. The adoption of the plan, any part, amendment, extension or addition requires an affirmative vote by not less than two-thirds vote of the entire membership of the commission. 
(c)  The adoption of a master plan or any part thereof requires adoption by the city council, certification of the commission chair, and filing with the county clerk and recorder. 
(d)  The city council may overrule the commission by two-thirds vote of the entire council. 
(e)  The commission may adopt bylaws regarding its administrative duties and procedures, regarding matters to include, but not limited to, meetings, quorums, voting, attendance, and public hearings, provided that such bylaws do not conflict with the Code or Charter. 
(Code 1985, § 10-21-5; Ord. No. 14-06, § 4, 6-3-2014) 
Secs. 70-32-70-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Board of adjustment, C.R.S. § 31-23-307. 

Sec. 70-51. - Created; terms; vacancies; compensation. 
    There is hereby created a board of adjustment consisting of five regular members and two alternate members. Three of the regular members shall be citizens, one from each ward of the city, and the other four members shall be citizens at large. Board of adjustment members shall not be current members of the planning and zoning commission or the city council. The members of the board of adjustment shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. Ward members shall be appointed for two-year terms. At-large and alternate members appointed for the term commencing on March 1999, shall serve for one year. Each succeeding term for such members shall be for two years. Members may be removed only for cause upon written charges and after public hearing. Any vacancy that occurs in the board of adjustment shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant. Cause for removal shall include, but not be limited to, a board member's failure to attend required training unless excused by the city council. A board of adjustment member shall be deemed to have vacated his position upon failure to attend four regular meetings and/or hearings within a calendar year. A board of adjustment member shall, after being absent from three regular meetings and/or hearings within a calendar year, be provided written notice from the mayor that any other absence from meetings and/or hearings within that year shall be cause for removal, and such member shall be deemed to have vacated his position if absent from any other regular meeting and/or hearing that year. Board of adjustment members shall, unless excused by city council, attend the first available training session approved by the city council and provided during their terms of office. The compensation of the members of the board of adjustment shall be as set by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(A)) 
Sec. 70-52. - Voting; quorum. 
    For the conduct of any hearing or the taking of any action, a quorum of four members of the board of adjustment shall be necessary. The alternate members shall not participate or vote on any matter unless a regular member is absent. In no event shall more than five members participate or vote on any matter. The alternate members shall serve on a rotating basis. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(B)) 
Sec. 70-53. - Hearing fees. 
    All applicants requesting a hearing before the board of adjustment shall pay an application fee to the city at the time of filing the application. The actual fee shall be as prescribed by resolution in accordance with section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(C)) 
Sec. 70-54. - Reversals of orders, decisions or determinations. 
    The concurring vote of four members of the board of adjustment shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of any such administrative official, or to decide in favor of the applicant any matter upon which is required to pass under this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(D)) 
Sec. 70-55. - Election of officers; rules for proceedings. 
    The board of adjustment shall elect a chair and vice-chair at the first meeting of each calendar year and shall adopt rules governing all proceedings before it. Such rules shall provide and require that: 
(1)  Public notice shall be given of all hearings and all hearings shall be open to the public. 
(2)  Notice of all hearings shall consist of publication once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city not less than 15 days prior to such hearing and posting of the property shall consist of placing one sign, at least 30 inches square with lettering not less than 11/4 inches in height, facing and legible from the public highway on the premises of the property for which the variance is requested. 
(3)  At the public hearing, any interested party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney, offer evidence and testimony and cross examine witnesses. The chair, or in his absence, the vice-chair, shall administer oaths or accept affirmations from all witnesses and may compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(4)  All evidence and testimony shall be presented publicly. The board of adjustment may take judicial notice of facts to the same extent and in the same manner as courts of record. 
(5)  The board of adjustment shall keep a record of its proceedings and the record of proceedings shall include all documents and physical evidence considered in the case, together with a review of the evidence of the public proceedings. The record of proceedings shall be filed immediately in the city hall and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(E)) 
Sec. 70-56. - Hearing and deciding appeals. 
    The board of adjustment shall have the power to hear and decide appeals from the rulings of the administrative official where it is alleged there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the administrative official in the enforcement of chapter 10 or this chapter. In the exercise of its powers, the board of adjustment may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirements, decision or determination as ought to be made, and, to that end, shall have all powers of the administrative official. The applicant shall file with the administrative official and with the board of adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the alleged error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the administrative official. The administrative official shall forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment, all documents and physical evidence considered in the case together with the documents constituting the record, from which the appealed action is taken. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(F)) 
Sec. 70-57. - Variances. 
    The board of adjustment shall have the power to authorize, upon appeal in specific cases, such variances from the terms of this chapter as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to exceptional and extraordinary circumstances, literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will result in unnecessary hardship. Every variance authorized hereunder shall not be personal to the applicant therefor, but shall be transferable and shall run with the land. No variance shall be authorized hereunder unless the board of adjustment shall find that all of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  That the variance will not authorize the operation of a use other than those uses specifically enumerated as used by right for the district in which is located the property for which the variance is sought. 
(2)  That owing to exceptional and extraordinary circumstances, literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will result in unnecessary hardship. 
(3)  That the circumstances aforesaid were not created by the owner of the property or his predecessors and are not due to, or the result of, general conditions in the district in which the property is located. 
(4)  That the development or use of the property for which the variance is sought, if limited by a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, cannot yield a reasonable return in service, use or income as compared to adjacent conforming property in the same district. 
(5)  That the variance will not substantially or permanently injure the appropriate use or adjacent conforming property in the same district. 
(6)  That the variance will not alter the essential character of the district in which is located the property for which the variance is sought. 
(7)  That the variance will not weaken the general purposes of this chapter or the regulations established for the specific district. 
(8)  That the variance will be in harmony with the spirit and purposes of this chapter. 
(9)  That the variance will not adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(G)) 
Sec. 70-58. - Nonconforming uses. 
    The board of adjustment shall have the power, upon appeal in special cases, to grant a variance permitting an increase in either or both the land area or the floor area in a structure or structures occupied by the nonconforming use, subject to terms and conditions fixed by the board of adjustment, as will not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to exceptional and extraordinary circumstances, literal enforcement of the provisions of article IV of this chapter, will result in unnecessary hardship. No variance shall be authorized hereunder unless the board of adjustment shall find that all of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  That the use is a nonconforming use as defined by article IV of this chapter, and is in full compliance with all requirements of said chapter applicable to nonconforming uses. 
(2)  That owing to exceptional and extraordinary circumstances, literal enforcement of the provisions of said chapter will result in unnecessary hardship. 
(3)  That the circumstances aforesaid were not created by the owner of the use. 
(4)  That the variance will not further injure the appropriate use of adjacent conforming property in the same district. 
(5)  That the variance will not alter the essential character of the district in which is located the use for which the variance is sought. 
(6)  That the variance will not weaken the general purposes of this chapter or the regulations established for the specific district. 
(7)  That the variance will be in harmony with the spirit and purposes of this chapter. 
(8)  That the variance will not adversely affect public health, safety or welfare. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(H)) 
Sec. 70-59. - Use of building, structure or land for purpose of public service. 
    The board of adjustment shall have the power to permit the erection and use of a building or structure, or the use of land in any location for a public service corporation or public utility purpose that the board of adjustment deems reasonable and necessary for the public convenience and welfare. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(I)) 
Sec. 70-60. - Appeals from the board. 
    Any person aggrieved, any taxpayer, the city or the mayor may have a decision of the board of adjustment reviewed in the manner provided in the rules relating to civil proceedings. No such review shall be granted unless a petition therefor, duly verified, setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, and specifying the grounds of the illegality is presented to a court of record within 30 days after the filing of the decision of the office of the board of adjustment. The board of adjustment shall not be required to return original papers filed with it, but it shall be sufficient to return certified copies thereof or such portions thereof as may be called for. The issuance of a writ on petition hereunder shall not stay proceedings upon the decision appealed from the court, upon application after notice to the board of adjustment and on due cause shown, may grant a restraining order. 
(Code 1985, § 10-22-1(J)) 
Secs. 70-61-70-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NONCONFORMING USES AND STRUCTURES 

Sec. 70-79. - Continuation of use or structure. 
    The lawful use of land or condition of structures existing on the date of adoption or amendment of this chapter may be continued as a "legal nonconforming use or structure," although such use or condition does not conform to the regulations specified by this chapter for the district in which such building or land is located, subject to the conditions and specifications of this article. This article shall not be deemed to allow uses or conditions of structures which are prohibited, or otherwise addressed, by other chapters of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(A); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-80. - Conformance of legal, nonconforming uses of land upon discontinuance, abandonment or vacation. 
    Any legal nonconforming use of land that is discontinued, abandoned, or vacated for a period of one year shall thereafter conform to the provisions of this chapter. A legal nonconforming structure that has been abandoned, vacated, or unused for a period of one year shall thereafter conform to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(B); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-81. - Damaged nonconforming structures; restoration. 
    Except as provided in section 70-85, any legal nonconforming structure which has been destroyed or damaged by fire, explosion, act of God, by public enemy, or otherwise, to the extent of 60 percent or more of its actual value, shall thereafter conform to the provisions of this chapter. Where more than 40 percent of the actual value of the structure remains after such damage, the structure may be restored to the same nonconforming condition as it existed before such damage, provided that such restoration is completed within 12 months. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(C); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-82. - Enlargement or structural alteration of nonconforming structures. 
    Except as provided in section 70-85, legal, nonconforming structures shall not be enlarged or structurally altered except to decrease the degree of nonconformity, or to effect repairs or alterations that the building official determines are necessary to rectify a hazardous health or safety situation. A legal, nonconforming use may be extended throughout the building, provided that there are no structural alterations except those required by ordinance or applicable law, and provided that approval is granted by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(D); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-83. - Mobile home parks. 
(a)  Except in the R-4 zone district, there shall be no right to replace a mobile home/manufactured home with another mobile home/manufactured home in a mobile home park. 
(b)  In the R-4 zone district, there shall be no right to replace an existing mobile home/manufactured home in a mobile home park if the replacement mobile homes/manufactured home causes a violation of, of continues a violation of, any provision of article VIII, division 5. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(E); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-84. - Change to other nonconforming use. 
    A legal nonconforming use may be changed to another nonconforming use only if the planning and zoning commission, after a public hearing, finds that: 
(1)  The change is to a use that would have been permitted by right or as a conditional use in the zoning district at such time as the existing legal, nonconforming use became nonconforming; and 
(2)  The proposed new use does not cause an "increased impact" as defined below. An increased impact occurs when any of the following conditions exist: 
a.  The available parking is inadequate for the new use; 
b.  The new use is an expansion in size, impact or effect upon the surrounding neighborhood including, without limitation, hours of operation, parking needs, vehicle trips generated, number of employees, objectionable conditions, glare, visual pollution, noise pollution, air emissions, vehicular traffic, storage of equipment materials and refuse and on-street parking; or 
c.  The new use adds additional dwelling units. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(F); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 70-85. - Reconstruction of damaged legal, nonconforming dwellings. 
    Except as prohibited by section 70-83, legal, nonconforming dwellings, used as such, that have been destroyed or damaged by fire, explosion, act of God, by public enemy or otherwise, may be reconstructed without regard to the percentage of destruction of the actual value as provided in section 70-81. Legal, nonconforming single-family dwellings, used as such, may be modified or altered for continued single-family use, provided that such modification or alteration does not increase the degree of nonconformity as measured by section 70-214. 
(Code 1985, § 10-19-1(G); Ord. No. 04-06, § 2, 6-1-2004) 
Secs. 70-86-70-113. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AMENDMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Amendments, C.R.S. § 31-23-305. 

Sec. 70-114. - Procedure. 
(a)  Amendments to this chapter shall be made in the manner prescribed by the statutes of the state relating to the zoning ordinances of cities and towns. Wherever notice is required to be given of public hearings before the zoning commission or the city council, such notice shall consist of publication once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city not less than 15 days prior to such hearing and, in the case of amendments to the zoning map, the premises for which a zoning classification change is requested shall be posted, giving notice of such proposed zoning change for a period of not less than 15 days immediately prior to the hearing at which such change is to be considered. Posting shall consist of placing one sign at least 30 inches square with lettering not less than 1.25 inches in height facing and legible from each public roadway abutting the premises, plus such additional signs as may be required by the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  In addition, the applicant for an amendment to the zoning map shall send by certified mail, not less than ten days prior to any public hearing before city council, a notice to all fee owners of property located within 300 feet of the subject property. Such notices shall be mailed to the address of the owners as shown on the records of the county assessor's office. The notice shall set forth the date, time and location of the hearing and the applicant's proposed zoning amendment. The applicant shall present documentation evidencing compliance with this mailing requirement prior to the public hearing. 
(Code 1985, § 10-20-1(A)) 
Sec. 70-115. - Fees. 
    Each application for an amendment to this chapter shall be accompanied by a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council in accordance with section 1-16. In addition, the expenses of publication and preparation of the aforesaid signs and notices shall, in all cases, be paid for by the person or persons petitioning therefor, except where such change may be initiated by the planning and zoning commission or by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 10-20-1(B)) 
Sec. 70-116. - Changes or modifications of zoning of previously zoned property; initiation. 
    The change or modification of zoning of property previously zoned may be initiated by the planning and zoning commission, council, city manager, or person with a legal interest in the property which is the subject of the proposed zoning change. The term "legal interest," as used herein, shall mean an equitable interest in the property established by contract or right of redemption or title interest in the property. 
(Code 1985, § 10-20-1(C)) 
Sec. 70-117. - Procedures for changes or modifications. 
    The change or modification of zoning of property previously zoned shall comply with the following procedure: 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall review the requested zoning and, within 30 days after said review, make its written recommendations to the council. 
(2)  The council shall conduct a public hearing concerning the requested zoning within 45 days after the city clerk has received the written recommendations from the planning and zoning commission, which recommendations shall be a part of the council record for each such hearing. 
(3)  Within 45 days after the council hearing, the council shall either zone the property as requested by ordinance or shall deny the initiated or requested zoning by resolution, describing the reasons relied upon for denying the zoning. 
(4)  The council is hereby granted and authorized to zone conditionally particular property and, in the event the conditions imposed by the council for granting particular zoning are not complied with, to revoke such zoning. 
(Code 1985, § 10-20-1(D)) 
Sec. 70-118. - Map changes. 
    Upon the approval of any amendment of the zoning map, the planning and zoning commission shall make the necessary changes in the official city zoning district map. 
(Code 1985, § 10-20-1(E)) 
State Law reference- Amendments and changes, C.R.S. § 31-23-304. 
Secs. 70-119-70-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VESTED PROPERTY RIGHTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Vested property rights, C.R.S. § 24-68-101 et seq. 

Sec. 70-150. - Purpose of article provisions. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide the procedures necessary to implement the provisions of C.R.S. § 24-68-101 et seq. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-1) 
Sec. 70-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Site specific development plan means only the following: 
(1)  A final subdivision plat, approved by city council in conformance with the requirements of this Code. 
(2)  The city council may, by formal agreement with a property owner, designate an approval other than those described above to serve as a site specific development plan approval for a specific project. 
    Vested property right means the right to undertake and complete a certain development and use of property under the terms and conditions of a site specific development plan. Unless specifically authorized by the city council, a vested property right shall terminate three years after it is initially established. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-2) 
Sec. 70-152. - Request for site specific development plan approval. 
    For those developments for which the landowner wishes the creation of vested rights, the landowner shall specifically request the approval by the city of the designated site specific development plan as a vested right. Such request shall be made in writing at least 30 days prior to the date that the approval is to be considered. Failure of the landowner to request such an approval renders the plan not a site specific development plan, and no vested rights shall be deemed to have been created. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-3) 
Sec. 70-153. - Notice and hearing. 
    No site specific development plan shall be approved until after a public hearing, preceded by written notice of such hearing. Such notice may, at the city's option, be combined with a notice required by C.R.S. § 31-23-304, as amended, for zoning regulations, or with required notice for subdivision plats or PUD plans. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-4) 
Sec. 70-154. - Approval; effective date; amendments. 
    A site specific development plan shall be deemed approved upon the effective date of the city council approval action relating thereto. In the event amendments to a site specific development are proposed and approved, the effective date of such amendments, for purposes of duration of a vested property right, shall be the date of approval of the original site specific development plan, unless the city council specifically finds to the contrary and incorporates such finding in its approval of the amendment. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-5) 
Sec. 70-155. - Notice of approval. 
    Each subdivision plat, subdivision agreement and PUD plan constituting a site specific development plan shall contain the following language: 
Approval of this plan may create a vested property right pursuant to C.R.S. § 24-68-101 et seq. 
Failure to contain this statement shall invalidate the creation of the vested property right. In addition, a notice describing generally the type and intensity of use approved, the specific parcel or parcels of property affected and stating that a vested property right has been created shall be published once, not more than 14 days after approval of the site specific development plan, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-6) 
Sec. 70-156. - Other provisions unaffected. 
    Approval of a site specific development plan shall not constitute an exemption from or waiver of any other provisions of this Code pertaining to the development and use of property. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-7) 
Sec. 70-157. - Limitations. 
    Nothing in this article is intended to create any vested property right, but only to implement the provisions of C.R.S. § 24-68-101 et seq., as amended. In the event of repeal of said article 68 or a judicial determination that said article 68 is invalid or unconstitutional, this article shall be deemed to be repealed and the provisions hereof no longer effective. 
(Code 1985, § 10-13-8) 
Secs. 70-158-70-181. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DISTRICTS AND DISTRICT REGULATIONS

    In order to carry out the provisions of this chapter, the city is hereby divided into the following zoning districts: 
R-1 Single-family residential district R-2, R-3 Multiple-family residential district R-4 Single-family mobile home district R-5 Single-family residential district C-1 Commercial district I-1 Industrial district P-1 Park district PUD Planned unit development  
(Code 1985, § 10-1-4) 
Sec. 70-183. - Zoning map. 
(a)  The boundaries and zoning classification of districts hereby established are shown on a map attached entitled, "City of Federal Heights Zoning," which map and all notations, references, data and other information shown hereon are by this reference hereby made a part of this chapter. 
(b)  In the event uncertainty shall be deemed to exist on the zoning district map, district boundaries shall be on section lines, lot lines, the centerlines of highways, streets and alleys or other lines to be determined by the use of scales shown on the said map. 
(c)  Where a lot is divided by a zoning district boundary line at the time of the enactment of this chapter, or by subsequent amendments, the less restrictive zone requirements may be extended within the lot into the more restrictive zoning district for a distance of not more than 25 feet. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-5) 
Sec. 70-184. - Listing of uses. 
    The listing of any use in said schedule as being permitted in any particular district shall be deemed to be an exclusion of such use from any other district unless the use is specifically permitted in such other district under the language set forth in the schedule. 
(Code 1985, § 10-1-6)

(Code 1985, § 10-1-8; Ord. No. 10-15, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 13-06, § 1, 3-5-2013; Ord. No. 17-14, § 2, 9-5-2017; Ord. No. 18-03, § 2, 4-3-2018; Ord. No. 18-08, § 4, 8-7-2018)

(3)  Child day care facilities, provided that such facilities have a valid state license and city business license. 
(4)  Assisted living facilities, as defined by state statute, provided that such facilities have a valid state license. 
(Code 1985, § 10-2-1; Ord. No. 14-05, § 1, 5-20-2014)
